(8) The city commission, by majority vote of the members present, may suspend all or any of these rules to the extent permitted by law. (9) Any person who violates any of these rules may be removed from the meeting. (10) Any speaker or proposed speaker who violates these rules after first being warned by the mayor or the city commission, either or both, to cease such violation shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be guilty of an offense and punished as set forth in section 1-9. (Code 1977, § 2-33; Ord. No. 00-19, § A, 8-1-2000; Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 4-17-2012) Secs. 2-68—2-92. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - LEGISLATION
Sec. 2-93. - Preparation. All proposed ordinances shall be prepared by the city attorney. (Code 1977, § 2-41; Mo. of 2-6-1962, § 11; Ord. No. 84-5, § 1, 2-21-1984) Secs. 2-94—2-114. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CODE OF ETHICS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Codes of ethics and conflicts of interest, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-115. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. For the convenience of the reader, unless the context of the regulation specifically relates to only one set or subset of actors, the terms "official," "employee," "appointee," and "volunteer" may be used synonymously with "official" and "employee" throughout this article. Agency means the city commissioner, and all other agencies, authorities, boards, commissions, committees, departments, and offices of the city, without exception. Appointee means any person duly appointed by the city commissioner to serve on any authority, board, committee, subcommittee, agency, body, or in any other office or position. Benefit means: (1) Anything regardless of its monetary value, perceived or intended by either the one who offers it or to whom it is offered, to be sufficient in value to influence the mayor or any commissioners in the performance or nonperformance of an official act; or (2) Anything regardless of its monetary value, which, under the circumstances, a reasonably prudent person would recognize as being likely to be intended to influence the mayor or a member of the commission in the performance or nonperformance of an official action. Business means a corporation, a partnership, a limited liability company, a sole proprietor, or any other person or organization carrying on an enterprise for profit. Business relationship means an agreement between parties designed to result in an enterprise for profit to those parties. Censure means a public expression of severe criticism or reproach. Confidential information means any information, which by law or practice is not available to the general public. Contract means any lease, claim, account or demand against or agreement with any person, whether express or implied, executed or executory, verbal or in writing. Employee means any person holding a classified position as defined in policy I, section 3, of the city's personnel policy. Employment means any rendering of services on request, whether paid or unpaid. Formal reprimand means an action taken by the ethics board against a person or entity found to be in violation of this article, issued in writing to the person or entity, chastising the person or entity for the violation. The record of said formal reprimand shall be inserted into the minutes of the city commissioner. Government or city means the City of Waycross, Georgia. Immediate family means spouse, children, parents and siblings of elected officials. Interest means any direct or indirect pecuniary or material benefit accruing to a public officer or employee as a result of a contract or transaction, which is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or within the city. This does not, however, include those contracts or transactions which by their terms and by the substance of their provisions confer the opportunity and right to realize the accrual of similar benefits to all other persons and/or property similarly situated. Examples of interest include, but are not limited to, situations involving: (1) Any person in the immediate family of the official, employee, appointee, or volunteer; (2) Any person or business with whom a contractual relationship (either written or implied) exists, whereby he may receive a payment or other benefit, including an agreement for employment; and (3) Any business in which he is an officer, director, employee, prospective employee or substantial shareholder (owning or controlling in excess of five percent of the total stock or total legal and beneficial ownership). Official means any official, officer, appointee, volunteer, or member of the government of the city who is not an employee, whether elected or appointed, whether paid or unpaid, whether permanent, temporary or alternate. Official act or action means any executive, legislative, administrative, appointive or discretionary act of any official or employee of the city or any agency of the city. Official city business means work, action, attendance, or other legitimate participation in any event or activity sanctioned by the governing authority of the city. Paid means the receipt of, or right to receive, a salary or commission, percentage, brokerage or contingent fee. Participate means to take part in official acts, actions or proceedings personally as an official or employee through approval, disapproval, decision or the failure to act or perform a duty. Property means any property, whether real or personal, tangible or intangible, including currency and commercial paper. Reprimand means an expression of disapproval, either public or private. Transaction means the conduct of any activity that results in or may result in an official act or action of the city. Volunteer means a nonpaid person engaging in official city business with the approval of the governing authority. (Code 1977, § 11½-2; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-116. - Declaration of policy. (a) The proper government and administration of the city requires that: (1) Its officials, employees, appointees, and volunteers conducting official city business including those appointed by city commissioner such as commission and authority members: a. Serve others and not themselves; b. Be independent, impartial and responsible; c. Use resources with efficiency and economy; d. Treat all people fairly; e. Use the power of their position for the well-being of their constituents; and f. Create an environment of honesty, openness and integrity; (2) Governmental policies and decisions are made in the proper channels of the government structure; (3) Public office and employment not be used for undue personal gain; and (4) The citizens of the city have confidence in the integrity of their government. (b) Because the attainment of one or more of these ends is impaired whenever there exists in fact, or appears to exist, a conflict between the private interests and public responsibilities of city officials and employees, the public interest mandates that the city protect against such conflicts of interest by establishing appropriate ethical standards with respect to the conduct of its officials and employees in situations in which a conflict may exist or appear to exist. (c) Yet it is also essential to the efficient operation of the city that those persons best qualified be encouraged to serve in positions of public trust. Accordingly, the standards set forth in this article must be understood and interpreted in a way that will not unreasonably frustrate or impede the desire to seek public office by those best qualified to serve. To that end, officials and employees should not, except as otherwise provided by law, be denied the opportunity available to all citizens to acquire and maintain private, economic and other interests except when a conflict would necessarily result. (d) The policy and purpose of this article, therefore, is to clarify those standards of ethical conduct that shall be applicable to the officials and employees of the city in the discharge of their public duties and to foster the development and maintenance of a tradition of responsible and effective public service. (Code 1977, § 11½-1; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-117. - Impartiality. No official or employee shall by his conduct give reasonable basis for the impression that any person improperly can influence such official or employee or unduly enjoy such official's or employee's favor in the performance of official acts or actions, or that such official or employee is affected unduly by kinship, rank, position or association with any person. (Code 1977, § 11½-5; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-118. - Conflict of interest. No elected official, appointed officer, or employee of the city or any agency or political entity to which this Code applies shall knowingly engage in any business or transaction or have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties or which would tend to impair the independent judgment or action in the performance of official duties. (Code 1977, § 11½-7; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-119. - Abstention. An official or employee who has an interest that he has reason to believe may be affected by his official acts or actions or by the official acts or actions of the city shall disclose that interest. Such official or employee shall abstain from participating in any such discussion, voting or otherwise participating in any official acts or actions affected by such interest. That interest shall be disclosed by such official or employee prior to there being taken any official act or actions. (Code 1977, § 11½-13; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-120. - Gifts and favors. (a) No official or employee shall accept any gift, loan, reward, favor or services that may reasonably tend to improperly influence him in the discharge of their official duties. This limitation is not intended to prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value, which are distributed generally, nor to prohibit officials or employees from accepting loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that employees and officials guard against relationships, which might be construed as, or give the appearance of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion (O.C.G.A. § 16-10-2). (b) Nothing in this article shall prohibit any official or employee from accepting a gift on behalf of the city, provided that the person accepting the gift shall promptly report the receipt of such gift to the city commissioner, which shall have the gift added to the inventory of the property of the city. (c) The provisions of this article shall not apply to campaign contributions made to an official in compliance with the Georgia Campaign and Financial Disclosure Act (O.C.G.A. § 21-5-30 et seq.). (Code 1977, § 11½-6; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-121. - Coercion. No official or employee shall use his position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit or other reward to him or persons within his immediate family, or those with whom the commissioner has business or financial ties. (Code 1977, § 11½-8; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-122. - Confidential information. No official or employee shall disclose or otherwise use confidential information acquired by virtue of his position with the city for his or another's personal gain. (Code 1977, § 11½-9; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-123. - Representation. Except in the regular discharge of official duties, no official or employee shall appear on behalf of any person, other than himself and his immediate family, before any city agency or municipal court. Neither shall any official or employee receive compensation for any services rendered on behalf of any person in relation to any case, proceeding or application before a city agency with respect to which such official or employee was directly concerned; or in which he has personally participated during the period of his service or employment, or which was under his active consideration or with respect to which knowledge or information was made available to him during the period of service or employment. However, a member of the city commission may appear before city agencies on behalf of his constituents in the course of his duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations. (Code 1977, § 11½-10; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-124. - Incompatible employment. No official or employee shall engage in or accept employment with or render services for any private business or professional activity when such is adverse to and incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties. (Code 1977, § 11½-11; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-125. - Public contracts. (a) The city shall not enter into a contract involving services or property with any official or employee or with a business in which the official or employee has an interest. This section shall not apply in the case of: (1) The designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds; (2) The borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution, which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan; (3) Contracts entered into in accordance with the O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6; (4) Contracts entered into under circumstances that constitute an emergency provided that a written record explaining the emergency is inserted by the mayor into the city commissioner minutes as soon as is practicable but no later than 15 days after the contract is entered into. (5) Contracts entered into with an official or employee, or with a business in which the official or employee has an interest, provided that such contract is: a. Awarded through a process of public notice and competitive bid; b. Disclosure of the nature of such member's interest is made prior to the time a bid is submitted; and c. After this section is complied with, a waiver of the prohibition contemplated by this section is issued by the city manager. (b) The city shall not enter into any contract with, or take any official act or action favorably affecting, any person, or business represented by such person when such person has been a member of the governing authority within the 12-month period preceding such action, except when the city had a contract with such person or business prior to the member leaving office or unless the business received the contract for having the lowest and best bid pursuant to the purchasing procedures established by the city and the member did not represent the business in its discussions with or submissions to the mayor and commission. (Code 1977, § 11½-14; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-126. - Zoning. (a) All officials and employees are deemed subject to the provisions of chapter 67A of title 36 of the O.C.G.A. (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.), and shall make the disclosures required in such chapter, and shall be subject to the penalties stated in said chapter. (b) In addition, any official required to make the disclosures set forth in chapter 67A of title 36 of the O.C.G.A. (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.) shall be prohibited from participating in the zoning matter in which such official or employee has a direct or indirect interest. A violation of the aforesaid provisions of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated shall also constitute a violation of this article. (Code 1977, § 11½-15; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-127. - Preacquisition of interest. No official or employee will acquire an interest in any contract, property or other transaction in order to take advantage of such interest where the official or employee, has reason to believe the city will act upon the contract, property or other transaction to the benefit of the official or employee. (Code 1977, § 11½-16; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-128. - Disclosure of relationships. (a) Each party subject to this article shall disclose to the city commissioner, either orally or in writing, the following information: (1) Any current business interests between or among any parties subject to this article, with a description of such involvement; (2) Any business interests between or among any parties subject to this article which have been terminated within the past six months; and (3) Any business interests between or among any parties subject to this article anticipated in the next six-month period. (b) Additionally, each party subject to this article shall inform the city commissioner, either orally or in writing, of any business relationship entered into with another party subject to this article, within ten days of such contractual or implied relationship. (c) Failure on the part of any party subject to this article to comply with the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a violation of this article. (Code 1977, § 11½-19; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-129. - Use of city property. No official or employee shall use or permit the use of any city property, services, personnel, labor or other thing of value for personal gain or for any purpose other than the official business of the city. Any parties violating this provision shall be required to pay to the city a sum equal to the value of the benefits received, and shall likewise be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article. (Code 1977, § 11½-20; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-130. - City attorney used for private business. No official or employee shall use the attorney or attorneys who are under retainer by the city for personal or private business without paying just compensation. (Code 1977, § 11½-21; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-131. - Compliance with applicable laws. No official shall engage in any activity or transaction that is prohibited by any law, now existing or subsequently enacted, which is applicable to him by virtue of his office. (Code 1977, § 11½-22; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-132. - Use of government purchasing or credit cards. No elected mayor or elected city commissioner shall be issued a government purchasing card or government credit card until said elected official has signed an agreement indicating that he will use said government purchasing card or government credit card in accordance with the policies of the city and with the requirements of state law. (Ord. No. 15-26, § 1(11½-23), 10-20-2015) Sec. 2-133. - Construction, application. (a) This article shall be construed liberally to effectuate its purposes and policies and to supplement such existing laws as may relate to the conduct of the persons made subject to this article. (b) This article shall in no way be construed as creating an employment contract between the city and its officials and employees. Nevertheless, any official or employee affected by this article shall be required to affirm in writing that he has received a copy of this article and has read it and understands its provisions. (c) The propriety of any official act or action taken by or transaction involving any official or employee immediately prior to the time the ordinance from which this article is derived shall take effect shall not be affected by the enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived. (Code 1977, § 11½-25; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-134. - Distribution and acknowledgement agreement. Each person elected, appointed or otherwise hired shall be furnished a copy of this article before entering upon the duties of his office or employment. (Code 1977, § 11½-24; Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Secs. 2-135—2-164. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 2-165. - Constituting the board; chairman. (a) The board of ethics of the city is hereby created and authorized by the mayor and city commission. (b) The board of ethics shall be composed of five residents of the city to be appointed as provided in this subsection and subsection (c) of this section. Each member of the board of ethics shall have been a resident of the city for at least one year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has, or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract, transaction, or official action of the city. (c) The mayor and commissioners shall each designate two qualified citizens to provide a pool of 12 individuals who have consented to serve as a member of such board of ethics. These individuals must agree to undergo a criminal background check conducted by the police department prior to designation, and/or redesignation, the results of which will be forwarded to the mayor and commission. These individuals should be available to be called upon for a period of two years to serve in the event a board of ethics is appointed. Upon initial designation to the pool, each individual shall attend a training session on this article, conducted by the city. Annually thereafter during their term, each individual shall be required to attend a training class at city expense. The mayor and commissioner shall re-designate individuals to serve in the pool in January at the conclusion of each pool member's two-year term. Pool members can be reappointed and there shall be no term limits for the pool members since future members of commission may wish to appoint the same pool members. However, the term for individuals appointed by the mayor or a commissioner shall end after two years. The city clerk shall maintain a list of the 12 qualified individuals. If a member of the pool does not finish their term, the commissioner who designated the original member shall put forward a new designee to fill the remaining pool term. (d) During the annual training session the pool shall select a chairman at the beginning of each calendar year from the 12 qualified members listed by the commission. The chairmanship shall remain in place for a one calendar year period. The chairman shall receive additional training regarding the procedures for conducting a hearing. If the chairman leaves before the end of their term, the candidate pool member shall be replaced as set out in subsection (c) of this section and the pool members shall select a new chairman to fill out the remaining term. (e) A quorum of the member pool of the board of ethics shall be seven members. A quorum of the pool shall be required for annual training and the selection of a chairman. (Code 1977, § 11½-3(a); Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-166. - Duties of board. The constituted board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers: (1) To administer this article; (2) To receive, review, investigate, process, make determinations on, and hear complaints of violations of standards required by this article; (3) To make such investigation and response to a complaint as it deems necessary to determine whether any person has violated any provisions of this article; (4) To hold such hearings and make such inquiries as deemed necessary to investigate and rule upon complaints; (5) Recommend any legislative or administrative action regarding the city's policies and practices which the board believes would or could enhance the ethical environment in which public servants work; (6) To report its findings and actions to the city commission; (7) All other duties and powers listed in section 2-167(f). (Code 1977, § 11½-3(b); Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Sec. 2-167. - Enforcement and administration. (a) Selection time. The constituted board of ethics shall be selected within 15 days after receipt of a complaint. (b) Complaints. (1) All complaints of ethical violations must be filed with the city manager, in writing, no later than 90 days after the alleged act occurred unless the complainant, by exercising reasonable diligence, failed to discover the alleged ethical violation within such 90-day period. In such a case, the complainant must file a written complaint with the city manager not later than 90 days after the complainant discovered the alleged violation. In all such cases brought after 90 days from the date of the alleged ethical violation, the complainant bears the burden of convincing the board of the true date complainant learned of the alleged violation. (2) In no event, shall an ethical charge be filed with the city manager more than two years from the date of the alleged ethical violation. (3) Constituting a hearing board. All complaints against an official or city employee shall be filed in writing and submitted to the city manager. The city manager shall provide a copy of the complaint to the mayor and commission. a. During a public meeting of the mayor and commission the city clerk shall place 11 names of the pool members in a receptacle. The chairman of the board shall be pre-selected by the pool at its annual meeting. The city clerk will then draw six names from the nine in the receptacle. The first four pool members selected, plus the chairman, shall constitute the board for consideration of the matter at hand. The last two names selected shall be alternates in the event that some of the chosen members cannot serve. b. The city clerk shall notify the selected members of their appointment by telephone the following day and shall ask if there is any reason the member feels they cannot or should not (due to a conflict of interest) serve on the board concerning the particular complaint. c. Pay and other staff support. 1. The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation. The governing authority of the city shall provide meeting space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city, the city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for it to perform its duties and responsibilities. 2. The city attorney is designated to be the legal advisor of the board, except that the city attorney is not authorized to represent the board in any legal action if doing so would create a conflict, which would prevent the city attorney from also representing the mayor, the city manager, or the governing body. 3. The city clerk shall serve as the recording secretary to the board and shall provide such administrative services to the board as may be necessary. (4) The complainant may withdraw the complaint at any time in writing. (c) Dismissal of frivolous complaints. Within 30 days of board selection the board may perform one or more of the following: (1) Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, review the complaint to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke disciplinary jurisdiction. The board of ethics shall be empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and to add the findings and results of its investigation to the file containing such complaint; (2) Upon completion of its review and/or investigation of a complaint, the board at a public meeting may dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke disciplinary jurisdiction. Provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the board of ethics shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he might otherwise have at law or in equity against the respondent government servant. A rejection shall prevent refiling of a complaint regarding the same subject and alleged perpetrator for the same offense within six months of the original complaint filing; (3) Admonish, formally reprimand, publicly censure, any complaining party that files an unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or factually insufficient complaint; and (4) Forward an order to the mayor and commission as set out in subsection (f)(22) of this section; or (5) Hold a public hearing within 60 days after the selection of the board. (d) Parties rights. At any hearing held by the board of ethics, the official, employee, or respondent who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the allegations at least ten business days before a hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses and to present evidence and witnesses in opposition or in extenuation according to the procedures contained in subsection (f) of this section. (e) Advisory opinions. When any official, employee, or person appointed by commissioner has a doubt regarding the applicability of any provision of this article to a particular situation, or regarding the definition of its terms, he may apply in writing or verbally during a public meeting to the city attorney for an advisory opinion. The advisory opinion shall be written unless it is given verbally during a public meeting, and may be provided directly to the requestor of such opinion. Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit a request for an informal opinion by any public servant from the city attorney regarding a potential conflict of interest. Neither a request for an informal opinion, nor the making of a statement concerning a potential conflict of interest made by a member of the governing body in the course of abstaining from voting shall create a presumption or inference that a public servant actually has a personal interest in the matter about which the opinion was requested. (f) Hearing procedures. (1) At the hearing the conduct of the parties shall be dignified both on and off the record. Misconduct before the board may be grounds for summary exclusion from the hearing. The hearing is intended to receive evidence either to refute or to substantiate specific charges. It shall not be a forum for discussion of extraneous or irrelevant matters having no bearing on the charges, and the alleged misconduct of others who may have escaped discipline in the past shall serve as no defense. All parties at action and witnesses shall be given ample time and opportunity to develop points, subject to the discretion of the board. It should be recognized that the board will be composed of private citizens. Accordingly, the board may not follow established legal procedures as might be expected in a court of law. However, in taking testimony and in considering the evidence, the board shall follow accepted legal procedure insofar as is practicable but shall not be bound by the technical rules of evidence observed in courts of law. The board may listen to hearsay testimony and assign such weight as may be warranted and may accept depositions and affidavits, if such testimony is material and relevant to the issues. The board may decline to listen to numerous character witnesses or numbers of witnesses testifying to identical facts. (2) The chairman of the board of ethics shall conduct the hearing. (3) The hearing shall be recorded and the city clerk shall prepare a written summary of the hearing. The complainant and/or respondent may provide a court reporter at their expense for a verbatim transcript of the hearing, if so desired. The city clerk, or their designee shall take minutes of the hearing, specifically including the name of the board members who make any motions, the board members who second any such motions, and the names of the individuals on the board and how each voted. This written report shall be presented to the city commission at the conclusion of the board's proceedings. (4) A quorum of the board shall be required to conduct the hearing. A quorum shall be defined as five members. If a member is unable to attend the hearing, the mayor shall designate one of the alternates to replace the member. The ethics board may, before the hearing and upon ten days notice to all parties, approve regulations governing conduct of ethics board hearings so long as such regulations do not conflict with this article. (5) The person who filed the complaint ("complainant") shall present his case to the board first. (6) All documentary evidence which is anticipated to be submitted to the board at the hearing by either the respondent or the complainant, and the names, with telephone numbers, of all individuals expected to present testimony to the board on behalf of either the respondent or complainant, must be given to the city clerk at least ten days in advance of the hearing. This requirement shall not apply to evidence used solely for purposes of cross examination or rebuttal. The failure of a party to adhere to this rule shall preclude such party from tendering such evidence or individual's testimony at the hearing through any form. The respondent, complainant, and the public shall be entitled to see all such lists that are placed on file with the city clerk. (7) The board may compel the production of any document in the possession of the city and subject to Open Records Act and the testimony of any city employee except where the employee is the respondent. All evidence shall be presented to all parties pursuant to subsection (f)(6) of this section. Where the board compels any such document or testimony after a hearing has commenced a continuation shall be provided so that subsection (f)(6) of this section can be complied with. (8) Neither party shall have the right to require depositions of any individual, including the opposite party. The respondent and complainant shall have the right to obtain affidavits that may be submitted to the board for consideration provided that such affidavits were filed with the city clerk no less than 48 hours prior to the hearing, and that the name of the affiant is provided to the city clerk. Both the respondent, complainant, and the public shall be entitled to see all such affidavits, which are placed on file with the city clerk. (9) The complainant's evidence must prove that respondent is guilty of the offense charged by the evidentiary standard commonly referred to as "preponderance of the evidence." (10) Each witness presented by the complainant, and including the complainant, shall be subject to cross examination by the individual accused of the ethical violation ("respondent") or such person's representative. (11) At the conclusion of the complainant's case, the respondent shall be entitled to move for dismissal based on insufficient evidence on the part of complainant's case. If respondent makes such a motion and the board, by majority vote, agrees to dismiss the complaint, the hearing shall be terminated at this point. If either the respondent fails to make such a motion, or, if the board decides by majority vote to overrule respondent's motion, the hearing shall continue. The board may also direct a decision in favor of the respondent upon the board's own initiative. (12) Respondent shall then be entitled to present his evidence to the board. (13) Respondent is not required to testify. The absence of respondent's testimony shall not be viewed by the board as an admission of any sort. (14) If respondent testifies, then respondent shall be subject to cross examination by complainant. All other witnesses who testify in the respondent's case shall be subject to cross examination by complainant. (15) All persons who testify before the board, shall be placed under oath, by either the chairman or a person designated by the chairman. The oath shall read substantially as follows: "Do you solemnly swear or affirm that the testimony that you are about to give in this matter (name matter) shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth so help you God?" (16) At the conclusion of respondent's case, the complainant may offer rebuttal evidence only to those items presented in respondent's case. At the conclusion of complainant's rebuttal, respondent shall be entitled to offer rebuttal evidence only to those matters presented in complainant's rebuttal case. (17) During the course of testimony and at the conclusion of all the testimony and closure of all of the evidence, the board members may ask questions of any of the individuals who testified before the board. (18) At the conclusion of all questions by parties and board members, the chairman shall end the hearing and permit the board to deliberate in public. If the board decides by majority vote that additional evidence is needed to make a decision, the board shall have the authority to conduct its own investigation or to require either the complainant or respondent to submit additional evidence at a continuation of the hearing which must be held no later than 45 days after the date of the initial hearing. The board has no authority to continue the hearing past this 45-day deadline. (19) Following the conclusion of any additional evidence received at the continued hearing, the board shall continue to deliberate. When deliberations are concluded, the chairman shall call for a vote. The board may vote immediately after deliberations are concluded or they may continue the meeting for up to two weeks when a public vote must be taken. The board's first vote must be whether the respondent violated the ethics code as charged by the complainant. If, by majority vote, the board rules that the respondent did not violate the ethics code as charged by the complainant, then the matter is concluded. If the board, by majority vote, concludes that the respondent did violate the ethics code as charged by the complainant, then the board must make a second decision by majority vote. The second decision involves the form of penalty. The board shall have six options of penalty which include: a. No admonishment and no further action; b. A public reprimand and admonishment not to violate the ethics code in the future; c. Formal reprimand; d. Public censure; e. Recommendation for termination, resignation or recall; and f. Recommendation of prosecution in city court. (20) The complainant may withdraw his complaint at any time without the approval of the board. (21) If any question concerning the hearing procedures, which is not otherwise addressed in this article, the city attorney, or in his absence, the appointed legal advisor to the board shall resolve the procedural question. Such resolution shall be placed in writing by the city attorney or other legal advisor and given to both parties. Such resolution shall also be presented to the board for final approval and recommendation to amend this article by adding such procedure. (22) An order will be generated by the board and submitted to the mayor and commissioner for inclusion in the minutes within five days of the completed hearing. (g) Appeals. (1) Any final decision by the board of ethics shall be reviewable by the city commission in a public meeting set for such purpose. The request for appeal shall be filed within ten days after the issuance of a final decision by the board of ethics with the city manager. The commission will be notified of the appeal at its next regular work session and shall set a date for a hearing to be held within 45 days of the work session at which the appeal date is set. The city manager shall cause notice of the hearing to be delivered by certified mail, return receipt requested or by such other means to ensure notice to the appellant (i.e., personal service), not less than ten days prior to the date set for the hearing. At the hearing on the appeal, the appellant shall be permitted to argue his case before the mayor and commission, but shall not be permitted to present any further evidence, either documentary or testimony. The commission shall render its opinion by a public vote at the conclusion of the proceedings to: a. Affirm the decision of the board of ethics; b. Reverse the decision of the board of ethics and enter a decision of a less severe nature; or c. Remand the case to the board of ethics for further consideration. (2) Any final decision by the city commission shall be reviewable by the superior court of the county. The review by the superior court shall be limited to an inquiry of whether there was any evidence before the board of ethics and city commission which supported the decision of the commission. This appeal shall be filed within ten days after the final decision of the commission. Provided, however, no action of the city commission or board of ethics refusing or failing to take action pursuant to this code of ethics shall be reviewable by the superior court. (Code 1977, § 11½-3(c); Ord. No. 05-11, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-2005) Secs. 2-168—2-187. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
Sec. 2-188. - Unbecoming conduct as ground for removal. Conduct on the part of any officer or employee appointed by the city manager, or any department head, which in the judgment of the city manager is unbecoming to an officer or employee of the city, shall be cause for immediate removal of such officer or employee. Conduct on the part of any officer or employee selected or appointed by the city commission, which in the judgment of the city commission is unbecoming to an officer or employee of the city, shall be cause for immediate removal of such officer or employee. The term "conduct unbecoming an employee" means that conduct which constitutes a breach of the public trust or is malpractice, misfeasance or malfeasance in office. (Code 1952, ch. 2, § 1; Code 1977, § 2-69) Secs. 2-189—2-214. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-215. - Declared disaster overtime pay for exempt employees. (a) In the event that a disaster or a state of emergency is proclaimed or declared in accordance with chapter 14, article III, sections 14-99 and 14-100 of the Code and/or a disaster or a state of emergency that affects the city is proclaimed by either the county, the state, or declared by the president, exempt employees shall be compensated for the overtime hours that they work as disaster service workers. (b) Exempt employees, including the fire chief, the police chief and the exempt administration sworn personnel, working as disaster service workers shall be paid only for those hours actually worked in excess of 40 hours during their normal work week and the hourly rate of pay shall be calculated by dividing the exempt employers current annual salary by 2080 (time and one-half pay). The following exceptions in public safety shall apply: (1) Fire exempt employees working as disaster service workers shall be paid only for those hours actually worked in excess of 53 hours during their normal work week and the hourly rate of pay shall be calculated by dividing the exempt employers current annual salary by 2756 (time and one-half pay). (2) Police exempt employees working as disaster service workers shall be paid only for those hours actually worked in excess of 43 hours during their normal work week and the hourly rate of pay shall be calculated by dividing the exempt employers current annual salary by 2236 (time and one-half pay). (c) Exempt employees working as disaster service workers may, at their option, elect to take either overtime pay as described in this section or compensatory time off at the equivalent rate of pay. Accrual of such compensatory time off shall not be counted against any other limits for compensatory time off that may otherwise exist in policy or memorandum of understanding. (Ord. No. 16-25 , § 1, 12-20-2016) Secs. 2-216—2-236. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL
Sec. 2-237. - Personnel policies adopted by reference. The personnel policies of the city are hereby adopted by reference as fully as if set out at length herein. (Code 1977, § 2-171; Ord. No. 91-5, § 1, 4-16-1991) Sec. 2-238. - Purpose. The purpose of this division is to establish a system of personnel administration for the city. The system shall consist of the following merit principles: (1) Recruiting, selecting and promoting or advancing employees on the basis of their knowledge, skills and abilities. (2) Establishing pay rates and schedules consistent with the principles of comparable pay for comparable work. (3) Retaining employees on the basis of the competency of their job performance, correcting inadequate or incompetent job performance and separating or, where possible, reassigning employees whose inadequate or incompetent job performance cannot be corrected. (4) Establishing a uniform system of handling grievances and appeal rights based on the principles of due process. (5) Assuring equal opportunity to applicants and employees of the city in all aspects without regard to race, color, creed, national origin or ancestry, age, sex, political or religious affiliation. (Code 1977, § 2-178; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-1979) Sec. 2-239. - Classified and unclassified service. (a) All offices and positions of the city shall be and are hereby divided into those of classified service and those of unclassified service. (1) The classified service of employment with the city shall include all full-time positions of employment with the city, which are not specifically placed in the unclassified service to the city. Unless specifically designated otherwise, the merit system of personnel administration established herein shall apply only to employees of the classified service of employment to the city. (2) The unclassified service shall include the following: a. The mayor and members of the city commission and other elected positions. b. Members of boards and commissions, city manager, municipal court judge and judge pro tempore, city attorney, city physician, city auditor, and the following department heads and staff: city finance director, personnel director, human resources director, purchasing and property control director, garage superintendent, public safety director/police chief, fire chief, fire marshal, public works director, park and tree superintendent, streets and drainage superintendent, solid waste superintendent, community improvement director, code enforcement director, city engineer, water and sewer director, water/sewer construction and maintenance superintendent, administrative assistant to the city manager and the secretary to the city manager, and any other position for which the city commission shall approve a transfer into the unclassified service. The city manager shall establish with the city commission's approval administrative guidelines for the employment and retention of department heads and staff of the unclassified service. These guidelines shall not be a part of the personnel system or policies established herein. c. Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary and special inquiry, investigation, or examination on behalf of the city commission, a committee thereof, or the city manager. d. Temporary or part-time positions unless specifically covered by action of the city commission. (b) Nothing herein shall be construed as precluding the appointing authority from filling any position in the manner in which positions in the classified service are filled. (Code 1977, § 2-179; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-1979; Ord. No. 05-19, § 1, 7-5-2005) Sec. 2-240. - Administration officers; effect of policies. (a) Administration of personnel by city manager. The city manager shall be responsible for a personnel system conforming with the policies and principles established by this division. The city manager shall specifically be responsible for: (1) Administration of the personnel system; (2) Selection of a personnel director responsible for the technical direction and operation of the personnel system; (3) Appointment, removal, suspension and discipline of all employees of the city subject to the policies set forth in this division, the city Charter and state and federal law. This authority may be delegated, at the discretion of the city manager, to the personnel director or other department heads; (4) The establishment of the number of city employees in the various city departments and offices and determination of duties and compensation of employees in accordance with the policies set forth in this division and subject to budget limitations and approval of the city commission; and (5) Performance of other duties in personnel administration as may be prescribed by law, this division and policies established hereunder. The city manager or his authorized agent shall be responsible for certification that the persons employed in the classified service have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this division and the policies hereunder. No city disbursing or auditing officer shall make or approve or take any part in making or approving any payment for personal service to any person holding a position in the Waycross city government unless said payroll voucher or account of such pay bears the certification of the city manager or his authorized agent. (b) Administration by personnel director. The city manager shall appoint a personnel director, whose appointment shall be confirmed by the city commission. The personnel director shall: (1) Administer, under the direction of the city manager, the personnel system as set forth in this division, and the personnel policies; (2) Recommend to the city manager personnel rules and regulations. Recommend changes to the personnel policies and to this division from time to time for the effective administration of the personnel system; (3) Maintain the administration of the classification and pay plan; (4) Develop, coordinate and administer recruiting and training programs for the city and its employees in order to have the best suited employee for a particular job; (5) Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness including training, safety, health and counseling; (6) Administer benefits; (7) Oversee and administer the maintenance of comprehensive personnel records of all the employees of the city; (8) Direct and administer the affirmative action program of the city; (9) Make an annual report to the city manager and city commission regarding the work of the department. (c) Administration of personnel policies, generally. (1) The personnel policies shall have the force and effect of law. The city manager shall present to the city commission personnel policies, rules and regulations for review and approval by the commission. The policies shall be effective following approval by the commission and after posting the notice and effective date of the proposed personnel policies, additions or changes thereto, for four weeks on the bulletin board or other posting place of every employee work site of the city; and issuance of a memorandum to all employees giving notice of a change in the policies. This memorandum shall be distributed one time only with the employees' paycheck approximately four weeks prior to the effective date of the policy change. During the four-week period, employees may voice any comments regarding the changes in the personnel policies. (2) The policies will cover specific procedures and policies governing the following phases of the personnel system: a. Administration of a position classification plan. b. Administration of a pay plan. c. Announcement of employee vacancies, acceptance of applications and selection methods. d. Establishment of promotional policies. e. Evaluation of the work of employees, including those serving probationary periods. f. Separation from service of employees by resignation, layoff, suspension and/or dismissal. g. Establishment of work schedules, attendance and leave regulations. h. Development of employee training and safety programs. i. Uniform system of handling all grievances and appeals. j. Rules governing the outside employment of city employees. k. Maintenance and use of necessary personnel forms and records. l. Such other matters as may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of this division. (Code 1977, § 2-180; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-1979) Sec. 2-241. - Discrimination prohibited. Illegal discrimination against any employee in recruitment, examination, appointment, training, promotion, retention, discipline or any other aspects of personnel administration shall be prohibited. (Code 1977, § 2-181; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-1979) Sec. 2-242. - Severability. If any policy or order hereunder, or application of such provision to any person or circumstances, shall be held invalid, the remainder of and the applications of such provision of such policy or order to persons or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid, shall not be affected thereby. It is hereby declared as the intent that the policy or order would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included therein. (Code 1977, § 2-182; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-1979) Secs. 2-243—2-262. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - DEPARTMENTS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-263—2-287. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY IMPROVEMENT DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-288. - Created. There is hereby created a new department of the city to be known as the department of community improvement. (Code 1977, § 2-134; Ord. of 8-6-1963, § 1) Sec. 2-289. - Functions. The department of community improvement is authorized and empowered, and it shall be the duty and function of such department, to plan, establish, and carry on a workable program of rehabilitation, redevelopment, and improvement of property within the city, and to perform such additional duties and functions as may be prescribed by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 2-135; Ord. of 8-6-1963, § 2) Sec. 2-290. - Director. The administrative head of the department of community improvement shall be known as the director of community improvement. (Code 1977, § 2-136; Ord. of 8-6-1963, § 3) Sec. 2-291. - Enforcement of state minimum standard codes. It is the policy of the city to enforce the mandatory minimum standard codes and amendments thereto pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-20(9)(B)(ii) and 8-2-25. The city shall enforce those permissive minimum standard codes and amendments thereto that are adopted by the city as set forth in section 103-47. (Code 1977, § 2-137; Ord. No. 95-06, § 1, 2-7-1995) Secs. 2-292—2-315. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PURCHASING DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-316. - Created. There is hereby created a department of the city to be known as the department of purchasing. (Code 1977, § 2-191; Ord. No. 78-23, § 1, 10-3-1978) Sec. 2-317. - Functions. The purchasing department is authorized and empowered, and it shall be the duty and function of said department to purchase, acquire and secure all the materials, equipment, vehicles, supplies and contractual services required and requisitioned for the operations and functions of all city departments and agencies; also, to maintain records, logs and controls for inventory of equipment and vehicles; and dispose of surplus materials, equipment, vehicles and supplies declared as obsolete by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 2-192; Ord. No. 78-23, § 2, 10-3-1978) Sec. 2-318. - Director. The administrative head of the department of purchasing shall be known as the director of purchasing and shall be appointed by the city manager, subject to the confirmation of the city commission, in like manner as are the heads of the other departments of the city. (Code 1977, § 2-193; Ord. No. 78-23, § 3, 10-3-1978) Sec. 2-319. - Staff. The purchasing department shall consist of a director and such staff as may, in the judgment of the purchasing director and city manager, be necessary to the proper discharge of duties and operations of such department. All members of the purchasing department of the city shall be employees of the city. (Code 1977, § 2-194; Ord. No. 78-23, § 4, 10-3-1978) Sec. 2-320. - Operations of purchasing system. (a) The purchasing director shall procure and purchase all the materials, equipment, vehicles, supplies and contractual services for the city using competitive bidding from suppliers, to attain and buy from the "lowest and best" bidders meeting specifications. All purchases and contracts estimated to cost over $5,000.00 shall be based on: (1) Formal written bids, and shall have written notices, newspaper advertisements, specifications, sealed bids, public opening of bids, bid deposits or bonds as deemed necessary; (2) Formal request for proposals; or (3) With prior approval of the city manager, online auction services, including, but not limited to, reverse auction services; and shall be approved by the city commission. All purchases and contracts estimated to cost from $1,500.00 to $5,000.00 shall be based, wherever possible, on written competitive quotations, by letter inquiry or formal written bids, as deemed applicable by the purchasing director and the city manager, and shall be approved by the purchasing director and the city manager. All purchases and contracts estimated to cost under $1,500.00 shall be based, wherever possible, on competitive quotations, either from telephone or letter inquiry and shall be approved by the purchasing director. "Lowest and best bid" criteria shall include price, and in addition the purchasing director, city manager and city commission shall consider ability, capacity, skill, character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, efficiency, previous performance, compliance to law, service, maintenance ability and financial resources of bidders. Products shall be evaluated on quality, availability, adaptability, delivery time and future maintenance and service. (b) Notwithstanding any provisions of this Code to the contrary, the city commission may proclaim an emergency and may authorize the city manager or his designee to procure by purchase or lease such goods and services as are deemed necessary and appropriate for the city's emergency response effort. This emergency procurement may be made in the open market with or without advertisement. The city manager shall use his best efforts to obtain competitive pricing for such emergency goods and services, and shall, where possible require sealed bids for such goods and services, and advertise for the procurement for such goods and services. Such emergency procedures shall not be used in violation or contravention of state and federal laws or regulations. The city manager shall provide for the commission a full written report of all procurements, together with a requisition for the required goods and services during the emergency. (Code 1977, § 2-195; Ord. No. 78-23, § 5, 10-3-1978; Ord. No. 04-03, §§ 1, 2, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 05-02, § 1, 1-18-2005) Sec. 2-321. - Surplus disposal. The purchasing director shall offer to public sale by sealed bid procedures, public auction, or through a duly authorized online market, all city material, equipment, vehicles and supplies that have been declared unusable and/or obsolete. Any sealed bid shall be advertised, opened in public and the highest and best bid shall be considered as buyer unless specified otherwise by the city commission. Any public auction shall be conducted using a licensed auctioneer and following standard public auction procedures. For use of the online market, the property shall be posted and sold in accordance with the terms of the approved host site, with the property going to the highest and best bidder. (Code 1977, § 2-196; Ord. No. 78-23, § 6, 10-3-1978; Ord. No. 01-21, § 1, 11-6-2001; Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 5-17-2005) Sec. 2-322. - Procedures and regulations. The purchasing director is hereby authorized and directed to adopt such written regulations as may be necessary to the implementation of this division. Any regulations adopted by the purchasing and property control director shall become effective 30 days after submission to the mayor and city commission unless the regulations are disapproved by the mayor and city commission within 30 days. Copies of the regulation shall be filed in the office of the purchasing director and made available for public inspection during business hours. (Code 1977, § 2-197; Ord. No. 78-23, § 7, 10-3-1978) Sec. 2-323. - Awards to county bidders. (a) Notwithstanding the terms and provisions of section 2-320 and any other terms or provisions of any other section of this Code, the city shall procure or purchase materials, equipment, vehicles, supplies and contractorial services from the lowest and best county bidder (as defined in subsection (b) of this section); provided, however, that the lowest and best county bidder must submit a bid in accordance with the terms and provisions of sections 2-316 through 2-322, inclusive; further provided that the lowest and best county bidder submits a bid which does not exceed the lowest and best bid from a bidder who is not a county bidder by the lesser of five percent or $1,000.00; further provided that if no county bidder submits a bid or if all county bids exceed the lowest and best bid from a bidder who is not a county bidder by more than the lesser of five percent or $1,000.00, then the bid shall be awarded to the lowest and best bidder, irrespective of the location of the bidder. (b) The term "county bidder" means a bidder who, at the time the bid is submitted (and for a period of at least 30 days prior thereto), maintains an office or place of business within the county, and employs at least one employee who works at, from, or out of said office or place of business. (c) In determining the lowest and best county bidder, the purchasing director, city manager and commission shall consider ability, capacity, skill, character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, efficiency, previous performance, compliance to the law, service, maintenance ability, and financial resources of bidders. Products shall be evaluated on quality, availability, adaptability, delivery time, and future maintenance and service. (Code 1977, § 2-199; Ord. No. 87-23, § 1, 7-7-1987) Secs. 2-324—2-349. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - FINANCE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-350—2-371. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ACCOUNTING STANDARDS FOR BUREAUS, AGENCIES, ETC., RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FROM THE CITY
Sec. 2-372. - Purpose. The ordinance from which this division is derived is enacted for the purpose of establishing accounting standards and requirements and shall apply to any agency as defined herein. (Code 1977, § 4½-1; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-1), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-373. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Agency means each bureau, authority, agency, commission, committee, organization, corporation or other body which receives financial assistance from the city. Financial assistance means grants and payments to an agency but not payments for goods and services rendered. Noncompliance means failure to act in accordance with the laws, regulations and contractual terms governing financial assistance that an agency received from the city. (Code 1977, § 4½-2; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-9), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-374. - Certification. Each agency as defined in this division or in any contract with the city shall provide to the city annually, within 30 days of the commencement of the fiscal year of the city: (1) Certification by an agency duly authorized and elected officers that said officers are duly elected and authorized to execute the certification. (2) That the agency has in operation an accounting system (satisfying generally accepted accounting principles) that will safeguard assets of the agency including, but not limited to, financial assistance funds from the city. (3) Such other certification that may be required in this division, applicable laws, and by contract with the city. (Code 1977, § 4½-3; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-2), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-375. - Internal control structure. Each agency as defined in this division or in any contract with the city shall adopt and enforce an internal control structure sufficient to control the use of its funds especially those which it receives from the city to ensure that said funds are used in accordance with the purposes of the city and in accordance with applicable laws. The officers of each agency shall certify compliance with this section annually at the same time that they give the certification required by section 2-374. (Code 1977, § 4½-4; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-3), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-376. - Line item budget. Each agency shall adopt annually a line item budget showing anticipated receipts and anticipated expenditures, and giving the purpose and amount of such receipts and expenditures. Each agency shall furnish the city, within 30 days of the commencement of the fiscal year of the city, a certificate by its officers that such budget has been adopted. (Code 1977, § 4½-5; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-4), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-377. - Financial report—Quarterly. In addition to the other requirements of this division, each agency shall provide to the city during the months of January, April, July and October of each year an accurate financial report showing actual receipts and expenditures on a quarterly and year-to-date basis as compared to the budget adopted by such agency. (Code 1977, § 4½-6; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-5), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-378. - Same—Annually. Each agency shall prepare and file with the city within 45 days of the end of the fiscal year of the agency an annual financial report of the agency's actual receipts and expenditures together with a comparison of the actual budget with such receipts and expenditures. (Code 1977, § 4½-7; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-6), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-379. - Audits. Each agency which is required by applicable law to cause all or part of its funds or accounts to be audited shall cause such audit to be conducted and a copy of all written audit reports, exhibits, appendices, and attachments shall be given to the city within ten days after such audit reports are completed. (Code 1977, § 4½-8; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-7), 11-6-1990) Sec. 2-380. - Noncompliance. If any agency should be guilty of noncompliance with any term or provision of this division or in violation of any applicable law or regulation requiring financial audits, statements or reports, the city shall be authorized to cease providing further financial assistance to such agency. The city shall be entitled to a refund from such agency of all such financial assistance provided to the agency during the period in which the agency is in noncompliance. (Code 1977, § 4½-9; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1(4.1-8), 11-6-1990) Secs. 2-381—2-403. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FIXED ASSETS
Sec. 2-404. - Capitalization and depreciation. Whenever the city purchases a fixed asset, the cost of which is $5,000.00 or greater, the city shall capitalize such fixed asset and depreciate the same in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Expenditure of less than $5,000.00 can be currently expended. (Code 1977, § 4½-21; Ord. No. 01-01, § 1, 1-2-2001) Secs. 2-405—2-421. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM
Sec. 2-422. - Short title. This division shall be known as the identity theft prevention program. (Code 1977, § 4½-31; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-423. - Purpose. The purpose of this division is to comply with 16 CFR 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Code 1977, § 4½-32; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-424. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Covered account means: (1) An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and (2) Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefor. Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. Customer means a person that has a covered account with a creditor. Identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. Personal identifying information means a person's credit card account information, debit card information bank account information and drivers' license information and for a natural person includes their social security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. Red flag means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. Service provider means a person that provides a service directly to the city. (Code 1977, § 4½-33; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-425. - Findings. (a) The city is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. (b) Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include water, sewer, garbage, and yard trash accounts. (c) The city's previous experience with identity theft related to covered accounts has been limited. The city does have customers attempting to open accounts with suspicious documents. (d) The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account and making payments on such accounts have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. (e) The city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts (f) The city determines that there is a moderate risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways: (1) Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; (2) Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; (3) Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; and (4) Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment. (Code 1977, § 4½-34; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-426. - Process of establishing a covered account. As a precondition to opening a covered account in the city, each applicant shall provide the city with personal identifying information of the customer consisting of a valid government issued identification card containing a photograph of the customer, social security card and in the case of a property owner, proof of ownership. Written authorization is required to change service. (Code 1977, § 4½-35; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-427. - Access to covered account information. (a) Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel. (b) Such password shall be changed every 90 days, shall be at least six characters in length and shall contain letters, numbers and symbols. (c) Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the city manager and the password changed immediately. (d) Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city manager and the city attorney. (Code 1977, § 4½-36; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-428. - Credit card payments. (a) In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third party service provider, such third party service provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. (b) All credit card payments made over the telephone or the city's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer data base. (c) Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account. (Code 1977, § 4½-37; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-429. - Sources and types of red flags. All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: (1) Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: a. Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; b. Identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; c. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; d. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or e. An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled. (2) Suspicious personal identification, such as suspicious address change. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: a. Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example: 1. The address does not match any address in the consumer report; or 2. The Social Security Number (SSN) has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. b. Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of birth. c. Personal identifying information or a phone number or address, is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the financial institution or creditor. d. Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address, mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity. e. The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers. f. The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. g. The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. h. Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor. i. The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. (3) Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts. (Code 1977, § 4½-38; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-430. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. (a) In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to his immediate supervisor. If, in his discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the finance director, who may in his discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the finance director in his discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the finance director: (1) Contact the customer; (2) Close the account. (b) In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall use his discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to his immediate supervisor. If, in his discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the finance director, who may in his discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the finance director in his discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the finance director: (1) Request additional identifying information from the applicant; (2) Deny the application for the new account; (3) Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or (4) Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Code 1977, § 4½-39; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 2-431. - Updating the program. The city council shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the council, update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft.
