At the time of renewal of a certificate of registration for a vicious dog, a dog control officer shall verify that the owner is continuing to comply with provisions of this article. Failure to renew a certificate of registration within ten days of the renewal date or initial classification date shall constitute a violation of this chapter. (h) The owner of a classified dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose or has attacked a human and shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog has died or has been euthanized. (i) A vicious dog shall not be transferred, sold, or donated to any other person unless it is relinquished to a governmental facility or veterinarian to be euthanized. (j) The owner of a classified dog who moves to the city shall register the classified dog within ten days of becoming a resident. (Code 1977, § 6-37; Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, 11-15-2011) Sec. 10-125. - Confiscation of dogs; payment of costs for recovery; euthanasia. (a) A dangerous dog or vicious dog shall be immediately confiscated by any dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer in the case of any violation of this chapter. A refusal to surrender a dog subject to confiscation shall be a violation of this chapter. (b) The owner of any dog that has been confiscated pursuant to this chapter may recover such dog upon payment of all reasonable confiscation and housing costs and proof of compliance with the provisions of this chapter, unless such confiscation is deemed to be in error by a dog control officer, an animal control board, or a probate court. All fines and all charges for services performed by a law enforcement or dog control officer shall be paid prior to owner recovery of the dog. Criminal prosecution shall not be stayed due to owner recovery or euthanasia of the dog. (c) In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this chapter within 14 days of the date the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be released to an animal shelter or euthanized in an expeditious and humane manner. The owner may be required to pay the costs of housing and euthanasia. (Code 1977, § 6-38; Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, 11-15-2011)

div.head: Chapter 12 - CEMETERIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Cemeteries generally, O.C.G.A. § 10-14-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 12-1—12-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CITY CEMETERIES
Sec. 12-19. - Permit required. No interment or disinterment shall be permitted in any city cemetery without a permit being first secured from the office of the city clerk and delivered to the public works director. (Code 1977, § 8-1; Ord. of 10-18-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 84-2, § 1, 1-24-1984) Sec. 12-20. - Lot prices, burial fees, etc. The price of grave lots, grave fees and other charges which may be imposed in connection with any city cemetery shall be as determined by the city commission from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 8-2; Ord. of 10-18-1955, §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 84-2, § 1, 1-24-1984) Sec. 12-21. - Sale of lots, interments, etc. (a) No interments shall be permitted or allowed by the public works director on a cemetery lot or portion thereof prior to said cemetery lot being paid for in full. (b) No cemetery lot shall be sold or reserved prior to the payment of at least one-half of the necessary fees. (c) Those persons making installment payments to the city for the purpose of securing a cemetery lot shall be required to execute a cemetery lot reservation agreement. (d) Persons making installment payments to the city to secure a cemetery lot shall pay interest at the city's prevailing rate, which is 12 percent annually. Payment schedules to purchase cemetery lots shall not exceed 12 months. (Code 1977, § 8-3; Ord. No. 84-2, § 1, 1-24-1984) Sec. 12-22. - Concrete vaults required; exception. (a) No interment in any city cemetery shall be permitted without the use of a concrete vault. Each such concrete vault shall be buried to such a depth that there will be a minimum of 12 inches of earthen cover between the top of the vault to the natural ground level. (b) The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not be required for interments within any area of any cemetery designated for the interment of paupers. (Code 1977, § 8-4; Ord. No. 84-18, § 1, 5-15-1984; Ord. No. 87-03, § 2, 2-17-1987) Sec. 12-23. - Work in city cemeteries to be performed in accordance with public works department regulations. In any city cemetery, all grave digging, monument installation, interment, disinterment, coping and any other work, of every nature and description, shall be performed in accordance with regulations established by the public works department. (Code 1977, § 8-5; Ord. No. 87-03, § 3, 2-17-1987)

div.head: Chapter 14 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND EMERGENCY SERVICES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 14-1—14-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-20 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 14-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Emergency management means the preparation for the carrying out of all emergency functions other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies, disasters, or the imminent thereat thereof, of manmade or natural origin caused by enemy attack, sabotage, acts of domestic or international terrorism, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, radiological action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, fire-fighting services; police services; emergency medical services; rescue; engineering; warning services; communications; defense from radiological, chemical, biological and other specials weapons to include weapons of mass destruction; evacuation of persons from stricken areas; emergency welfare services; consequence management functions to include victim services; emergency transportation; plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services; and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. (Code 1977, § 9-1; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § I; Ord. No. 78-22, § I, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § I, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 93-29, § 1A, 12-6-1993) Sec. 14-20. - Emergency powers. In the event of the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency in any part of Waycross-Ware County is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by the federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts and available resources of the several localities and relief organizations in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby, the mayor of the city with the concurrence of the chairman of the county commission, or in their absence, their legally appointed successor, may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: (1) To enforce all rules, laws, and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control of all civil forces and helpers in Waycross-Ware County. (2) To seize, take for temporary use, or condemn any property for the protection of the public in accordance with condemnation proceedings as provided by law. (3) To sell, lend, give, or distribute all or any such property among the inhabitants of the county, to account to the proper agency for any funds received for the property. (4) To perform and exercise such other functions and duties, as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population of Waycross-Ware County. (Code 1977, § 9-2; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § IV; Ord. No. 78-22, § IV, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § IV, 2-19-1980) Sec. 14-21. - Volunteers. All persons, other than officers and employees of Waycross-Ware County, performing emergency functions pursuant to this article, shall serve with or without compensation. If compensation is granted, rates of pay will be based on type and nature of services performed. While engaged in such emergency functions, volunteers shall have the same immunities as city and county officers and employees. Services performed by private enterprise such as industry, utility companies, etc., at the direction of local government shall be compensated in the same manner as volunteers. (Code 1977, § 9-3; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § V; Ord. No. 78-22, § V, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § V, 2-19-1980) Secs. 14-22—14-45. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR
Sec. 14-46. - Office established. In agreement with the governing bodies within the entire county, there is hereby established the county emergency management agency. (Code 1977, § 9-18; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § II; Ord. No. 78-22, § II, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § II, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 93-29, § 1B, 12-6-1993) Sec. 14-47. - Appointment. The mayor and city commissioners in concurrence with the chairman and commissioners of the county shall nominate, for appointment by the state director of emergency management, a director of emergency management for the entire county. (Code 1977, § 9-19; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § II; Ord. No. 78-22, § II, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § II, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 93-29, § 1C, 12-6-1993) Sec. 14-48. - Duties. When appointed, the director of emergency management is charged: (1) To represent the governing officials of the city and the county on matters pertaining to emergency management; (2) With assisting county and city officials in organizing county and city resources for emergency operations; (3) With developing in conjunction with the city and county departments, the Waycross-Ware County basic plan for emergency functions set forth in section 14-19. Such plan will be consonant with the state emergency plan and shall be submitted to the county commission and/or city commission for approval and thence to the state director for approval; (4) With maintaining the emergency management agency in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management and disaster program including the rendering of required reports to the state emergency management office; (5) Rendering reports such as financial, daily activity, etc., as required by governing officials in keeping with good business practices; (6) Procuring, with the consent of governing officials, a facility to be used as the city-county emergency operating center; and (7) During periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of city and county governing officials, coordinate the activities of the city-county emergency operating center staff. (Code 1977, § 9-20; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § II; Ord. No. 78-22, § II, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § II, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 93-29, § 1D, 12-6-1993) Secs. 14-49—14-69. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ORGANIZATION
Sec. 14-70. - Establishment. The county emergency management office shall be established around existing city-county departments and agencies. (Code 1977, § 9-32; Ord. of 6-20-1972, § III; Ord. No. 78-22, § III, 9-19-1978; Ord. No. 80-6, § III, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 93-29, § 1E, 12-6-1993) Secs. 14-71—14-98. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STATE OF EMERGENCY CURFEW
Sec. 14-99. - When authorized. The mayor shall have the right to declare an emergency to exist when, in his opinion, one or more of the following conditions exists: (1) That there is extreme likelihood of danger of destruction of life or property due to unusual conditions, regardless of whether it is a natural or manmade disaster. (2) Unusual or extreme weather conditions, making use of city streets or areas difficult or impossible. (3) Civil unrest, commotion or uprising is imminent or exists. (4) There is a stoppage or loss of electrical power affecting a major portion of the city. (Code 1977, § 9-46; Ord. of 10-17-1967, § 1; Ord. No. O17-01 , § 1, 1-3-2017) Sec. 14-100. - Emergency powers. After declaration of such emergency, the mayor shall have the right to exercise any or all of the following powers: (1) The power to use employees of the city to assist in the safety and preservation of life, limb and property of citizenry of the city. (2) The power to close streets and sidewalks and to delineate areas within the city wherein an emergency exists. (3) The power and authority to remove debris which poses an immediate threat to life, public health and safety, significant damage to improved public and private property, and the economic recovery of the city. (4) The power and authority to enter upon and remove debris from public and private roads, rights-of-way, storm drainage easements, and ingress/egress easements with the city limits, including private communities, for the purposes of emergency vehicle travel, stormwater conveyance, protecting public health and safety, facilitating response and recovery operations, and for any other purpose the city manager determines is necessary to remove an immediate threat to life, public health and safety, significant damage to improved public and private property, and the economic recovery of the city. (5) The power to impose emergency curfew regulations. (6) The power to close business establishments within the affected area. (7) The power to close any and all municipally owned buildings and other facilities to the use of the general public. (8) The power to do any and all acts necessary and incidental to the preservation of life, limb and property of the citizenry. (Code 1977, § 9-47; Ord. of 10-17-1967, § 1; Ord. No. O17-01 , § 1, 1-3-2017) Sec. 14-101. - Duration. (a) No emergency power as set forth herein may be effective for more than 72 hours after the declaration of an emergency by the mayor. However, upon declaration of a second or further emergency to exist the emergency powers as set forth herein may be exercised during such further emergency period or periods but never for more than 72 hours in one declared emergency period. (b) No emergency period shall extend beyond the next regular, special or called meeting of the city commission. (Code 1977, § 9-48; Ord. of 10-17-1967, § 1) Sec. 14-102. - Area affected. The declaration of an emergency as to a portion of the city shall specify with exactness the area in which the emergency is declared to exist. (Code 1977, § 9-49; Ord. of 10-17-1967, § 1) Secs. 14-103—14-132. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STREET AND BUILDING NUMBERING
Sec. 14-133. - Posting of visible street numbers required. (a) The owner of any parcel or tract of real estate within the city on which a structure is located, whether residential or otherwise, shall post on the building, house or structure, or its appurtenant mailbox or mailboxes, or in its yard, the appropriate street number of the residence or occupant located on said property. The posted street number shall be mounted in such a fashion as to be visible from the public street fronting said property. Except as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, the street numbers shall be at least two inches in height and shall be of contrasting color to the background. (b) Notwithstanding the terms of subsection (a) of this section, with respect to: (1) Structures and buildings newly constructed and occupied after April 30, 1998; (2) Existing structures and buildings modified and occupied after April 30, 1998; (3) Addresses changed as a result of action by county emergency 911 system; and (4) Buildings without address numbers thereon as of April 30, 1998; the street numbers shall be at least four inches in height and shall be of contrasting color to the background. (Code 1977, § 12-60; Ord. No. 85-35, § 1, 11-5-1985; Ord. No. 98-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-21-1998) Sec. 14-134. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Street number. (1) For purposes of section 14-133, the term "street number" means the Arabic number or series of numbers assigned to a structure within the city by the office of code enforcement. (2) Upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, it shall be presumed for purposes of compliance herewith that the street number presently being used on any structure within the city is the street number for said structure. (Code 1977, § 12-61; Ord. No. 85-35, § 1, 11-5-1985) Sec. 14-135. - Enforcing official; issuance of warning; citation. The chief of the police department shall be empowered to enforce the provisions of this article and shall have the authority to issue citation for a violation thereof. Such warning shall be submitted to the property owner in writing by certified or registered mail, allowing ten days for said property owner to remedy said violation. (Code 1977, § 12-62; Ord. No. 85-35, § 1, 11-5-1985) Sec. 14-136. - Penalty for violation of article provisions. The penalty for any violation of this article, upon citation issued by the chief of the police department pursuant to section 14-135, shall be the general penalties for violation of ordinances of the city as set forth in section 1-9. (Code 1977, § 12-63; Ord. No. 85-35, § 1, 11-5-1985)

div.head: Chapter 16 - FAIR HOUSING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Fair housing, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-200 et seq.
Sec. 16-1. - Discriminatory housing practices prohibited. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-3-220, the city hereby adopts the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 8-3-202, 8-3-203 and 8-3-204, as adopted and amended as if fully set out herein. (Code 1977, § 16-21; Ord. No. 78-12, § 1, 5-16-1978) Sec. 16-2. - Complaint procedure. Any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice or who believes that he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur may file a complaint with the director of the department of community improvement. The complaint shall be in writing and shall contain such information and be in such form as the director requires. Upon receipt of such a complaint, the director shall furnish a copy of the same to the person who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged discriminatory housing practice. Within 30 days after receiving a complaint, the director shall investigate the complaint and give notice in writing to the person claiming to have been injured whether he intends to resolve it. If the director decides to resolve the complaint, he shall proceed to try to eliminate or correct the alleged discriminatory housing practice by informal methods of conference, conciliation and persuasion. In the event the director has been unable to obtain voluntary compliance with this chapter, after acting with reasonable promptness, he shall so notify the person claiming to have been injured. The person claiming to have been injured may then commence a civil action in any appropriate court against the respondent named in the complaint, to enforce the rights granted or protected by this chapter, insofar as such rights relate to the subject of the complaint. (Code 1977, § 16-25; Ord. No. 78-12, § 5, 5-16-1978)

div.head: Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Obstruction of public administration and related offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-20 et seq.; damage to and intrusion upon property, O.C.G.A. title 16, ch. 7; prescribed burning, O.C.G.A. title 12, ch. 6; fire department, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Open burning and outdoor fires. (a) Prohibition; exceptions. It is unlawful for any person in any area of the city to cause, suffer, allow or permit open burning of any vegetative matter such as leaves, grasses, pine straw, pine cones, tree limbs or stumps, including the "slash burning" of forest residue for land-clearing purposes; of refuse, trash, or rubbish of any kind; of any materials which include soils or are in contact with soils during burning; of any other open-burning material; or to use for open burning any noncontainment devices such as air-curtain destructors, common backyard fireplaces or fire pits dug into the ground; or to suffer, allow or permit open burning that will be offensive or objectionable because of smoke or odor emissions when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous, except as follows: (1) Any grill, barbeque or other metal framework using charcoal, wood, propane or natural gas for cooking food for immediate human consumption, provided no nuisance is created. (2) Operation of devices using open flames such as kettles, blow torches, welding torches, portable heaters, and other flame-making equipment, provided that the use of such equipment does not violate other local or state law. (3) Training fire department personnel under the supervision of the fire chief or his designee. (4) Silviculture practices specifically related to "prescribed burning" under authority of the state forestry commission, as exempted from local ordinance, resolution, and regulation by the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. For purposes of this subsection, the term "prescribed burning" of any forest land means a "permitted" fire set by the owner or owner's designated agent under controlled conditions to burn forest understory and used as a forest management practice to establish favorable seedbeds, remove competing underbrush, accelerate nutrient recycling, control insect pests, enhance wildlife habitat, and otherwise contribute ecological benefits. Not exempted is the burning of leaf or brush piles not necessary to accomplish the purposes of prescribed burning. (5) Chimeneas or any other similar commercially produced freestanding vessels made of metal in which a contained outdoor fire is made; or fire pits made from stones, masonry or similar material for keeping a contained outdoor fire and used for cooking or warmth, provided no nuisance is created. (6) Burn barrels, as long as the burn barrels are at least 25 feet away from any building or structure and on private property. Any burn barrel shall have vent holes above the ash line for combustion air and shall be covered with a heavy mesh wire screen. Untreated wood or lumber shall be the only material or substance allowed in burn barrels and must not produce dense smoke or create any nuisance. Burn barrels shall be constantly attended and supervised by a competent person of at least 18 years of age until the fire is extinguished and cold. (7) Bonfires, being a large open air fire used as part of a celebration, provided that a bonfire shall not be conducted within 150 feet of a structure or any combustible material or growth. Conditions which would cause a fire to spread within 150 feet of a structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition of the bonfire. Except as otherwise provided by law, a permit must be obtained from the city fire department prior to kindling a fire for a bonfire. Application for such permit shall only be made by the owner of the land upon which the fire is to be kindled or the duly authorized representative of such owner. Any permit issued under this section is good only for the day issued. (8) Open burning of vegetative material for the purpose of land clearing using an air curtain destructor, provided the following conditions are met: a. The location of the air curtain destructor is at least 300 feet from any occupied structure or public road or private road. An air curtain destructor used solely for utility line clearing or road clearing may be located at a lesser distance upon approval of the department of natural resources, or environmental protection division; b. No more than one air curtain destructor is operated within a ten-acre area at one time or there must be at least 1,000 feet between any two air curtain destructors; c. Only wood waste consisting of tress, logs, large brush and stumps which are relatively free of soil are burned in the air curtain destructor; d. Tires or other rubber products, plastics, heavy oils or asphaltic based or impregnated materials are not used to start or maintain the operation of the air curtain destructor; e. The air curtain destructor is constructed, installed and operated in a manner consistent with good air pollution control practice for minimizing emissions of fly ash and smoke; f. The cleaning out of the air curtain destructor pit is performed in a manner to prevent fugitive dust; and g. The air curtain destructor cannot be fired before 10:00 a.m. and the fire must be completely extinguished, using water or by covering with dirt, at least one hour before sunset. (9) The fire department shall investigate any complaint about fire or smoke. Any fire started or maintained in violation of this section is a nuisance prohibited by section 26-19 and shall be promptly extinguished by the person or persons responsible for same upon notice by the fire chief or his designee. (b) Permit required. Except as otherwise provided by law, a permit must be obtained from the city fire department prior to kindling a fire for recognized silvicultural or range or wildlife management practices, or prevention or control of disease or pests or bonfires. Application for such permit shall only be made by the owner of the land upon which the fire is to be kindled or the duly authorized representative of such owner. (c) Revocation of permit. The city fire chief or his designee may revoke a permit issued pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, when the fire chief or his designee finds by inspection or otherwise that: (1) The permit is used for a location or establishment other than that for which the permit was issued; (2) The permit is used for a condition or activity other than that authorized in the permit; (3) The conditions and limitations set forth in the permit have been violated; (4) There have been any false statements or misrepresentations as to a material fact in the application or permit or plans submitted therewith or a condition of the permit; (5) If neighbors complain about the smoke. (d) Attendance. Open burning, bonfires or recreational fires shall be constantly attended by the permittee or other person designated in the permit until the fire is completely extinguished. A minimum of one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose or water truck, shall be kept at the fire location and available for immediate utilization to extinguish the fire. (Code 1977, § 12-2; Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 10-19-2004; Ord. No. 16-24 , § 1, 12-6-2016) Sec. 18-2. - Tampering with fire hydrant. It shall be unlawful for any person, without written authority from the fire chief, to tamper with or take water from or release water from a public fire hydrant. (Code 1977, § 12-2) Secs. 18-3—18-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 18-23. - Composition. The city shall maintain a fire department composed of a chief of the fire department and such subordinate officers as may, in the judgment of the chief of the fire department and the city manager, be necessary to the proper discipline and handling of the fire department, together with such number of firefighters as may, in the judgment of the city commission, be necessary for the proper discharge of the duties of such department. All members of the fire department shall be officers of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 8, § 1; Code 1977, § 12-17) Sec. 18-24. - Oath of members. All members of the fire department shall take and subscribe an oath before the city clerk to fairly and impartially discharge their duties. If the city clerk is absent for any reason whatsoever, the oath shall be administered by the city attorney. In addition, the oath taken and subscribed shall comply with the requirements of O.C.G.A. §§ 45-3-1—45-3-10. (Code 1952, ch. 8, § 2; Code 1977, § 12-18; Ord. No. 14-24, § 1, 10-21-2014) Sec. 18-25. - Selection of firefighters. The chief of the fire department, when properly selected, shall select persons whom he thinks are qualified to be firefighters. The names of the persons so selected shall first be submitted to the city manager, and the city manager shall submit the list of such officers to the city commission with the recommendation that they be selected by the city commission as firefighters of the city. Should the names submitted meet with the approval of the city commission, the persons shall be duly elected, and declared to be firefighters of the city, according to the recommendation of the city manager. If the city commission shall see fit to reject the name of any person so submitted, then the chief of the fire department shall select another person whose name shall be submitted to the city manager, who, if he approves, shall submit the name to the city commission. This method of selection shall be continued until the city commission shall have approved of the selections of the chief of the fire department and the city manager for all of the members of the fire department. (Code 1952, ch. 8, § 6; Code 1977, § 12-22) Secs. 18-26—18-53. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STATE MINIMUM FIRE CODES
Sec. 18-54. - Adoption. For the purposes of establishing uniform rules and regulations, the city commission hereby adopts the State Minimum Fire Safety Standards as set forth in the rules and regulations of the office of safety fire commission, chapter 120-3-3, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated (together with all parts and subparts thereof, including, without limitation, all indices and appendices) as fully as if set forth at length herein and from the date the ordinance from which this article is derived shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling with respect to minimum fire safety standards and relating to the public safety, health and general welfare within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1977, § 12-78; Ord. No. 00-10, § 1, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 15-22, § 1, 9-1-2015) Sec. 18-55. - Appeals. Any person or entity receiving written notice from the appropriate official of the city of noncompliance or deficiencies in his property under this article may, within 15 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the zoning board of appeals. Said appeal shall state the location of the property, the date of the notice of violations, and the number of such notice. The appellant must state any defenses to the alleged violations, if any. (Code 1977, § 12-79; Ord. No. 00-10, § 1, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 15-22, § 1, 9-1-2015) Sec. 18-56. - Enforcement. The regulations and code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be enforced by the fire chief, or the person designated by said fire chief. (Code 1977, § 12-81; Ord. No. 00-10, § 1, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 15-22, § 1, 9-1-2015)

div.head: Chapter 20 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Smokefree Air, O.C.G.A. § 31-12A-1 et seq.; tattoo studios, O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 20-1—20-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SMOKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN AREAS WITHIN BUILDINGS AND INDOOR FACILITIES OF THE CITY
Sec. 20-20. - Legislative intent. The city commission finds that the effects of secondary, tertiary and side-stream smoke generated by the smoking of cigars, cigarettes, pipes and similar articles poses a threat to the health, safety and well-being of the citizens of the city who do not smoke. The city commission further finds that the Surgeon General's reports on smoking hazards, linking high levels of involuntary smoke exposure buttresses the need to provide more protection to non-smokers in public settings. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to place reasonable limitations on smoking within buildings and indoor facilities and city owned or leased vehicles of the city, while striking a balance between the health needs of all non-smoking individuals and the rights of smokers. The city commission further finds that it is in the interest of public health, safety, and general welfare of the employees, residents and visitors of the city to protect them from the impacts of breathing secondary, tertiary or side-stream smoke in buildings and indoor facilities and vehicles owned, leased, managed and operated by the city. (Code 1977, § 15-52; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 11-04, § 1, 4-4-2011) Sec. 20-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Designated smoking area means a separate enclosed room where smoking is permitted and which: (1) Is not frequented by the public or non-smoking employees; (2) Is not a work area, restroom or meeting room; and (3) Is not the only employee lounge area. Non-smoking area means an area in which smoking is prohibited. Personnel policies means the city personnel policies as the same may be amended from time to time. Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette or any other combustible substance or substances, including, without limitation, tobacco which is used for the purposes of inhaling or exhaling the smoke therefrom. Violation means the failure by any person to comply with any section of this article the failure of any person to observe any restrictions on smoking that are promulgated as a result of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-53; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 20-22. - Prohibitions on smoking. Except as otherwise provided in this article, within all buildings, structures and indoor facilities, city vehicles, owned, operated, leased or managed by the city, and which are used by or open to the public, including therein, private offices, hallways, restrooms, escalators, elevators, stairways, lobbies, reception and waiting rooms, classrooms, meeting or conference rooms, auditoriums, lounges, all smoking is prohibited. (Code 1977, § 15-54; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 11-04, § 1, 4-4-2011) Sec. 20-23. - Posting of "No Smoking" signs. The city manager or his designee shall cause "No Smoking" signs to be conspicuously posted in any public place where smoking is prohibited. The size, design, and wording of such sign shall be left to the city manager or his designee. Further, the city manager or his designee shall determine the basis for clarity, sufficiency, and conspicuousness in communicating the intent of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-55; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 20-24. - Enforcement authority. The city manager and/or his designee and/or the chief of police and/or his designee shall have authority to enforce the provisions of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-56; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 20-25. - Designation of smoking areas. Notwithstanding the terms and conditions of this article, the city manager or his designee shall establish designated smoking areas to accommodate in a reasonable manner city employees who smoke. The city manager or his designee shall post "Smoking" signs within or upon the area designated as the designated smoking area. Further, smoking in a designated smoking area shall not be a violation of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-57; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 20-26. - Applicability of article provisions. It is further the intent of this article that the terms and provisions herein apply to employees of the city, as well as to citizens and visitors in and upon city buildings and indoor facilities as described in this article. (Code 1977, § 15-58; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 20-27. - Violations by city employees. (a) It is further the intent of the city commission and it is hereby enacted that this article shall constitute a rule, regulation, policy, practice and directive as contemplated by the city personnel policies and a violation thereof by a city employee shall constitute conduct constituting grounds for corrective discipline pursuant to such personnel policies. (b) It is further the intent of the city commission that any city employee violating the terms and provisions of this article, upon the first violation only, shall not be subject to corrective discipline as set forth in said personnel policies. However, upon the second or subsequent violation such employee shall be subject to corrective discipline as set forth in said personnel policies. (c) Nothing in this article shall limit the procedural standards established and set forth in said personnel policies. (d) Nothing in this section is intended to limit the applicability of section 20-22 to city employees who are found guilty before the judge of the municipal court of violating the terms of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-59; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 15-12, § 1(15-59(d)), 7-7-2015) Sec. 20-28. - Penalty for violations. (a) Any person violating the provisions of this article upon conviction before the judge of the municipal court shall be punished as follows: (1) First offense ..... Warning. (2) Second offense ..... Fine of $10.00. (3) Third offense ..... Fine of $25.00. (4) Fourth offense ..... Fine of $50.00. (5) Fifth and all subsequent offenses ..... Fine of $100.00. (b) The municipal court judge shall have the authority and discretion to suspend or probate any part of the sentence; further, the municipal court judge may permit the sentenced party to perform community service in lieu of payment of a fine at the rate of $5.00 per hour. The performance of such community service shall be in compliance with such conditions as the municipal court judge may order. Persons accused of violating this article may be arrested and required to post a bond for future appearance. Violations of this article shall be tried in the municipal court. Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1977, § 15-60; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 15-12, § 1(15-60), 7-7-2015) Secs. 20-29—20-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FOOD SERVICE RULES
Sec. 20-60. - Adoption. For the purposes of establishing uniform rules and regulations, the city commission hereby adopts and enacts the rules of the department of human services of public health chapter 290-5-14, food service, including subsections 290-5-14-01, 290-5-14-02, 290-5-14-03, 290-5-14-04, 290-5-14-05, 290-5-14-06, 290-5-14-07, 290-5-14-08, 290-5-14-09, 290-5-14-10 as set forth in the rules and regulations of said department of human services effective July 31, 1995, as amended through the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated (together with all parts and subparts thereof, including, without limitation, all indices and appendices) as fully as if set forth at length herein and from the date the ordinance from which this article is derived shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling with respect to the subject matter thereof, and relating to the public safety, health and general welfare within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1977, § 15-91; Ord. No. 01-03, § 1, 2-6-2001) Sec. 20-61. - Appeals. Any person or entity receiving written notice from the appropriate city official of noncompliance or deficiencies in his property under this article may, within 15 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the city clerk. Said appeal shall state the location of the property, the date of the notice of violations and the number of such notice. The appellant must state any defenses to the alleged violations, if any. (Code 1977, § 15-92; Ord. No. 01-03, § 1, 2-6-2001) Sec. 20-62. - Enforcement. The regulations and code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be enforced by the county health department and the enforcement officer or officers of the county health department shall be the sanitarian and sanitation officer for the purpose of this article. (Code 1977, § 15-94; Ord. No. 01-03, § 1, 2-6-2001) Secs. 20-63—20-82. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - TATTOO/BODY-PIERCING STUDIOS AND ARTISTS
Sec. 20-83. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish reasonable standards for individuals performing tattoo and body-piercing procedures and for the facilities from which the procedures are provided. Such standards should ensure the health and safety of all individuals performing and receiving these services. (Code 1977, § 15-102; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-84. - Exemptions. These regulations do not apply to a physician or osteopath licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-1 et seq., or a technician acting under the direct supervision of such licensed physician or osteopath. (Code 1977, § 15-103; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-85. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Antibacterial solution means any solution used to retard the growth of bacteria approved for application to human skin and includes all products labeled accordingly. Appropriate disinfectant means an EPA-registered disinfectant or a 1:10 dilution of bleach and water. Body piercing means the creation of an opening in an individual's body other than the individual's ear, to insert jewelry or other decoration. Body-piercing artist means any person who performs body piercing. County means the local county board of health or its duly authorized representatives. Currently licensed health care professional includes physicians, registered nurses (RN), licensed practical nurses (LPN), and licensed emergency medical technicians. Department means the department of human resources of the state. Governing body means the partnership, the corporation, the association, or the person or group of persons who maintain and control the tattoo/body-piercing studio and who are legally responsible for the operation of the studio. OSHA means Occupational Safety and Health Association. Permit means the authorization granted by the county to the governing body to operate a tattoo/body-piercing studio. Plan of correction means a plan for correcting deficiencies in meeting rules and regulations of the department of human resources. Sanitary means clean and free of agents of infection or disease. Sanitized means effective antibacterial treatment by a process that provides sufficient concentration of chemicals for enough time to reduce the bacteria count including pathogens to a safe level on equipment. Sterilization means holding an instrument in an autoclave for required length of time at 15 to 30 pounds pressure at a temperature of 273 degrees Fahrenheit or 121 degrees Celsius. Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in, piercing, or implanting indelible pigments or dyes under the skin. Tattoo artist means any person who performs tattooing. Tattoo/body-piercing studio means any permanent building or structure on a permanent foundation, holding a valid city or county business license and permit from the county board of health, wherein a tattoo/body-piercing artist performs tattooing or body piercing. (Code 1977, § 15-104; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-86. - Governing body. (a) The governing body shall be responsible for compliance with the requirements in O.C.G.A. § 41-40-1 et seq., with applicable administrative rules and regulations of the county board of health, including, but not limited to, all applicable statutes, rules and regulations regarding disclosure of ownership. (b) Prior to being granted a permit, each tattoo/body-piercing studio shall develop a written statement of policies and procedures outlining the responsibilities of management. (1) Tattoo/body-piercing artists shall not be under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs while performing tattoo/body-piercing procedures. (2) No person shall be tattooed or pierced who appears to be under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs. (3) No animals, except for guide dogs accompanying blind persons, shall be allowed in the tattoo studio. (4) No minors are to be tattooed (O.C.G.A. § 16-5-71), or receive body piercing. (5) Written report of any infection or allergic reaction resulting from the application of a tattoo or body piercing shall be forwarded to health department within five working days of its occurrence or knowledge thereof. (6) Tattoo artists shall not remove an existing tattoo from a person. (Code 1977, § 15-105; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-87. - Minimum floor plan requirements. The following minimum floor plan requirements shall apply to tattoo/body-piercing studios: (1) The tattoo/body-piercing studio shall be constructed, arranged, and maintained as to provide adequately for the health and safety of its customers. (2) The studio shall be constructed in a manner to allow the customer receiving the tattoo/body piercing adequate privacy from observers. The work area shall be separate from the waiting area. (3) Tattoo/body-piercing studios must have adequate ventilation. (4) Walls and ceilings must be painted or covered in a manner which would allow for easy and effective cleaning. Paint or covering must be light in color. (5) Floors of the work area must not be carpeted. Surfaces shall be of a nonabsorbent material that would allow for effective cleaning by conventional methods. (6) A clean and sanitary toilet and hand washing facility shall be made accessible to customers; however, it shall be separate from the work area. (7) The work area shall be equipped with at least one sink and basin providing hot and cold running water for the use of the artists for washing their hands and preparing customers for tattooing/piercing. This area shall be provided with soap, an antibacterial solution, single-use towels or air blower, and individual hand brushes for each artist. (8) The work area shall be provided with adequate lighting. (9) The work area shall not be used as a corridor for access to other rooms. (Code 1977, § 15-106; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-88. - Furnishings and fixtures. (a) Furnishings of the tattoo/body-piercing studio shall be maintained in good condition, intact, and functional. Furnishings should be made of or covered in a material that is easily cleanable and non-absorbent. The studio shall be kept clean, neat, and free of litter and rubbish. (b) Cabinets for the storage of instruments, dyes, pigments, single-use articles, carbon, and stencils shall be provided for each tattoo artist and shall be maintained in a sanitary manner which protects them from contamination. (c) Work tables and chairs shall be provided for each tattoo/body-piercing artist. (1) Surfaces of all worktables and chairs shall be constructed of material that is smooth, light colored, nonabsorbent, corrosive resistant, and easily sanitized. (2) Work tables and chairs shall be sanitized with a bactericidal solution after each application. (Code 1977, § 15-107; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-89. - Supplies. (a) Bulk single-use articles shall be commercially packaged and handled to protect them from contamination. These articles shall be stored in an area separate from the toilet facilities. (b) All materials applied to the human skin shall be from single-use containers and shall be disposed of after each use. (Code 1977, § 15-108; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-90. - Dyes and pigments. (a) All dyes and pigments used in tattooing shall be from professional suppliers specifically providing dyes and/or pigments for the tattooing of human skin. (b) In preparing dyes or pigments to be used by a tattoo artist, only nontoxic sterile materials shall be used. Single-use or individual portions of dyes or pigments in clean, sterilized individual containers or single-use containers shall be used for each patron. (c) After tattooing, the remaining unused dye or pigment in the single-use or individual containers shall be discarded along with the container. (Code 1977, § 15-109; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-91. - Piercers' jewelry. (a) Client and piercer should have appropriate size and quality jewelry chosen before the procedure begins. (b) Only appropriate jewelry should be used in piercing. Appropriate jewelry is made of implant grade, high-quality surgical stainless steel (316 LVM series), solid 18K gold, niobium, titanium, or platinum. Appropriate jewelry has no nicks, scratches, or irregular surfaces that might endanger the tissues. (c) Ear studs or other jewelry designed for earlobe piercing are not appropriate jewelry for other body parts and must not be used by piercers. (Code 1977, § 15-110; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-92. - Sanitation. (a) Prior to the start of the tattoo/body-piercing procedure the artist should inspect his hands for hangnails, small cuts, sores, and abrasions. If a cut, sore, or abrasion is detected, a bandage should be applied for added protection before gloving. Trim fingernails to ensure that gloves are not punctured. (b) All jewelry such as watches, rings, etc., should be removed prior to the start of the tattoo procedure. (c) Before working on each client, the fingernails and hands of the tattoo/body-piercing artist shall be thoroughly washed and scrubbed with warm water, and antibacterial soap, using an individual hand brush that is clean and in good repair. The hands should then be dried by either an air blower or by single-use towels prior to beginning work on each client or when interrupted in the process. (d) Single-use disposable latex or neoprene vinyl examination gloves shall be worn during the tattooing process. Gloves shall be changed and properly disposed of each time there is an interruption in the application of the tattoo, the gloves become torn or punctured, or whenever their ability to function is compromised. (e) Each artist shall wear a clean outer garment, apron or smock. These items shall be changed after each client. (f) Tattoo/body-piercing artists who are experiencing symptoms of diarrhea, vomiting, fever, rash, or skin infections shall refrain from tattooing/body-piercing activities. (g) Adequate numbers of sterilized needles and tubes must be on hand for each artist for the entire day and night operation. (h) Only single-use disposable razors shall be used to shave the area to be tattooed. (i) Smoking and consumption of food or drink is prohibited in tattoo/body-piercing studios. (j) Universal precautions are to be followed per OSHA standards and guidelines. (Code 1977, § 15-111; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-93. - Sterilization. (a) An operational sterilizer (autoclave) shall be provided in each tattoo/body-piercing studio. (b) Nondisposable instruments shall be kept in a separate puncture resistant container until brush scrubbed in hot water and soap, and then sterilized by autoclaving. (c) The following procedures should be followed during the sterilization process: (1) Prior to being placed in the autoclave all equipment shall be bagged, labeled, dated and sealed. (2) Each autoclave bag may hold no more than one liner and shader tube with needle and bar inserted into tube. (3) To protect needle tips from damage an appropriate sterile protective covering shall be placed on the needle tip. (4) From a cold start, instruments shall remain in the autoclave according to manufacturer's specifications. (5) If the process begins with a hot start, the instruments should be processed according to manufacturer's specifications. (6) To achieve proper sterilization, temperature must reach 273 degrees Fahrenheit and 15 to 30 psi. (7) Spore indicators shall be used each time and the results must be kept in a log at the location for a minimum of three years. (d) If using pre-sterilized equipment, documentation must be on file from equipment manufacturer that describes the method of sterilization meeting the manufacturer's recommendations for storage and maintenance of sterility. (Code 1977, § 15-112; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-94. - Tattoo preparation. (a) Before placing the tattoo design on the client's skin, the artist shall treat the skin area with an antibacterial solution. (b) If an acetate stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be thoroughly cleaned and rinsed in a germicidal solution for at least 20 minutes and then dried with sterile gauze or dried in the air on a sanitized surface after each use. (c) If a paper stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be single use and disposable. (d) If the design is drawn directly onto the skin, it shall be applied with a single-use article only. (Code 1977, § 15-113; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-95. - Body piercers. Body piercers shall: (1) Set up equipment in front of client. (2) Open sealed autoclave bags containing sterile equipment in front of client, and discard the autoclave bag. (3) Disinfect all jewelry contaminated with only airborne pathogens (not previously worn or contaminated) with a non-hazardous hard surface disinfectant approved by the EPA. All jewelry contaminated or potentially contaminated with bloodborne pathogens (previously worn by another person) should be autoclaved, stored in sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated. (4) Pre-sterilize all needles used in piercing, use only on one person, at one sitting, for a single piercing, and immediately dispose of in a medical sharps container. (5) Pre-sterilize all forceps, tubes, etc., in sealed, dated, sterile indicator bags. These items are to be used on one person, in one sitting. After one such use, they must be autoclaved and stored in sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated. (Code 1977, § 15-114; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-96. - After tattoo/body piercing application. (a) The completed tattoo shall be washed with a single-use towel saturated with an antibacterial solution. (b) After the area has dried, apply a thick layer of antibacterial ointment from a collapsible or plastic tube. (c) A bandage shall then be applied to the tattoo using sealed telfa (non-sticking) pads. (d) Verbal and written instructions, approved by the county health department for the care of the body art procedure site shall be provided to each client by the operator upon completion of the procedure. The written instructions shall advise the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection and contain the name, address and phone number of the establishment. These documents shall be signed and dated by both parties, with a copy given to the client and the operator retaining the original with all other required records. The facility shall also post in public view the name, address and phone number of the county health department and the procedure for filing a complaint. The notice for filing a complaint shall be included in the establishment application packet. (Code 1977, § 15-115; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-97. - Disinfection of workplace. (a) Each tattoo/body-piercing studio must be kept clean and sanitary. The owner must develop and implement a cleaning schedule that includes appropriate methods of decontamination and tasks or procedures to be performed. This written schedule must be based on the location within the studio, the type of surfaces to be cleaned, type of possible contamination present, the tasks or procedures to be performed, and their location within the studio. (b) The following procedures should be adhered to: (1) Clean and sanitize all equipment and work surfaces with an appropriate disinfectant after completion of tattoo/body-piercing procedures and at the end of work shift when surfaces have become contaminated since the last cleaning. (2) Remove and replace protective coverings such as plastic wrap and aluminum foil after each tattoo/body-piercing procedure. (3) Inspect and decontaminate, on a regular basis, reusable receptacles such as bins, pails, and cans that have a likelihood for becoming contaminated. When contamination is visible, clean and decontaminate receptacles immediately, or as soon as feasible. (4) Studios should be free of insects, rodents and vermin. (Code 1977, § 15-116; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-98. - Disposal of waste. (a) Needles, razors, or other sharp instruments used during tattoo/body-piercing procedures, shall be placed in puncture resistant, closed containers immediately after use. (b) Needles shall not be purposely bent or broken, or otherwise manipulated by hand. (c) Containers of sharp waste shall be sent to a biohazardous waste facility where they are either incinerated or otherwise rendered non-hazardous in compliance with 29 CFR 1920.1030, pertaining to occupational exposure to bloodborne pathogens. Record of disposal must be kept on site. (d) Disposable waste shall be placed in easily cleanable, closed containers provided with tight fitting lids, to prevent leakage or spillage. (e) Waste containers shall be kept closed when not in use. (f) Disposable waste shall be handled, stored, and disposed of to minimize direct exposure of personnel to waste materials. (g) The containers shall be located as near as feasible to the area of use. These containers shall not be overfilled. (Code 1977, § 15-117; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-99. - Personnel/operator/artist permit. (a) No person shall practice body art procedures without first obtaining an operator/artist permit from the county health department. (b) The operator/artist permit shall be valid from the date of issuance and shall automatically expire in one year and must be renewed annually unless revoked sooner by the department. (c) Application for operator/artist permits shall include: (1) Name; (2) Date of birth; (3) Sex; (4) Residence address; (5) Mailing address; (6) Phone number; (7) Place of employment as an operator/artist; (8) Training and/or experience; (9) Proof of attendance at a bloodborne pathogen training program and first aid course given or approved by the county board of health; (10) Physical examination; (11) Criminal history report; (12) Fingerprinting; (13) Photograph. (d) All operator/artist permits shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where they may be readily observed by clients. (e) Persons performing the tattoo/body-piercing operation shall be 18 years of age or older and maintain current certification in CPR first aid and have proof of attendance at a bloodborne pathogen training program (or equivalent), given or approved by the county health department. Training/courses provided by professional body art organizations/associations may also be submitted for consideration. (f) The certification required in subsection (e) of this section must be obtained prior to the permit being issued. (g) The artist must obtain a physical examination by a licensed physician within 12 months prior to employment or initial application for permit. The examination must be sufficiently comprehensive to assure that the artist is free of communicable diseases. (h) Proof shall be provided upon request that all operators have completed the Hepatitis B vaccination series; that antibody testing has revealed that the employee is immune to Hepatitis B; or that the vaccine is contraindicated for medical reasons. Contraindication requires a dated and signed physician's statement specifying the name of the employee and that the vaccine cannot be given. (Code 1977, § 15-118; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-100. - Client files. (a) For each client, proper records of tattoos administered shall be maintained by the studio. (b) Records of each client shall be prepared prior to the procedure being performed and shall reflect the client's name and signature, address, phone number, type of positive picture ID, proof of age, date tattooed, design, its location and name of the artist. (c) A statement of informed consent by the individual receiving the tattoo must be maintained on file. (d) A statement by the client attesting that he is not under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs shall be on file. (e) A copy of procedures signed by the client advising them of proper subsequent care of the tattoo shall be maintained on file. (f) A copy of instructions signed by the client informing them on the risks involved and possible complications that might result from the tattoo/body-piercing procedure must be maintained on file. (Code 1977, § 15-119; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-101. - Application for permit. (a) The governing body of each tattoo/body-piercing studio shall submit to the county health department an application for a permit to operate under the rules and regulations. No tattoo studio shall be operated and no tattooing/body piercing performed without such a permit which is current under these rules and regulations. (b) The application for permit shall be made on forms provided by the county board of health. (c) Each application for a permit shall be accompanied by a floor sketch of the tattoo studio showing windows, doors, room measurements, chairs, tables and equipment placement for clients and/or staff. (d) A listing of the names of all staff including the owner who will be working in the studio shall be included with the application for a permit. This listing shall include the full name of each staff person. (e) The ownership of the studio shall be fully disclosed in its application for a permit. (f) Zoning and other local requirements regarding proper location and establishment of tattoo studios shall be addressed by the applicant with the responsible local officials. (Code 1977, § 15-120; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-102. - Permit. (a) The governing body of each tattoo/body-piercing studio shall obtain a valid permit from the county board of health prior to beginning operation. Every year effective January 1 of each year, a permit must be obtained. To be eligible for a permit the studio must be in compliance with these rules and regulations. (b) The permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises. (c) Permits are not transferable from one studio to another. (d) A permit shall no longer be valid and shall be returned to the county board of health when the studio ceases to operate, is moved to another location, the ownership changes, or the permit is suspended or revoked. (e) A studio which fails to comply with these rules and regulations shall be subject to the sanctions available to the county board of health pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq., including, but not limited to, denial or revocation of its permit by the county board of health. (Code 1977, § 15-121; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-103. - Inspections. (a) The studio and its records shall be available for review and examination by properly identified representatives of the county board of health. (b) A copy of the inspection report shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises and also shall be available for public inspection at the county health department wherein the studio is located. (Code 1977, § 15-122; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003) Sec. 20-104. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) Enforcement of these rules and regulations shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq., and this Code. (b) No person shall engage in tattooing/body piercing except in a licensed studio. All tattoo artists must have an operator permit. No tattoo studio shall be operated without a permit. Failure or refusal to file an application for a permit shall constitute a violation of this Code. (c) The county board of health may refuse to grant a permit for the operation of any tattoo studio that does not fulfill the minimum requirements of these rules and regulations and may revoke a permit that has been issued and invoke other sanctions if a studio violates any of these rules and regulations. Before any order is entered refusing a permit applied for or revoking a permit the applicant or permit holder shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing before the county board as provided in O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq. The notice of refusal or revocation shall contain directions on how a hearing may be requested. (d) The county board of health is empowered to institute appropriate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enjoining violation of any applicable provision of O.C.G.A. title 31, or of the rules and regulations. (e) Any person convicted of a violation under this article by the municipal court shall be punished as set forth in section 1-9. (Code 1977, § 15-123; Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 12-2-2003)

div.head: Chapter 22 - LAW ENFORCEMENT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 22-1—22-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-19. - Personal property in possession of police department. All personal property, not including firearms, motor vehicles and bicycles, coming into the possession of the police department from any source which has been abandoned by its owner, where the owner is unknown, where the owner cannot be located or where the owner has not responded within 90 days to notice given by the police department for the owner to claim and take possession of said personal property, wherein the item is not contraband and has no foreseeable evidentiary value, shall be considered abandoned property and disposed as herein provided in this article. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-20. - Attempt to locate owner. Due diligence will be made to locate the rightful owner of any personal property coming under the provisions of this article and to give notice to the owner to claim and take possession of personal property in the possession of the police department. "Due diligence" means, but shall not be limited to, the mailing of a letter by first-class mail to the last known address of the owner as indicated in the incident report. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-21. - Disposition of abandoned property. Any personal property, not a firearm, motor vehicle or bicycle, in the possession of the police department which is abandoned, where the owner is unknown or not claimed by its owner within 90 days after notice has been sent by first-class mail to the owner shall be disposed as provided by O.C.G.A. § 17-5-54 (e) or other applicable law of this state. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-22. - Records. Records will be maintained showing the manner in which each item came into possession of the police department, a description of the property, all efforts to locate the owner, any case or docket number, the date of publication of any newspaper notices, and the date of the sale, if any. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-23. - Bicycles. Bicycles which may come into possession of the police department as a result of being abandoned or recovered shall be kept for a period of 90 days, and every reasonable effort will be made to determine the owner thereof. If, after 90 days, it cannot be determined to whom the bicycle rightfully belongs and there has been no claim for such bicycle, the bicycle may be donated to any non-profit organization or non-profit group making a request for such to the chief of police, upon the consent of the city commission or shall be disposed as provided by O.C.G.A. § 17-5-54 (e) or other applicable law of this state. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Section 22-24. - Records on bicycles. Records shall be kept on such bicycles as to when and how acquired, and when and to whom disposition was made, and proper receipts shall be obtained by the police department. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-25. - Firearms. Any firearm coming into the possession of the police department from any source which has been abandoned by its owner, where the owner is unknown or where the owner has not responded within 90 days to notice given by the police department for the owner to claim and take possession of said firearm, wherein the firearm has no evidentiary value, shall be considered an abandoned firearm and disposed as provided hereinafter. Notice to any owner to claim and take possession of said firearm shall be given as provided in section 22-20 of this article. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Sec. 22-26. - Disposition of firearms. Any abandoned firearm in the custody of the police department shall be disposed as provided by O.C.G.A. § 17-5-54(g) or other applicable law of this state. (Ord. No. 16-08 , § 1, 6-7-2016) Secs. 22-27—22-39. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 22-40. - Composition. The city shall maintain a police department consisting of a chief of police and such subordinate officers as may, in the judgment of the chief of police and the city manager, be necessary to the proper discipline and handling of such police department, together with such number of police officers as may, in the judgment of the city commission, be necessary for the proper discharge of the duties of such department. All members of the police department shall be officers of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 16, § 1; Code 1977, § 27-16) Sec. 22-41. - Oath of police officers. All police officers shall take and subscribe an oath before the city clerk to fairly and impartially discharge their duties. If the city clerk is absent for any reason whatsoever, the oath shall be administered by the city attorney. In addition, the oath taken and subscribed shall comply with the requirements of O.C.G.A. §§ 45-3-1 through 45-3-10. (Code 1952, ch. 16, § 2; Code 1977, § 27-17; Ord. No. 14-23, § 1, 10-21-2014) Secs. 22-42—22-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - POLICE AUXILIARY
Sec. 22-71. - Established. There is hereby established, as a part of the city police department, a unit known as the active police auxiliary. (Code 1977, § 27-31; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 1) Sec. 22-72. - General control. The active police auxiliary shall be under the direction of the chief of police and subject to his general control. (Code 1977, § 27-32; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 2) Sec. 22-73. - Qualifications; application. Members of the active police auxiliary must be at least 21 years of age, and submit an application for membership to the police department on such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police. (Code 1977, § 27-33; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 3; Ord. No. 90-02, § 2, 1-16-1990) Sec. 22-74. - Compensation. Members of the active police auxiliary shall serve without pay from the city. (Code 1977, § 27-36; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 6) Sec. 22-75. - Uniforms. The city shall furnish uniforms which must be worn by active police auxiliary members at all times when on duty. (Code 1977, § 27-37; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 24 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— City courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-8-1 et seq.; bonds, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 24-1. - Where sessions held. The sessions of the municipal court shall be held in the courtroom of the police administration building located at 512 Oak Street, Waycross, Georgia, or in the discretion of the judge or judge pro tempore, in the county courthouse. (Code 1977, § 29-1; Ord. of 1-2-1973, § 1; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-1), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-2. - Judge pro tempore. The attorney appointed by the commission to serve as judge pro tempore shall have the same qualifications as the judge. Sec. 24-3. - Assessment and evaluation requirement. The judge of the municipal court may, as part of the sentence for any person convicted of an offense in said court, require such person to submit to assessment and evaluation for alcohol and/or substance abuse. The judge of the municipal court may withhold full sentencing pending receiving results of said assessment and evaluation. (Code 1977, § 29-41; Ord. No. 89-10, § 1, 6-20-1989; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-20), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-4. - Counseling and treatment. Either before the assessment and evaluation or after receiving the results of said assessment and evaluation, the judge of the municipal court, as part of the sentence, may require the convicted offender to submit to counseling, treatment (including admission into a drug or alcohol treatment center), as well as additional assessment and evaluation. (Code 1977, § 29-42; Ord. No. 89-10, § 2, 6-20-1989; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-21), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-5. - Payment of costs; selection of supervising agency. The judge of the municipal court may further order that the convicted offender pay the costs of such assessment and evaluation, as part of the sentence for the offense. The judge of the municipal court may also order the convicted offender to pay the costs of such counseling and treatment (including admission into a drug or alcohol treatment center), as well as additional assessment and evaluation; provided, however, that such costs shall not exceed the amounts permitted by law. The judge of the municipal court shall select the agency, department, bureau or facility to conduct such evaluations, assessments, counseling, and treatment, but shall select only those qualified by experience and training. (Code 1977, § 29-44; Ord. No. 89-10, § 4, 6-20-1989; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-22), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-6. - Additional assessment or cost for information technology. Any person against whom a fine is imposed by the municipal court for the violation of any of the laws or ordinances of the city or the laws of the state shall be subject to an additional assessment or cost in the amount of $10.00 per violation, said sum to be used for improvement or enhancement or upgrade of the information technology used by the city police department, and all said costs to be set aside in a separate fund earmarked for that purpose; provided, however, said additional assessment or cost shall not be imposed or added for any offense where prohibited by law. (Code 1952, ch. 1, § 4; Code 1977, § 1-6(b); Ord. of 9-4-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 94-23, § 1, 12-6-1994; Ord. No. 04-06, § 1, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 15-12, § 1(1-6(a)), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-7. - Trial. The cases before the municipal court shall be tried, without a jury, as speedily as possible. With due regard to the rights of the accused and of the city, continuances may be granted by the court upon proper showing made, in accordance with the rules governing such matters in the superior courts of the state, but such continuances shall be only until a time when the case can be properly tried in the discretion of the presiding judge or judge pro tempore. (Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-25), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-8. - Term of office. The city commission shall appoint the judge and judge pro tempore of the municipal court in January of each year for a term of one year. Any individual appointed as judge, or judge pro tempore, shall serve until a successor is appointed, unless he or she is removed as provided in section 24-9. (Ord. No. 16-13 , § 1, 7-5-2016) Sec. 24-9. - Removal of judge from office. Any individual appointed as judge, or judge pro tempore, may be removed during his or her term of office by two-thirds vote of the entire membership of the city commission as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2.2. (Ord. No. 16-13 , § 1, 7-5-2016) Secs. 24-10—24-32. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BAIL BONDS
Sec. 24-33. - Acceptance; approval of surety. The police department, or its designee, shall accept bail for any person who is charged with an offense against the laws or ordinances of the city or within the jurisdiction of the municipal court or who is arrested for such offense for his appearance before the municipal court; provided that the surety tendered and offered on such bond is approved by the chief of police or his designee. (Code 1952, ch. 18, § 5; Code 1977, § 29-16; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-34), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-34. - Scire facias on forfeited bonds. The city clerk shall issue a scire facias on all forfeited bonds against the principal and his sureties, which shall be served by a member of the police force of the city, if the parties are residents of the city. If the principal or sureties reside in the county outside of the city, such party shall be served by the county sheriff. The scire facias shall be served at least 20 days before the day of the sitting of the municipal court to which it is returnable. If the principal or his sureties reside out of the county or the state, a scire facias returnable to the municipal court may be served by publication as in cases of scire facias to revive judgment in the superior courts of the state. (Code 1952, ch. 18, § 7; Code 1977, § 29-18; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-36), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-35. - Judgment on scire facias. If, at the return time of such scire facias, no sufficient cause shall be shown to the contrary, judgment, on motion, shall be entered by the municipal court against such principal and sureties, or such of them as have been served. (Code 1952, ch. 18, § 8; Code 1977, § 29-19; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-37), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-36. - Execution. On the entering of the judgment specified in section 24-35, the city clerk shall issue an execution against the principal and the surety in conformity with such judgment, and in substantially the form and manner that executions are issued by the city for taxes. The execution shall be placed in the hands of the city manager or his designee who shall proceed to collect the same as tax executions are enforced and collected. (Code 1952, ch. 18, § 9; Code 1977, § 29-20; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-38), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-37. - Forfeiture of cash bond. In any case where any person charged with an offense brought in the municipal court, or arrested for such offenses, has deposited a sum of money as a bond for his appearance in said municipal court, and similarly where some other party has deposited a sum of money for the appearance of such person in said municipal court, then and in the event such person does not appear at the time appointed, for whose appearance such sum of money was deposited in lieu of a bond as aforesaid, said sum of money shall be forfeited instantly by the judgment of the municipal court entered upon the municipal court docket and shall be paid over to the city. (Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-39), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-38. - Effect on forfeitures. This article shall in no way affect the procedure now in force for the forfeiture of any sum of money which is deposited by any person for his appearance in the municipal court. Code 1952, ch. 18, § 10; Code 1977, § 29-21; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1(29-40), 7-7-2015) Sec. 24-39. - Additional methods for giving of, and forfeiture and collection of, appearance bonds. (a) When any person is charged with an offense against the laws or ordinances of the city or within the jurisdiction of the municipal court, or when any person is arrested for any such offense, such person shall: (1) Give bond for his appearance at any session of the municipal court in the same manner as bonds are given for appearance in the superior courts of the state; or (2) Give bond in any manner now provided by the city Charter, this Code, and the ordinances, resolutions and laws of the state applicable to the city.
