However, the applicant may neither supplement nor amend his application within said five-working-day period except at the invitation of the police chief or his designee. Any attempt to do so sua sponte shall be deemed a separate and new application. (c) The police chief or his designee may deny the application for permit upon any of the following reasons or combination of reasons: (1) The application does not contain all required information or materials, or the information set out in the application is so incomplete, vague, or ambiguous as to prevent full and proper review by the police chief or his designee; (2) The application contains material omissions, falsehoods, or misrepresentations; (3) The applicant, or entity represented by applicant, is incompetent to contract, sue, or be sued; (4) The person applying lacks authority to represent the entity for which the application is made; (5) The applicant or entity represented by applicant has on prior occasions damaged public property, or has not paid in full for such damages, or is in arrears as to any judgment civil, criminal, or administrative rendered against the applicant or entity, or is in violation of any injunction or restraining order entered against the applicant or entity, whether under the same name or another; (6) The applicant or entity represented by applicant has on prior occasions violated permitting ordinances in connection with events of a substantially similar nature; (7) The plan of the event as proposed is likely to present a danger to the health or safety of participants in the event or other members of the public (though not through the agency of any predicted reaction by onlookers or members of the public); (8) The plan of the event as proposed is likely to restrict and/or congest traffic (vehicular or pedestrian) on any of the public roads, rights-of-way, sidewalks, or waterways in the immediate vicinity of such event; (9) The plan of the event as proposed is likely to cause a disturbance of the peace, or is likely to burden lawful commerce in the area at the time of the proposed event, or is likely to intrude upon the privacy or property of citizens in the area of the proposed event; (10) The plan of the event as proposed includes activities which are prohibited by laws of the United States, the state, or ordinances of the city, or activities which constitute nuisance or tortious conduct with respect to public or private property or persons; (11) The plan of the event as proposed would conflict with previously planned programs or events organized and conducted by the city and previously scheduled for the same time and place; (12) The plan of the event as proposed is prohibited by or is inconsistent with the classifications and uses of the proposed or desired location; (13) A fully executed prior application for permit has been or will be granted to a prior applicant authorizing uses or activities which do not reasonably permit multiple occupancy of that particular space; or (14) The plan of the event as proposed includes the use of sign, display, post, or placard, banner which exceed two feet by three feet in size, are made of a material other than paper, cardboard, poster board, or foam, are attached or affixed to any wooden, plastic, metal, or other type of support, or are draped or affixed to any of the city property, including, but limited to, the ground, trees, and buildings within the city. (d) It is the specific intent of the city in enacting the ordinance from which this division is derived to regulate only the time, place and manner of events and not to regulate the content or message of any speech or expressive conduct. The factors enumerated in subsection (c) of this section, which we find express and support the substantial and compelling interests of this governing body in the preservation of the rights and liberties of its citizens and the safety, health, and good order of its society, are the only bases upon which the police chief or his designee shall decide to issue or deny a permit applied for hereunder and no such decision shall be made or justified based upon the anticipated or predicted content of the speech or expressive conduct of any applicant. (Code 1977, § 22-81; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-113. - Revocation. (a) For events that have been granted a permit or events that do not require a permit, the city police department shall have the authority to terminate an event at any time, or prevent its initiation, should traffic, weather, or other conditions develop which present an imminent danger to those participating in the event or to the public at large. If an event is permitted and is terminated pursuant to this subsection, the permit shall be revoked for that day only. (b) The city police department shall have the authority to terminate the event at any time or prevent its initiation should any consideration or combination of considerations enumerated herein as a ground for denial of a permit arise or first become apparent to the city police department after the grant of a permit. If an event is terminated pursuant to this subsection, the permit shall be permanently revoked. (c) If, in preparation for or after the start of an event for which a permit has been issued, participants in said event violate the terms of the permit or deviate in material fashion from the plan submitted in the application for the permit, the police department shall have the authority to terminate the event at any time or prevent its initiation. If an event is terminated pursuant to this subsection, the permit shall be permanently revoked. (d) If a state of emergency is declared, as defined and set forth in the emergency management provisions of chapter 14, article II, any and all events, permitted or otherwise, shall automatically be terminated and any permits therefor shall be permanently revoked. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the terms of the permit or to deviate from the plan submitted in the application for the permit. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons who have been permitted to conduct an event to remain on the permitted location or facility, after an event, permitted or otherwise, has been terminated pursuant to this section. (Code 1977, § 22-82; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-114. - Appeals. (a) Upon receipt of any decision by the police chief or his designee denying an application, upon revocation of a permit or other ruling pursuant to this division adverse to the applicant, or upon the receipt of a notice indicating that all or a portion of an applicant's security deposit has been retained, an applicant may, within five calendar days, file an appeal of said denial, revocation or adverse ruling, security deposit retention, or call of the letter of credit with the city manager, which appeal shall be in writing and sent to the city manager by certified U.S. mail or hand delivery. (b) The written appeal must state succinctly the grounds upon which it is asserted that the determination should be modified or reversed and shall be accompanied by copies of the application for permit, the written notice of determination to which appeal is being made, and any other papers relevant to the denial, retention of the security deposit, or call of the letter of credit. (c) Within seven calendar days of the receipt of a written appeal, the city manager shall set a hearing date. The city manager shall cause notice of the hearing to be served upon the applicant by certified U.S. mail. Such notice shall include the date, time, and location of the hearing. (d) At the hearing, all parties shall be provided a fair and impartial hearing and shall be allowed to produce any and all evidence concerning the appeal. (e) Within seven calendar days after the conclusion of the hearing, the city manager shall make a written decision on the appeal, which shall affirm, modify, or reverse the decision being appealed. The notice of the decision shall be sent to the applicant at the address set forth on the application for permit by certified U.S. mail and shall set forth the reasons for the decision. (f) The decision of the city manager shall be binding on all parties, subject to the right of appeal as provided by O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1 et seq. (Code 1977, § 22-83; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-115. - Time allotment. At or prior to the expiration of the time allotted and permitted for an event, the permitted person shall have completely vacated the permitted location or facility so as to allow any subsequent permittee to occupy and conduct an event at said location without interference or delay. (Code 1977, § 22-84; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-116. - Violations. Any person who violates this division may be subject to immediate arrest. The imposition of a penalty under the provisions of this section shall not prevent the revocation of any permit issued pursuant to this division. (Code 1977, § 22-87; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-117. - Exceptions. This division shall not apply to any of the following: (1) A governmental agency, including its employees or officials, acting within the scope of its functions or conducting official governmental business; (2) Uses, activities, or events being conducted on the public properties of the city, or the facilities thereon, that do not have the effect, intent, purpose, or propensity to attract the notice of people who are not a part of such use, activity, or event; (3) Events that are sponsored by the city within the scope of its functions; (4) Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, provided that such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; and (5) Funeral processions. (Code 1977, § 22-88; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Sec. 28-118. - Conflict of provisions. The requirements of this division shall be in addition to those requirements of section 38-7 to the extent that this division applies to parades within the corporate limits of the city. If there is a conflict between the terms of this division and said section 38-7, the terms of this division shall control. (Code 1977, § 22-89; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 5-18-2004) Secs. 28-119—28-150. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PRESENCE AND CONDUCT IN PUBLIC PARKS
Sec. 28-151. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Custodian means any person over the age of 18 years who is loco parentis to a juvenile. Emergency means a sudden unexpected event or occurrence which affects or may affect life, safety or health. (Notice: An emergency under this definition shall not be the same as an emergency under section 1-7(b).) Guardian means any person other than a parent, who has legal guardianship of a minor. Minor means any person under the age of 18 years. Municipal public parks means any park, playground or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort, for business, entertainment, or for other lawful purposes, and which has been either deeded to or dedicated to public use or ownership. Municipal public parks shall also include the sidewalks abutting any park, playground or place described in this definition. Parent means the natural or adoptive parent of a minor. (Code 1977, § 23-17; Ord. No. 90-29, § 4, 10-2-1990) Sec. 28-152. - Curfew. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter, remain, idle, wander, stroll, or play in any municipal public park, either on foot, or in a motor vehicle, or otherwise, in, about, or upon any municipal public park in the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., unless the person is on an emergency errand, or for special functions as set forth herein or where the presence of such person is connected with or required by some legitimate employment, trade, profession, or occupation. (Code 1977, § 23-18; Ord. No. 90-29, § 5, 10-2-1990) Sec. 28-153. - Special functions. Any person attending a special function for entertainment of any church, school, club, or other organization that requires such person to be in such municipal public park at a later hour than is called for in section 28-152, shall be exempt from the provisions of section 28-152, provided that the church, school, club, or other organization shall register in advance with the chief of police or his designate to have the park open and available at such later hour. The registrant shall state the time the function or entertainment shall end, and the persons who attend the function shall be required to leave the municipal public park no later than the time when the function is ended. (Code 1977, § 23-19; Ord. No. 90-29, § 6, 10-2-1990) Sec. 28-154. - Procedure for violations. (a) Any police officer, upon finding a person in violation of section 28-152, shall ascertain the name and address of such person, and warn the person that he is in violation of this division and shall direct the person to proceed at once to leave the municipal public park. The police officer shall report such action to the chief of the police department. (b) If such person refuses to leave the park in response to such warning or direction by any police officer, or refuses to give such police officer his correct name and address, or if the person has been warned on a previous occasion that he is in violation of this division, he shall be subject to arrest except that a minor shall be taken to the police department and the parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of such person shall be notified to come and take charge of the minor. If the parent, guardian, or other adult person referred to in this subsection cannot be located, or fails to come and take charge of the person, the person shall be released to the juvenile authorities. (Code 1977, § 23-20; Ord. No. 90-29, § 7, 10-2-1990) Sec. 28-155. - Signs stating park hours to be posted. Signs stating park hours shall be posted prominently in each park. (Code 1977, § 23-22; Ord. No. 90-29, § 9, 10-2-1990) Secs. 28-156—28-178. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - BLOCK PARTIES
Sec. 28-179. - Purpose. The purpose of this division is to promote and regulate use of city streets within the corporate limits of the city. It is the specific intent of this division to regulate only the time, place and manner of events and not the content or message of any speech or expressive conduct. (Code 1977, § 22-90; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-180. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Block parties means those gatherings of more than 20 people which has the effect, intent, purpose or propensity to attract the notice of people who are not otherwise part of the gathering and which necessitate closing portions of streets of the city. (Code 1977, § 22-91; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-181. - Use of public streets and application. No person shall, without first obtaining a permit issued by the police chief or his designee after application made not less than 15 days prior to the block party and made in accordance with section 28-111 and subject to all requirements and conditions fully set forth in section 28-111. Additionally, applicants shall also present a petition of not less than 85 percent of those residents whose residences face the portion of the road to be closed for the block party approving the block party. The petition shall contain the name, address, phone number and signature of those persons approving same. (Code 1977, § 22-92; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-182. - Review by police chief or his designee. All provisions of section 28-112 shall be applicable to block parties, except that the police chief or his designee shall have ten working days from the receipt of a fully completed, executed and filed application to review same, verify the names on the petition, and render a decision and communicate same to the applicant. (Code 1977, § 22-93; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-183. - Special requirements and fees for block parties. (a) Block parties may be held only between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. on Monday through Thursday and from 10:00 a.m. through 11:00 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays and from 2:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. on Sundays. Block parties shall not be permitted at any other times. (b) Fees as established by the city commission must be tendered with all applications, in addition to bonds and/or security deposits. (c) Street closure shall not occur prior to the beginning time for the event and must be reopened not later than 11:00 p.m. or the close of the event, with street cleanup being completed at the time of reopening. Both ends of the street being closed must be blocked. Streets can be designated as closed by using official block event tape and signs, barricades or cones. The city will initially deliver and set up tape, barricades or cones. The applicant will be responsible for maintenance and removal of the tape or barricades or cones and storage until the city retrieves on the next business day. (d) Bonds or security deposits shall be set and determined by the proposed size of the event and/or the likelihood of damage. (e) There shall be no amplification of sound which would disturb those residents not participating or as would cause traffic interference by vehicles driving past the closed street. All noise shall be kept to acceptable limits as set forth in division 5 of this article. (f) No main thoroughfare shall be closed for a block party. The police chief or his designee shall maintain a listing of streets which cannot be closed to through traffic for a block party. (Code 1977, § 22-94; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-184. - Incorporation of provisions. All provisions of sections 28-109 through 28-117 not in conflict with this division are made applicable herein by reference hereto. (Code 1977, § 22-95; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Sec. 28-185. - Conflict of provisions. The requirements of this article and this division shall be in addition to those requirements of section 38-7 to the extent that this article applies to parades within the corporate limits of the city. If there is a conflict between the terms of this article and said section 38-7 and division 2 of this article, the terms of this article shall control as to all block parties. (Code 1977, § 22-96; Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 12-6-2005) Secs. 28-186—28-208. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - NOISE
Sec. 28-209. - Unnecessary or unusual noises generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any unnecessary or unusual noise between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. which either annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; or to make, continue or cause to be made or continued between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., whether in the operation of any machine or the exercise of any trade or calling or otherwise, any noise which either annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others, unless the making and continuing of the same shall be absolutely necessary for the protection or preservation of property, or of the health, safety, life or limb of some person, in any of which events steps shall be taken to reduce the amount of such noise to an absolute minimum and for as short a duration of time as possible. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 1; Code 1977, § 21-1) Sec. 28-210. - Ringing bells, beating gongs, blowing whistles. It shall be unlawful for any person to ring any bell, beat or strike any object of any kind whatever, sound any gong or blow any whistle or horn, or make, or aid or continue, encourage or assist in making, any other or unusual distinct and loud audible noise upon any street or other public place in close proximity thereto; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to prevent: (1) The blowing of a steam whistle: a. For an alarm of fire; b. Upon locomotive engines when required by law and when absolutely necessary in the operation of trains; c. Upon stationary engines in factories or other industrial establishments at the time of beginning or quitting work in such establishments; (2) The use of musical instruments as part of a band duly authorized to perform within the limits of the city; and (3) The giving of absolutely necessary signals upon a motor vehicle, motorcycle, bicycle or other vehicle. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 2; Code 1977, § 21-2) Sec. 28-211. - Engine whistles not to be unnecessarily blown. It shall be unlawful for any person to blow the whistle of any engine unnecessarily loud or long within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 3; Code 1977, § 21-3) Sec. 28-212. - Noises in connection with advertising; sound amplifying mechanisms on automobiles, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise, or call attention to any advertisement, article, business, calling or profession upon any public street, sidewalk or entrance to a place of business within the corporate limits of the city, by means of any horn, megaphone, siren, whistle, bell, radio, mechanical piano, phonograph, graphophone, victrola or any other sound-producing or sound-amplifying mechanism, instrument or device of any kind whatsoever. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to operate in or upon any automobile, truck or other conveyance, upon any public street, any horn, megaphone, siren, whistle, bell, radio, mechanical piano, phonograph, graphophone, victrola or sound-producing or sound-amplifying mechanism, instrument or device; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed or held to apply to the use of a horn, bell or other usual signaling apparatus when the same is absolutely necessary or required for the protection of persons or property, or to any fire or police car or apparatus, or hospital ambulance responding to a call and reasonably used, or to radio sets installed in passenger automobiles and not stepped-up with sound or special amplifying devices; nor shall this section apply to duly authorized public parades and gatherings when such parades and gatherings are of general public interest as contrasted with private parades and gatherings conducted for commercial and publicity purposes. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 4; Code 1977, § 21-4) Sec. 28-213. - Noises likely to attract and congregate a crowd on streets and sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate in any store, stand, office building or other place within the city any horn, megaphone, siren, whistle, bell, radio, mechanical piano, phonograph, graphophone, victrola or other sound-producing or amplifying mechanism, instrument or device of any kind whatsoever when the sound thereof is sufficiently audible upon any public street or sidewalk to attract and congregate a crowd thereon; provided, however, that this section shall not be deemed or held to apply to the usual and customary demonstration or use in any store of any musical instrument or the giving of musical instruction in any store or other place of business; provided further, that such demonstration or use of such musical instrument be not stepped-up by the use of amplifiers, horns or other sound magnifying devices. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 5; Code 1977, § 21-5) Sec. 28-214. - Noises in residential section of city. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, permit the operation of, make, cause or continue the operation of, in any place of business or residence, in the residential section of the city, any bell, whistle, horn, radio, piano, mechanical piano, phonograph, graphophone, victrola or other similar instruments or devices, in any unusually loud and distinctly audible manner, which causes disturbance to a substantial portion of those living in the same neighborhood; provided that it is not the intention of this section to prohibit or interfere with the use of such instruments in the usual and customary manner and when sufficiently muted so as to not unduly disturb others in the same neighborhood, but applying to the use of such instruments when so handled or operated as to cause an unusually loud and offensive disturbance to others residing in the same neighborhood. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 6; Code 1977, § 21-6) Sec. 28-215. - Blowing horns, etc., on vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person operating an automobile or other vehicle in a line of traffic on any of the streets, or in any of the public places of the city, to continue sounding horns, gongs, whistles, sirens or to otherwise create any unusual noise, when traffic is for any reason held up. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 7; Code 1977, § 21-7) Sec. 28-216. - Use of vehicles with muffler cutout open, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any motor vehicle, automobile or similar vehicle, with a muffler cutout open, or without proper muffler protection for the prevention of unnecessary noises. (Code 1952, ch. 14, § 8; Code 1977, § 21-8)

div.head: Chapter 30 - PARKS AND RECREATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 30-1—30-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CITY AUDITORIUM
Sec. 30-19. - Management generally. The management, care and custody of the city auditorium is under the authority and responsibility of the city manager and the city manager may assign any of those duties to a subordinate. Any conditions arising from the renting or using of the auditorium requiring classification shall be brought to the attention of the city manager, and his decision shall be final unless an exception is granted by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 23-81; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-81), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-81), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-20. - Application for use. (a) All persons desiring to rent the auditorium must make application on a form furnished by the human resources department. The human resources department will check the application for completeness and approve it or deny it based on availability of dates requested. When approved, the application shall be presented to the cashier for payment of a deposit or full-rental charge. (b) Persons must be at least 25 years of age to rent the auditorium. (Code 1977, § 23-82; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-82), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-82), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-21. - Fees. For the use of the city auditorium and its facilities, persons shall pay to the city rental charges as established by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 23-83; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-83), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-83), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-22. - Waiver of fees. The city commission and the city manager may permit the use of the auditorium for patriotic purposes through veterans or other similar military service organizations without paying the rental charges set out in section 30-21. (Code 1977, § 23-84; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-84), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-84), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-23. - Deposit. Accompanying the initial application approved by the human resources department, a deposit as established by the city commission, with the amounts based on whether or not alcoholic beverages are being served or consumed, shall be required. The city manager has the authority to waive the deposit, or any portion thereof, if the applicant has previously rented the city auditorium without any damages and properly cleaned the city auditorium after the event. Within a two-week period after completion of the event, the city will return the deposit to the renter upon approval of the inspection of the building for damages and cleanliness. If the event is canceled less than 30 days prior to the scheduled event, the deposit will not be refunded. (Code 1977, § 23-85; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-85), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-85), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-24. - General rules. The following general rules are established and every user of the auditorium shall comply with the rules and regulations set forth herein and/or rules and regulations established by the city commission from time to time governing the use of the auditorium: (1) Consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises may be permitted by a lessee when approved in advance upon receipt of a written application request to the city manager, and subject to such terms and conditions as the said city manager may from time to time promulgate in writing, which may include terms as to insurance, cleanup fees, deposits, security personnel, limits on the number of guests and other matters the city manager may require. Such alcoholic beverages may be provided at no charge by the approved lessee to its guests, or they may be sold to such guests. In either case, regardless of whether such alcoholic beverages are provided at no charge or sold, such alcoholic beverages shall be dispensed only by a beverage caterer who must be approved by the city manager and must be the holder of a pouring license in good standing issued by the city, the county, and the state. No "brown-bagging," as defined by state law or section 6-13, shall be allowed under any circumstances. (2) The lessee of the auditorium shall be responsible for the proper conduct of its invitees in the building and on the premises and the lessee shall make necessary arrangements with the city police department for proper protection during the performance. (3) There shall be no smoking of tobacco products in the building or on the stage. (4) All paper and decorations used in decorating the building shall be fire or flame proof unless substitutes are approved by the city fire chief or his designee. (5) Nails, screws, tape or thumb tacks shall not be used; no decorative or other material shall be attached to any part of the building so as to damage the building. (6) The person using or renting the auditorium shall furnish all stage hands, ticket takers, ushers, decorations, and other help. The city's responsibility shall be to operate the sound systems, curtains, lighting system, and any other technical operations or requirements within the auditorium which shall always remain under the city's control and supervision in connection with producing the sponsored event. (7) Admissions may be sold for theater type performances. However, the sale of standing room will not be permitted and chairs will not be allowed in aisles, passageways or exit-ways. The occupancy requirement limitation as determined by the city fire chief must be strictly adhered to by the lessee. (8) All activities shall cease not later than 2:00 a.m., unless a later closing hour is authorized by the city manager; provided, however, all events where the serving or sale of alcohol is permitted must cease not later than 2:00 a.m., subject to all prohibitions in section 6-8. (9) The person renting or using the auditorium shall be liable and shall pay for all damages done to the building or equipment, normal wear and tear excepted. (10) The auditorium shall not be used to accommodate a gathering in excess of the seating capacity as prescribed by the city fire chief or his designee. (11) The auditorium shall not be subleased. (12) Any individual, person, or group using the auditorium shall forfeit the right of further use, if any of the rules and regulations set forth in this section are violated. (Code 1977, § 23-86; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-86), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 14-19, § 1, 10-7-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-86), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-25. - When license required. No performance shall be allowed in the auditorium, if a specific license is required for such performance until said specific license has been acquired and paid. (Code 1977, § 23-87; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-87), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-87), 1-20-2015) Sec. 30-26. - Forbidden uses. (a) The auditorium shall not be used to the detriment of the health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the city. (b) The lessee and any other person coming upon the premises of the city auditorium are prohibited from violating any state or federal law or any city ordinance. (Code 1977, § 23-88; Ord. of 3-7-1956, § 3; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1(23-88), 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1(23-88), 1-20-2015) Secs. 30-27—30-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARK AND PUBLIC FACILITY NAMING
Sec. 30-56. - Policy. The following policy shall control the naming of parks and any and all other public facilities in the city: (1) If a public park or any other public facility is named for a person, the city commission will consider renaming said facility only in extraordinary circumstances. (2) The city commission will not consider naming a park or public facility for a person who is living at the time of the petition. (3) Any person who desires to have a park or public facility named or renamed must file a petition providing not less than the following information: a. Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. b. The current name of the park or facility. c. The requested name of the public park or facility. d. The reason for the requested change. e. The applicant's relationship to the person for whom the park or facility is to be named. f. The reason the park or facility should be named for such person. g. Whether the applicant has contacted other persons in the area and obtained their approval for the naming or has circulated a written document (i.e., a petition and obtained neighborhood signatures). h. The number of properties abutting the park or public facility, and the names and addresses of the owners of these properties. (4) The petition must be signed by not less that 75 percent of the property owners and/or residents in property abutting the public park or public facility for which the naming or renaming request is made. The city shall have a reasonable period of time to verify the signatures and that 75 percent of the property owners and/or residents have in fact signed the petition. (5) The petition must be filed with the city clerk together with an application fee as established by the city commission, due and payable at the time the petition is filed. The application fee is nonrefundable, even if the request is denied. (6) Upon accepting any petition for naming or renaming a public park or public facility, the city shall set a date for a public hearing. The hearing shall be published in the local newspaper not less than two times prior to the hearing, with the first publication being not less than ten days before the hearing. (7) The effective date of the naming or change in naming of a park or public facility shall be not less than 90 days following final approval of the ordinance enacting the change. (Code 1977, § 23-89; Ord. No. 05-14, § 1, 6-21-2005) Sec. 30-57. - Pernell Roberts Memorial Park. The city commission does hereby dedicate and name the city park that is located and situated between the following streets: Isabella Street on the north, McDonald Street on the east, Mary Street on the south and Nicholls Street on the west, and previously known as Folks Park and Mary Street Park, as Pernell Roberts Memorial Park. (Ord. No. 15-25, § 1(23-90), 10-6-2015) Editor's note— The provisions of this section are not effective until May 18, 2016. Sec. 30-58. - Edwin Arthur Herrin Park. The city commission does hereby dedicate and name the trailhead located and situated between Alice Street, Carswell Avenue and Isabella Street as Edwin Arthur Herrin Park. (Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(23-91), 10-6-2015)

div.head: Chapter 32 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 32-1. - Use of bicycles, scooters, skateboards, roller blades, all terrain vehicles, mini-motorcycles and other similar devices restricted. (a) Except as otherwise specifically provided herein, the use of scooter, skateboards, roller blades, and similar devices shall be prohibited on any road, street, business or sidewalk within the areas of the city designated Downtown Waycross Business District: (1) Anywhere within the corporate limits of the city as more specifically set forth in subsection (d) of this section, unless the owner of property in that zone authorizes the use of scooters, skateboards, roller blades and similar devices and has posted a sign thereon indicating the authorization. Bicycles may be used on such property so long as the use of the bicycle is for transportation purposes only. Other use of bicycles, including, but not limited to, "ramp jumping" is strictly prohibited. (2) In any city park or city owned property or other public area which has not specifically been designated and posted as an area where the use of scooters, skateboards, roller blades and similar devices, as specified, is allowed. Bicycles may be used on such property so long as the use of the bicycle is for transportation purposes only. Other use of bicycles, including, but not limited to, "ramp jumping" is strictly prohibited. (b) Use of all terrain vehicles and mini-motorcycles (also known as "pocket rockets" or "pocket bikes") is prohibited in the corporate limits of the city or on any road, street, other public property or private property open to the public, including, but not limited to, parking lots and other similar locations where members of the public may be present or may be expected to be present. (c) This section shall not apply to the use of motorized devices used by the physically impaired for transportation purposes. (d) Downtown Waycross Business District includes all property contained within the boundaries as set forth in the following description: All that tract or parcel of land, situated, lying and being in the City of Waycross, Ware County, Georgia, more particularly described as follows: Beginning at a point where the centerline of Francis Street intersects with the centerline of Remshart Street; thence northerly along the centerline of Remshart Street to it intersection with the centerline of Carswell Avenue; thence westerly along the centerline of Carswell Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of Folks Street; thence northerly along the centerline of Folks Street to its intersection with the southerly boundary of Brunswick Avenue; thence southeasterly along the southerly boundary of Brunswick Avenue to its intersection with the easterly boundary of Pendleton Street; thence southerly along the easterly boundary of Pendleton Street 198.97 feet to a point; thence easterly 118.83 feet to a point; thence northerly 57.80 feet to a point 125.61 feet east of the easterly boundary of Pendleton Street; thence northeasterly 103.44 feet to a point on the southerly boundary of Brunswick Avenue located 157.49 feet from the easterly boundary of Pendleton Street; thence southeasterly along the southerly boundary of Brunswick Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of Alice Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Alice Street to its intersection with the centerline of Carswell Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of Carswell Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of Plant Avenue; thence southwesterly along the centerline of Plant Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of Francis Street; thence westerly along the centerline of Francis Street to its intersection with the centerline of Remshart Street at the point of beginning. (Code 1977, § 33-1; Ord. No. 06-09, § 1, 5-2-2006) Sec. 32-2. - Sweeping trash on streets and sidewalks. No merchant or other person shall sweep or blow any paper, trash, yard clippings or other matter on the streets, sidewalks or other public places in the city. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 11; Code 1977, § 33-3) Sec. 32-3. - Construction of downspouts, etc., which shed water on sidewalks. No person shall be permitted to erect any drain, gutter, downspout, valley or any flat or sloping roof of any character that will in any manner drain or shed water on any sidewalk of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 12; Code 1977, § 33-4) Sec. 32-4. - Interference, obstruction of public improvements prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or obstruct any public improvements authorized by the city commission, the mayor or other city officials by means of threats, coercion, duress or any other method whatsoever, either directly or indirectly. (Code 1977, § 33-5) Sec. 32-5. - Specifications for sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways. All sidewalks, curbs and gutters and driveways constructed in the city shall conform to the plans and specifications established therefor by the city. (Code 1977, § 33-6) Sec. 32-6. - Manner of work; cleanliness of premises. All work done or performed under the provisions of this chapter shall be done or performed in a good, workmanlike manner. Such work shall not be accepted or approved by the city until the premises thereof has been cleaned and cleared of all debris, trash and rubbish which may have accumulated during such work. (Code 1977, § 33-7) Secs. 32-7—32-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS
Sec. 32-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Motorist means the person operating any motor vehicle, automobile or truck within the city and shall include, without limitation, "motoring public." Responsible party means the property owner or owners and person in possession (which shall include, without limitation, a tenant or lessee) of real property adjoining any public street, road, alley or public thoroughfare, accepted and maintained by the city. Street means the streets, roads, alleys, and public thoroughfares in the city which shall include the entire width of the right-of-way of the streets, roads, alleys and public thoroughfares in the city. (Code 1977, § 33-22; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-7-1995) Sec. 32-32. - Protection of public. It shall be unlawful for any person, whether with permission granted in accordance with this article or not, to place, or allow to be placed, any obstruction of whatever kind or nature in such places without protecting the public safety by providing and maintaining at all times, at his own expense, ample barricades, warnings, signals, lights and guards at, upon or near such obstruction. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 6; Code 1977, § 33-21) Sec. 32-33. - Drainage. It shall be unlawful for any person in any way or manner whatever to obstruct any canal or ditch within the city which has been cut or opened by the city authorities for drainage purposes. (Code 1952, ch. 15, § 13; Code 1977, § 33-19) Sec. 32-34. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or allow to be placed, any obstruction of any kind on the sidewalks, streets, alleys or other public property in the city, whether such public property be opened or unopened or used or unused, unless written permission therefor has been first obtained from the city manager. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 5; Code 1977, § 33-20) Sec. 32-35. - Violations; corrections. (a) No responsible party, after notice from the building and code manager of the city or his designee to correct any violation shall permit any shrub, tree brush, bushes or other vegetation (hereinafter referred to as "vegetation") to grow on the real property owned by or in possession or such responsible party to the extent that such vegetation blocks the visibility of motorists traveling along any street, road, alley or public thoroughfares in the city, which adjoins the real property owned by or in possession of the responsible party. It is the responsibility of the responsible party on whose real property the vegetation is growing to remove or trim the vegetation so that it will not block the visibility of the motoring public traveling upon such street, road, alley or public thoroughfare of the city. (b) No responsible party, after notice from the building and code manager of the city or his designee to correct any violation, shall permit any signs, fences, vehicles, junk, lawn ornaments, and other tangible items of every nature and description (hereinafter referred to as "tangible items") to be placed upon, or remain upon the real property owned by or in possession of such responsible party to the extent that such tangible items block the visibility of motorists traveling along any street which adjoins the real property owned by or in possession of the responsible party. It is the responsibility of the responsible party on whose real property the tangible items are placed or are remaining to remove such tangible items so that they will not block the visibility of the motoring public traveling upon such street, road, alley or public thoroughfare. (c) If the building and code manager cannot find any responsible person within the city to correct any violation, the building and code manager shall give notice by publication once in one newspaper of general circulation in the city, requiring correction of any violation. The building and code manager may, but is not required to, make additional attempts to notify the responsible party. (d) It shall be the duty of the responsible party, within seven days after the notice from the building and code manager, to correct any violation. (e) If any responsible party contends that there is no violation, such responsible party may appeal the notice, in writing, within seven days of the notice from the building and code manager, to the building and code manager at city hall. Such appeal will be heard and considered by the board of zoning appeals, or such other body as may be designated by the city commission from time to time. The decision of the board of zoning appeals shall be final. (f) If the responsible party does not appeal any such notice, or correct such notice within the time set forth in the notice, or upon exhaustion of the appeals, the city may correct the violation and hold the responsible party responsible for the costs thereof. Any unpaid costs or charges which shall remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after the same become due and payable shall be and are hereby declared a lien upon the property upon which such vegetation or tangible items are located and removed. (g) If, in the opinion of the city manager of the city, an emergency situation exists which is an immediate threat to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens and motorists passing upon such streets, roads, alleys and public thoroughfares, then the city may, upon 24 hours' notice to the responsible party, remove such vegetation and/or tangible items, and hold the responsible party responsible for the costs thereof as set forth in this article. (Code 1977, § 33-23; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-7-1995) Secs. 32-36—32-58. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS
Sec. 32-59. - Jurisdiction and application. The jurisdiction of this article shall apply to all roads, streets, alleys and highways in the corporate limits of the city except private roads and those roads, streets or highways which are a part of the state highway system. (Code 1977, § 33-33; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(art. I), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-60. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City means the City of Waycross or any division, department, agency, authority or branch thereof, or the city commission or other city officer having charge of the streets of the city. City streets means the public roads within the city which are a part of the city streets and highways on the effective date of this article and any subsequent additions to the street system made by the City of Waycross. Dedication means the donation by the owner, either expressly or impliedly, and acceptance by the city commission. Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, association or private organization of any character. Private road means a privately owned road or way, which is only open for the benefit of one or more individuals and not dedicated to the use of the general public, or a road which lies on privately owned land. Public road means the highway, road, street, alley, avenue, detour or other way dedicated to the public and intended or used for its enjoyment and for the passage of vehicles in the city (except state highway system roads) including, but not limited to, sidewalks, bike paths, road surfaces, shoulders, bridges, drainage ditches, canals, culverts. Right-of-way means a general term denoting land, property or interest therein, usually but not required to be a strip, acquired for or devoted to a city street. (Code 1977, § 33-34; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(art. II), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-61. - Obstruction, excavation or alteration; permit required. From and after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, no person shall obstruct, excavate or alter the surface or location of any public road, or materially injure any part of any public road, without first obtaining a permit from the city. (Code 1977, § 33-35; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(301), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-62. - Application for permit. As a condition precedent to the granting of such permit, such applicant shall file an application in writing with the city engineer specifically describing the nature, extent, location and time of proposed obstruction, excavation or alteration and such other information as the city, through its designated official, may require. (Code 1977, § 33-36; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(302), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-63. - Inspection prior to issuance of permit. An inspection of the location of work in the area where the permit is requested shall be made by the city engineer or other city official prior to the issuance of a permit. (Code 1977, § 33-37; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(303), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-64. - Time. Except in case of emergency, a permit to excavate, obstruct, or alter a public road shall be made ten days prior to the issuance of a permit. (Code 1977, § 33-38; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(304), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-65. - Fee. In order to defray the administrative cost involved in the administration and enforcement of this article, the city manager may establish a reasonable fee not to exceed $25.00 for each mile or fraction thereof of encroachment as measured parallel to the roadway centerline, which fee when established, shall be payable to the order of city and paid prior to the issuance of the desired permit. (Code 1977, § 33-39; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(305), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-66. - Permit to be displayed. The permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be available for inspection by city officials and prominently displayed at the site of any excavation, obstruction or alteration of a public road. (Code 1977, § 33-40; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(306), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-67. - Indemnity bond. At any time that applicant proposes to penetrate the paved surface of any public road and a portion thereof is to be removed, the application for a permit shall be accompanied by an indemnity bond, certified check or bonded contract, in such amount as the city engineer may establish and which is available to the city to assure the applicant or applicant's contractor after the excavation or alteration is completed will restore the paved road surface to same condition as it previously existed, prior to such alteration or excavation. (Code 1977, § 33-41; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(401), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-68. - Bonds and other security. The indemnity bond or other security posted by the applicant shall not be released, until such time as the city engineer certifies in writing that such restoration work has been fully completed by applicant in accordance with the standards established by the city engineer pursuant to the provisions of this article. (Code 1977, § 33-42; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(402), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-69. - Insurance. The city, as a condition to issuing a permit under the provisions of this article, may require proof that applicant or applicant's contractor carries liability insurance to pay any damages to any member of the public caused by the work performed under the authority of said permit. (Code 1977, § 33-43; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(403), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-70. - Standards. (a) The most recent as adopted by the state department of transportation (DOT), and the DOT's "Regulations for driveway and encroachment control," including current revisions, as applicable and modified by the city engineer shall govern all work or installations in, on, along, over or under public streets of the city. (b) The interpretation of the requirements of these regulations shall be made by the city engineer which shall be final. (c) Copies of the regulations including all amendments and modifications shall be on file in the city engineer's office. (Code 1977, § 33-44; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(501), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-71. - Installation of traffic control and safety devices on site. Traffic controls and safety devices shall be installed at applicant's expense and used at excavation, alteration or obstruction sites as specified in the Georgia Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways as now in force or hereafter amended. (Code 1977, § 33-45; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(601), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-72. - Violation a misdemeanor; penalties. (a) Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9. (b) Any person violating any provision of this article may be ordered by the city commission to remove any equipment, facilities, and appliances from and discontinue its use of the public roads. (Code 1977, § 33-46; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(701), (702), 5-8-1984) Sec. 32-73. - Enforcement. The city engineer is hereby authorized to request the city attorney, in the event of violation of this article, to petition for an injunction to enforce the performance of any duty or act imposed by this article or for an order to restrain the breach of any duty or the commission of any act, imposed or prohibited or unauthorized by the provisions of this article. (Code 1977, § 33-47; Ord. No. 84-16, § 2(703), 5-8-1984) Secs. 32-74—32-104. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CONCRETE STRUCTURES
Sec. 32-105. - Permit required; plans and specifications to be submitted. All persons shall, before placing any concrete structure on the streets and roadways of the city, make application to the city manager for a permit therefor and submit plans and specifications and show the location of the proposed construction. The plans and specifications and the grades and alignment, with respect to the roadway, must be approved by the city engineer prior to the commencement of any work. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 1; Code 1977, § 33-48) Sec. 32-106. - Quality of concrete and work. The quality of the concrete and work done under the provisions of this article shall be such that the construction will be durable and safe for use by the public. Such work, if done in strict accordance with the state highway department standard specifications will be acceptable as being in compliance with this article. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 2; Code 1977, § 33-49) Sec. 32-107. - Thickness and width of paving. In all concrete structures for which a permit is required by this article the thickness and the width of the concrete paving shall be not less than the measurements specified in this section for the following types of work: (1) Sidewalks with no vehicular traffic shall be four inches thick and four feet wide. (2) Driveways and parkways shall be six inches thick and of sufficient width for use by vehicles. (3) Curbs and gutters shall be in conformity with curbs and gutters already in place and adjacent to the proposed construction, or in conformity with the standards of state highway department. (4) Valley gutters shall be six inches thick and of standard width. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 3; Code 1977, § 33-50) Sec. 32-108. - Requirements as to expansion joints. All expansion joints in concrete structures for which a permit is required by this article shall be premoulded. Joint filler shall be not less than one-half inch thick and shall extend the full depth of the paring. Expansion joints shall be provided every 40 feet in sidewalks, and expansion joints shall also be provided where the sidewalk joins the curb, where the sidewalk joins a building, on each side of a driveway which crosses a paved sidewalk and on either side of a driveway which abuts a building. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 4; Code 1977, § 33-51) Secs. 32-109—32-129. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PARKS, GRASS, PLATS, SQUARES
Sec. 32-130. - Duty of public works department. All parks, squares and grass plats shall be cared for, supervised and regulated by the public works department, subject to the provisions of this Code and any other ordinance of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 14; Code 1977, § 33-63) Sec. 32-131. - Trees, plants, etc.—Permit to plant. No tree, plant, flower or shrub of any kind shall be planted by any person in any street, park, square, grass plat or cemetery without a written permit from the director of the public works department. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 15; Code 1977, § 33-64) Sec. 32-132. - Same—Injuring, trimming, etc. No tree, shrub, flower, or plant of any kind in any street, park, square, grass plat, or cemetery, shall be removed, cut, mutilated or injured in any way. All necessary cutting, trimming and removing will be done by the public works department, except that such department may, in its discretion, issue a permit for others to trim or cut such. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 16; Code 1977, § 33-65) Sec. 32-133. - Permit to place fences, etc. No fences, railings, tree boxes, seats or obstructions of any kind, shall be placed in, or upon, or around any park, square or grass plat without a written permit from the director of the public works department. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 17; Code 1977, § 33-66) Sec. 32-134. - Firing pistols, building bonfires, etc. The firing of pistols or guns, the building of bonfires and the use of firecrackers or any explosive or combustible fireworks, or any similar thing, is prohibited in or upon any park, square, grass plat, or cemetery. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 20; Code 1977, § 33-69) Sec. 32-135. - Injuring, removing, etc., benches, monuments, etc. No person shall mutilate, injure, cut, mark, deface, remove or destroy any bench, fountain, fence, house, monument or structure, or property of any kind, in any park, square, grass plat or cemetery. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 23; Code 1977, § 33-71) Sec. 32-136. - Placing of wires, advertisements, signs, etc. No wires, advertisements, notices, signs, boards, or similar things shall be fastened to any tree, nor placed in any park, square, grass plat, or cemetery unless by written permission of the director of the public works department. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 24; Code 1977, § 33-72) Sec. 32-137. - May be closed; use when closed. The director of the public works department may, at his discretion, temporarily close to the public any portion of any park, square, grass plat, or cemetery during the time of any alterations or improvements, or whenever it may be deemed best for the public good, and all persons are prohibited from entering any such place when so closed. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 26; Code 1977, § 33-74) Sec. 32-138. - Digging into, etc., so as to injure trees, flowers, etc. No person shall dig into, tear up or disturb the soil or place any material, building, table, structure, pipe, sewer, or any other thing in or upon any park, square, grass plat, or cemetery, nor commit any act which might injure or destroy the trees, grass, flowers, or shrubbery growing in such place without a written permit from the director of the public works department. (Code 1952, ch. 21, § 22; Code 1977, § 33-75) Sec. 32-139. - Street renaming policy. The following policy shall control the renaming of the streets and roads in the city: (1) If a street is already named for a person, the city commission will consider renaming the street only in extraordinary circumstances. (2) The city commission will not consider naming a street for a person who is living at the time of the application. (3) Any person who desire to have a street renamed must file a petition providing not less than the following information: a. Name, address and telephone number of the applicant; b. The current name of the street; c. The requested name of the street; d. The reasons for the request change; e. If applicant requests that the street be named for person, state the applicant's relationship, if any to the person for whom the application wishes to have the street named; f. The reasons that the street should be named for such person; g. Whether the applicant has contacted other persons on the street, circulated a petition, etc.; and h. Give number of properties abutting the street and names and addresses of the owners of all property abutting the street. (4) The petition must be signed by not less than 75 percent of the property owners and/or residents abutting the public street for which the name change is requested. The city shall have a reasonable period of time to verify that the petition contains signatures of 75 percent of property owners and/or residents of the public street. (5) The application must be filed with the city clerk together with an application fee as established by the city commission, due and payable at the time the application is filed. The application fee is nonrefundable, even if the request is denied. (6) Upon accepting any application to change the name of a street, the city shall set a date for a public hearing. The hearing shall be published in the local newspaper not less than two times prior to the hearing, with the first such publication being not less than ten days before the hearing. (7) The effective date of the change of a street name shall be not less than 90 days following final approval of the ordinance that enacts the change. (Code 1977, § 33-76; Ord. No. 04-01, § 1, 1-20-2004) Sec. 32-140. - Renaming of city streets. (a) By resolution dated July 6, 1972, the city commission changed the name of Fair Lane and Butler Street to Martin Luther King Street. (b) By ordinance dated June 7, 1994, the city commission changed "H" Street to Vernon Willis Drive. (c) By ordinance dated November 19, 1996, the city commission changed the name of Johnson Street to Arnold McKinney Drive. (d) By ordinance dated May 15, 2001, the city commission changed the name of Climax Street to Tommie M. Kennedy Circle. (e) By ordinance dated December 17, 2002, the city commission changed the name of Rosebud Street to Albert Hill Sr. Drive. (f) By ordinance dated December 2, 2003, the city commission changed the name of Amanda Street to Chisem Street. (g) By ordinance dated March 6, 2012, the city commission changed the name of State Street to Ossie Davis Parkway. (h) By ordinance dated June 21, 2016, the city commission changed "I" Street to Evans Way. (i) By ordinance dated June 21, 2016, the city commission changed "J" Street to Pearlie Bowden Drive. (j) By ordinance dated July 19, 2016, the city commission changed Louisiana Avenue to R.L. McGee Drive. (k) By ordinance dated August 1, 2017, the city commission formally changed Martin Luther King Street to Martin Luther King Drive. (Ord. No. 16-09 , § 1, 6-7-2016; Ord. No. 16-10 , § 1, 6-7-2016; Ord. No. 16-11 , § 1, 6-7-2016; Ord. No. 16-16 , § 1, 7-19-2016; Ord. No. O17-17 , § 1, 8-15-2017)

div.head: Chapter 34 - TAXATION, LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. title 48; occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.; fair business practices, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-390 et seq.; financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-90 et seq.; adult bookstores and movie houses, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 34-1. - Ad valorem tax on tangible property other than motor vehicles. (a) For each tax year, the city shall levy and collect ad valorem taxes on tangible property other than motor vehicles in two installments. (b) The first installment on such taxes shall be one-half of the entire amount due for the year and shall become due and payable on September 1 of each calendar year. For the purposes of this subsection, one-half of the taxes levied on the property for the preceding tax year shall be due and payable at the time of the first installment and the remaining taxes shall be due and payable at the time of the final installment. (c) Taxpayers shall pay the second installment for such taxes in the amount of one-half of the entire amount due for the year and the same shall be due and payable on December 20 of each calendar year. Those taxes due on the final installment which are not due later than December 20 of each calendar year shall be the total taxes due on the property for the current year after credit has been given for tax payments made in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. (d) This section shall continue in full force and effect in all subsequent tax years unless repealed by the city commission. (e) Any ad valorem taxes due the city under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month from the date the tax is due until the date the tax is paid. For the purposes of this subsection, any period of less than one month shall be considered to be one month. (f) The city shall levy and collect taxes from all persons required by law to make annual tax returns of all their property to the state revenue commissioner in accordance with the provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section, even though no assessments have been placed on the subject tangible property for the tax year for which the installments are being collected. Taxes not paid when due under any installment authorized pursuant to this section shall bear interest at the rate provided by law for unpaid ad valorem taxes for the due date of any such installment. (g) Any taxes required to be paid hereunder not paid in full by December 20 of any year shall be subject to penalties and interest as provided by law. (Code 1977, § 34-2; Ord. No. 87-53, § 1, 12-21-1987) Secs. 34-2—34-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GROSS RECEIPTS TAX FOR INSURANCE COMPANIES
Sec. 34-21. - Imposed—On life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1984, and for each year thereafter, an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums" as used in this section means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The tax imposed shall not apply to annuity considerations. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 34-94. (Code 1977, § 34-31; Ord. of 6-1-1965, § 1; Ord. No. 83-38, § 4, 10-4-1983) Sec. 34-22. - Same—All other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the city in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums" as used in this section means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 8; Code 1977, § 34-32; Ord. No. 83-38, § 5, 10-4-1983) Sec. 34-23. - Application; payment. (a) Every insurance company doing business within the city and subject to the premium tax herein imposed shall file with the city clerk, on forms prescribed by him, a report showing the names and addresses of its agents representing such company in the city; the location and person in charge of each and every business location within the city operated and maintained by such company; the classes of insurance written; and such other reasonable information as may be required; and, in addition, shall furnish complete information regarding the premiums received, by class, during the preceding calendar year from policies written on risks residing or located within the city. Such report shall be made over affidavit of an officer of such company. It is hereby declared to be a violation of this article for any person to knowingly give false or incomplete information on any such report. Said report shall be filed at the time of paying the said premium tax. (b) All reports required to be filed under this article shall be confidential and the information contained therein shall be solely for the use of the officers of the city responsible for administering this article. (Code 1977, § 34-33; Ord. of 1-19-1965, § 3) Sec. 34-24. - When due; delinquent. The premium taxes levied by this article are due and payable on January 1 of each year. Any company not reporting and paying the premium tax on or before February 15 of such year shall be delinquent. (Code 1977, § 34-34; Ord. of 1-19-1965, § 2) Sec. 34-25. - Enforcement. (a) The taxes levied by this article may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city. (b) In the event the city clerk shall be unable to collect the money on such executions, he shall make a return of nulla bona thereon, and thereupon the license or permit of such insurance company or the agents thereof to do business in the city shall be automatically revoked. Thereafter, until such delinquent tax or taxes shall have been paid, it shall be a violation of this article for such company or its agents to do business or offer to do business or to hold themselves out to the public as engaged in such business in the city. (Code 1977, § 34-35; Ord. of 1-19-1965, § 4) Sec. 34-26. - Quarterly statement of business transacted. Each and every insurance or bonding company or society or association or other forms of insurance underwriting enterprise or the agents thereof, doing business in the city as provided in this article, shall through its local representative or agent or through its agent in charge of the home office where there is no local agent, file with the city clerk quarter-annually, on April 15, July 15, October 15, and January 15 of each year, a sworn statement showing in detail the amount of business transacted, as provided in this article during the preceding quarter. The statement shall be on forms furnished by the city and shall contain in detail all necessary information to enable the city to determine the correct amount of the percentage tax due the city. The city clerk, at his option, may require such statement to have attached thereto a statement from the home office of the company showing the names of the persons, firms or corporations on whom or for whom the business was written, the amount of premiums paid and the date when the contract expires or terminates. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 9; Code 1977, § 34-36) Sec. 34-27. - Assessment of company or agent failing to file quarterly statement. Should the statement referred to in section 34-26 not be filed as provided in that section, the city clerk shall, from the best information at hand, assess the defaulting company or agent such amount as may appear to be due and owing by such company or agent. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 10; Code 1977, § 34-37) Sec. 34-28. - When gross receipts tax to be paid; effect or failure to pay. (a) At the time of filing the statement referred to in section 34-26, the percentage tax on the gross receipts shall be paid into the treasury of the city and should such payment not be made within ten days from the filing of such statement, the city clerk shall issue execution against such company or agent for the amount due and turn the same over to the city manager or his designee for collection as other tax executions are collected. (b) Should the city manager or his designee be unable to collect the money on such executions, he shall make a return of nulla bona thereon and thereupon the license and permit of such insurance or bonding company or society or association, or other form of insurance underwriting enterprise or the agents thereof, to do business in the city shall be automatically revoked. Thereafter, until such delinquent tax shall have been paid, it shall be unlawful for such companies or agents to do business or to offer to do business or to hold themselves out to the public as engaged in such business in the city. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 11; Code 1977, § 34-38) Sec. 34-29. - Duty of person collecting premiums on account of life insurance companies. Each and every bank or loan company or other person or company in the city which collects premiums for the account of any life insurance company, association or society, shall pay on the gross premiums received for such companies, as provided in section 34-21, the sum of two percent per annum. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 12; Code 1977, § 34-39) Sec. 34-30. - Right of city to examine books, papers, etc. The city, by its duly authorized agent for the purpose of aiding "life group" referred to in section 34-21 and "fire group" referred to in section 34-22 in the preparation of the sworn statement required to be filed by section 34-26 or of ascertaining the correctness of any such sworn statement, or for the purpose of preparing and filing such statement where none has been filed, shall have free and complete access for the purpose of examination, at all reasonable times, to any books, papers, records, or memoranda bearing upon the matter required to be included in such sworn statement. If any person, corporation, partnership, society or association required under this article to pay the percentage tax pursuant to this article, or any agent or employee in charge of the books, papers, records or memoranda to which the city or its agents for the purpose of this article desire access, shall refuse to permit the city or its agents to make examination of such books, papers, records, or memoranda, such refusal shall be unlawful. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 13; Code 1977, § 34-40) Sec. 34-31. - Application of article—Generally. The provisions of this article shall apply to all persons, firms and corporations in the "life group" referred to in section 34-21 and in the "fire group" referred to in section 34-22, whether or not any such companies maintain in the city a local agent or agency as such terms are understood and used among insurance or bonding companies; provided, such companies receive or collect or report premiums on policies issued on persons, property, indemnity or business which are located within or domiciled within the corporate limits of the city, and whether such premiums are received, reported or collected by the insurance companies direct through the United States mail, express companies, banks, individuals, firms or other collecting agencies. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 14; Code 1977, § 34-41) Sec. 34-32. - Same—Banks, etc. The provisions of this article so far as they relate to the enforcement thereof, as well as to obtaining and furnishing information and filing returns and the penalties provided for violations, shall apply to each and every bank or other financial institution in the city, and to the officers thereof; which collect premiums for the account of any insurance company, association or bonding company, as specified in this article. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 15; Code 1977, § 34-42) Sec. 34-33. - Agents, officers, etc., to file required quarterly statement and to pay tax. It shall be unlawful for any agent or officer or local manager of any such insurance or bonding or indemnity company or bank or other financial institution to fail or refuse to file the statement referred to in section 34-26 or to fail or refuse to pay the percentage tax levied and required by this article. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 16; Code 1977, § 34-43) Sec. 34-34. - Compliance with article. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or to counsel, aid or abet any such violation of failure to comply. (Code 1952, ch. 22, § 17; Code 1977, § 34-44) Secs. 34-35—34-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX ON ROOMS, LODGING OR ACCOMMODATIONS
Sec. 34-57. - Levied; amount. Pursuant to the provisions of an act of the General Assembly authorizing each municipality in the state to impose, levy and collect an excise tax upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the municipality for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value, provided no such tax shall be levied upon the sale or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days, or for the use of meeting rooms, there is hereby levied an excise tax in the amount of five percent of the charges to the public for such furnishing of any room or rooms, lodgings or accommodations, furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city within said city, all as authorized in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). (Code 1977, § 34-51; Ord. No. 89-06, § 1, 5-2-1989) Sec. 34-58. - Failure to remit tax due; false and fraudulent returns; penalties. (a) When any person liable hereunder shall fail to make any return or pay the full amount of the tax required herein, there shall be imposed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days, or fraction thereof, during which the failure continues, not to exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater; provided, however, if such failure is due to providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the city clerk in affidavit form attached to the return and remittance within ten days of due date, such returns may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or the failure to file a return, where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due herein, a specific penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. (b) When any person fails to remit the tax, or any portion thereof, on or before the day when such tax shall be required by law to be paid, there shall be added to the amount due interest at the rate provided for executions from the date until paid. (c) All penalties and interest imposed herein shall be payable and collectible by the city treasurer in the manner as if they were a part of the tax imposed. (Code 1977, § 34-54; Ord. No. 89-06, § 4, 5-2-1989) Sec. 34-59. - Expenditure of tax revenues. (a) The city shall expend (in the fiscal year during which the tax is first collected at a rate in excess of three percent and at all times thereafter) an amount equal to the amount by which the total taxes collected under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51 exceed the taxes which would be collected at a rate of three percent for the purpose of promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows and for the purposes set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3).
