For each business location in addition to one, the licensee shall pay an additional license fee as established by the city commission for each calendar year or portion of a year in which the licensee conducts business at such additional location. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-7), 9-2-2014) Sec. 34-254. - Revocation of license. (a) The license issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the mayor and city council, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: (1) Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; (2) Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with any purchase transaction; (3) Failure to maintain the daily record as required in this article; (4) Any other violation of this article; or (5) Conducting the business licensed under this article in any unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. (b) Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be served on the licensee by handing the notice personally to the person in charge of the licensee's business, or by mailing the notice, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-8), 9-2-2014) Sec. 34-255. - Records and information to be recorded. Every person or business engaged as a pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, or dealer in precious metals and gems within the city shall secure from every person from whom he receives any goods, except used books, whether by purchase or through pledge, trade, pawn or exchange, the following: (1) Government-issued photo identification card, such as a driver's license, military identification card, state identification card or passport; (2) The name, address, telephone number, race, sex, height, weight, date of birth, and a Social Security or driver's license number; (3) A digital photograph clearly showing a frontal view of the subject's face. Each digital image shall be labeled with the date and time of the transaction and stored in such a manner that they are safe from corruption. If the same subject makes additional transactions within 30 days of the original transaction; provides the same government issued photo identification card as mentioned in subsection (1) of this section; and the subject's appearance has not materially changed, a new digital photograph shall not be required until a transaction is made after 30 days from the original transaction; (4) A complete and accurate description of the goods acquired, and a digital photograph or image of the goods acquired including the following information, if available: a. Brand name; b. Model number; c. Manufacturer's serial number; d. Size; e. Color, as apparent to the untrained eye; f. Precious metal type, weight, and content if known; g. Gemstone description, including the number of stones; h. In the case of firearms, the type of action, caliber or gauge, number of barrels, barrel length, and finish; i. Any other unique identifying marks, numbers, or letters; j. The date and time of the transaction. (5) The pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, and dealer in precious metals and gems shall maintain the above information and digital photographs or images for a period of three years and make the same available to law enforcement personnel upon request. (6) The pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, and dealer in precious metals and gems shall require the seller to sign a statement verifying that the seller is the rightful owner of the goods or is entitled to sell, consign, or trade the goods. (7) This section shall not apply to the receipt of used books or pawn transactions commonly known as "title pawn" transactions where the pawnbroker takes possession of a motor vehicle certificate of title, takes a security interest in the motor vehicle certificate of title, and retains physical possession of the vehicle certificate of title for the entire length of the pawn transaction. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-9), 9-2-2014) Sec. 34-256. - Report to police; required format. (a) Every pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, and dealer in precious metals and gems located within the city shall make a computer-generated daily report, in such format as prescribed by the chief of police, of all transactions that occurred during the 24-hour period ending at 9:00 p.m. on the date of the report. A report shall be made each day prior to 11:59 p.m. for each day the operator or dealer transacts business. If an operator or dealer is closed, or does not otherwise engage in any transactions on a particular day, a report indicating "no transactions" shall be filed for that day. Daily reports shall be filed electronically by posting to a law enforcement web site designated by the chief of police. When technological problems prevent posting the daily report electronically, a printed, typed or legibly handwritten report shall be delivered to the police department in lieu thereof. (b) This section shall not apply to the receipt of used books or pawn transactions commonly known as "title pawn" transactions where the pawnbroker takes possession of a motor vehicle certificate of title; takes a security interest in the motor vehicle certificate of title, and retains physical possession of the vehicle certificate of title for the entire length of the pawn transaction. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-11), 9-2-2014) Sec. 34-257. - Hold period; police holds. (a) Any pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, dealer in precious metals and gems, or person operating under a license granted pursuant to this article who takes goods on pawn or who buys goods, taking full title thereto, shall hold the goods so taken in pawn for at least 30 days before disposing of the goods by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. (b) The city police department, or any other law enforcement agency, has the authority to place property that is the subject of police or law enforcement investigation on "police hold." In that event, the city police department, or other law enforcement agency, shall notify the pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, or dealer in precious metals and gems of the need for a "police hold" and identify all property subject to the "police hold." Upon notification, it shall be the responsibility of the pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, or dealer in precious metals and gems to maintain the subject property until such time as the property is released from "police hold" status or the property is confiscated as evidence. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-13), 9-2-2014) Sec. 34-258. - Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, dealer in precious metals and gems or person operating under a license granted pursuant to this article to commit any of the following acts: (1) Fail to make an entry of any material matter in the daily record of said business; (2) Make any false entry in the daily record of said business; (3) Falsify, obliterate or destroy the daily record of said business or remove the daily record from the place of business; (4) Refuse to allow any police officer or duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect the daily record of said business or any goods in the possession of said business during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time; or (5) Fail to comply with this article in any other material way. (Ord. No. 14-17, § 1(31-14), 9-2-2014) Secs. 34-259—34-279. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - JUNK AND JUNK DEALERS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.
Sec. 34-280. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Junk dealer means any person engaged in the business of purchasing old rope, chain, iron, copper or copper wire, parts of machinery, old iron, brass, bottles, garden hose, cast and wrought iron, steel, stoves or parts thereof, hides, steam boilers or parts thereof, tools of all kinds, saw mill machinery or parts thereof, hand, mill or other saws, automobile parts or tires, old clothing, rags, sacks, leather, tin, lead or other metal, babbit or other compositions from metals, old wood, metal, or iron wheels, journals, springs of all kinds, rails, wire of all kinds, any and all other odds and ends of similar character usually dealt in and handled by dealers in secondhand wares. (Code 1952, ch. 12, § 1; Code 1977, § 17-1) Sec. 34-281. - Purchase before sunrise or after sunset prohibited. No junk dealer shall purchase any of the articles or things named in section 34-280, or things usually bought and sold by junk dealers, before sunrise or after sunset. (Code 1952, ch. 12, § 2; Code 1977, § 17-2) Sec. 34-282. - Daily reports to police. All junk dealers, or dealers in junk or secondhand things, or odds and ends, shall make daily reports in writing and itemized to the chief of police of all junk, articles or things purchased during the day, from whom each purchase was made and the address of the person from whom such purchase was made. (Code 1952, ch. 12, § 3; Code 1977, § 17-3) Sec. 34-283. - Retention of services. All articles, things, odds or ends of junk purchased by a junk dealer shall be kept in its original form and shape in a conspicuous place, separate from other property subject to inspection of the police or public, for not less than six days, during which time such purchases shall not be ground up, broken up, melted or changed from its original form or shape or make-up or altered in any manner. After six days such purchases may be mixed or mingled with any other property owned or stored by such dealer. (Code 1952, ch. 12, § 4; Code 1977, § 17-4) Secs. 34-284—34-315. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, PEDDLERS, AND SOLICITORS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
Sec. 34-316. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Booth or stand means any table, shelf, counter, cart, or other facility, whether mobile or fixed, which is placed on a street or other public place within the city for the purpose of selling or offering to sell any goods or service to the public, or for soliciting for any purpose. License means the right or privilege granted by the city to engage in business as a transient merchant or peddler within the corporate limits of the city. Evidence that such right or privilege has been granted shall be in the form of a license document issued by the city, which document shall be kept at the merchant's place of business within the city or on the peddler's person or within the peddler's vehicle. Local peddler means any person who is a resident of the city, who has no regular fixed place of business within the city, and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services by going from place to place within the city, except a person selling agricultural products and holding a letter from a county agent certifying that the products were produced by that person. Also excepted from this definition are those persons selling agricultural products at what is commonly referred to as the "farmers' market" normally held at Memorial Stadium. Permit means the authorization granted by the city to solicit for charitable or religious purposes, or to solicit subscriptions, there being no fee nor charge for such permit. Evidence that such authorization has been granted shall be in the form of a permit document issued by the city. Solicitor for charitable or religious purposes means any person who solicits contributions from the public, either on the streets of the city or from door to door, for any charitable or religious organization, and who does not sell or offer to sell any single item with a cost to the purchaser in excess of $10.00. No qualification as a "charitable" or "religious" organization shall exist unless the applicant: (1) Is able to demonstrate a current exemption certificate from the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended; or (2) Has maintained in Ware County a continuous existence as a charitable or religious organization for a period of three years prior to the date of its application pursuant to this article. Solicitor for subscriptions means any person who solicits subscriptions by going from place to place within the city, and who offers for sale subscriptions to magazines or other materials protected by the provisions of the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States of America. Transient merchant means any person, firm, or corporation, whether resident or nonresident of Waycross, who has no permanent, regular place of business within the city and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services from a temporary fixed place of business located within the city, such temporary places of business to include any room or space in a hotel or motel, boardinghouse, public or private building, or any other fixed place of business within the city; however, no merchant shall be considered a transient merchant under this article if: (1) Such merchant is a bona fide commercial traveler selling goods at wholesale by samples; (2) Such merchant has already paid a license to the city for the privilege of conducting permanent business; (3) Such merchant is a peddler otherwise licensed by the city to sell goods from place to place; or (4) Such merchant is a civic club, service club, or school who, from time to time, engages in the selling of merchandise to the public as a club or school project. Transient peddler means any person who is a nonresident of the city, who has no permanent, regular place of business within the city, and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services by going from place to place within the city, except a person selling agricultural products and holding a letter from a county agent certifying that the products were produced by that person. Also excepted from this definition are those persons selling agricultural products at what is commonly referred to as the "farmers' market" normally held at Memorial Stadium. (Code 1977, § 24-2; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-317. - License or permit required; application forms; picture identification. (a) License or permit required; application. (1) No person shall operate a business as a transient merchant or peddler within the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city; and no solicitor for charitable or religious purposes or solicitor for subscriptions shall solicit within the city unless a permit has been granted by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. Such license or permit shall be effective only for the period stated in the document unless suspended or revoked prior to expiration. (2) Application for a license or permit shall be made on forms provided by the city and shall provide such information as is required by this article, and such additional information as may be necessary to define completely the activities to be conducted within the city. (b) At the time of filing any application for a permit or license under this article the applicant shall present with the application to the city a current valid driver's license showing a picture identification reasonably acceptable to the city clerk containing the picture of the applicant thereon. (Code 1977, § 24-3; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 10-9-2001) Sec. 34-318. - Application for transient merchant's license, transient peddler's license. An application containing the following information shall be completed and filed with the city by each applicant for a license to do business within the city as a transient merchant or transient peddler: (1) Name of the applicant; (2) Permanent address and telephone number of the applicant; (3) Local address and telephone number of the applicant; (4) The applicant's date of birth and age, if an individual; (5) The applicant's federal employer identification number; (6) If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name and home address of each partner, principal, or corporate officer; (7) If the applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; (8) If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name, home address, date of birth, age of the principal representative in the city; (9) Name and home address of all employees to work in the city; (10) Name of the business represented by the applicant, if different from the applicant; (11) Permanent address of the business represented by the applicant; (12) Name of agent conducting sale, if any; (13) Local address and telephone number of sales agent, if any; (14) Type of merchandise or service to be offered for sale; (15) Place where business is to be conducted; (16) Date to be in business, and total number of days to be in business; (17) Hours during which business will be conducted; (18) Manner in which business is to be conducted; (19) Georgia sales tax number of authorization; (20) Georgia state business license number, if required; (21) State and license tag number of each vehicle to be used in the business; (22) List of all cities where business has been conducted by the applicant within the 12-month period immediately preceding the application. The license shall be signed under oath by the applicant; (23) List of any and all felony criminal convictions and convictions of any crime involving moral turpitude of the applicant within five years prior to the date of the application. (Code 1977, § 24-4; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-319. - Registered agent required; transient merchant. (a) Any transient merchant shall submit evidence with his license application showing that such transient merchant has filed with the city clerk the name and permanent address of the transient merchant's registered agent. Such agent shall be a local property owner and a resident of the county for the previous 12 months. It shall be the responsibility of this individual to act as agent of such transient merchant upon whom any process, notice, or demand required or permitted by law to be served upon the transient merchant may be served in the same manner provided by law for the service of a summons or complaint. Said registered agent shall agree in writing to act as such agent, and a copy of the agreement shall be filed with the license application. In addition, such registered agent must be of such character and integrity as to be bondable. (b) Any such registered agent shall act in the same capacity and have the same duties and responsibilities, and be subject to the same actions of the superior court, as would any agent registered as required by O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq., known as the "Transient Merchant Act of Georgia." (c) In addition, all registered agents shall also complete an application containing the following information and file such with the city before any license shall be issued to a transient merchant: (1) Name of registered agent; (2) Permanent address and phone number of registered agent; (3) Length of time that registered agent has been a resident of the county; (4) Location of property owned by this individual which would qualify one to act as a registered agent. Such application shall be signed under oath by the registered agent. (Code 1977, § 24-5; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-320. - Basis for disapproval or revocation of license. No license shall be approved and any license previously issued may be revoked if an investigation determines that: (1) Any false statement, material omission, or untrue or misleading information is contained in or left out of the application; (2) The applicant, or any principal participant in the business has been convicted within the past five years of a felony, or of any crime involving moral turpitude, whether in connection with operation of the business or not; or (3) Said business is operated, or is proposed to be operated, in violation of any law of the United States or the state, or in violation of any city ordinance. (Code 1977, § 24-6; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-321. - Building and code manager approval required. No transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall set up a booth, stand, to conduct business or operation within the city until the building and code manager has reviewed the application to assure compliance with zoning, building, and safety code requirements of the city before issuing the license. (Code 1977, § 24-7; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 01-18, § 2, 10-9-2001) Sec. 34-322. - Permit and fee for transient merchant. A transient merchant shall pay a base regulatory fee in an amount as established by the city commission, not to be prorated. Said base regulatory fee shall expire on the earlier of 12:00 midnight on the 14th consecutive day after the effective day of the transient merchant permit or at 12:00 midnight on December 31 of the year issued. After the 14th consecutive day from the effective date of the transient merchant permit for the calendar year, the transient merchant shall pay to the city an additional regulatory fee in an amount as established by the city commission per day, or any portion thereof, during which the transient merchant conducts business within the city during the calendar year in which the base regulatory fee was paid. The maximum number of additional days that a transient merchant can conduct business in a calendar year within the city is 25 days. In the event that a higher regulatory fee is required of a transient merchant pursuant to another ordinance, statute or regulation, such higher regulatory fee shall apply. (Code 1977, § 24-8; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 01-18, § 3, 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 15-17, § 1, 8-4-2015) Sec. 34-323. - Bond requirement for transient merchant. Before any license or permit shall be issued to a transient merchant pursuant to this article, the transient merchant shall file with the city clerk a bond binding the applicant to the city in the full sum of $1,000.00, executed by the applicant as principal and by a surety approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall fully comply with the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state governing the conduct of such business and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes and all judgments that may be recovered against the applicant and by any person for damages growing out of any misrepresentation, deception, or breach of warranty in the conduct of such business. It is further required that this bond be held, maintained, and in force for a period of not less than 12-month period immediately following the last day of the transient merchant's business in the city. (Code 1977, § 24-9; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 01-18, § 4, 10-9-2001) Sec. 34-324. - License fee for transient peddler. Before conducting any business regulated by this article, the applicant for a permit for a transient peddler shall pay the city a base regulatory fee in an amount as established by the city commission, not to be prorated. Said base regulatory fee shall expire on the earlier of 12:00 midnight on the 14th consecutive day after the effective day thereof or at 12:00 midnight on December 31 of the year issued. After the 14th consecutive day from the effective date of the transient peddler permit for the calendar year, the transient peddler shall pay to the city an additional regulatory fee in an amount as established by the city commission, per day, or any portion thereof, during which the transient peddler conducts business in the city during the calendar year in which the base regulatory fee was paid. The maximum number of additional days that a transient peddler can conduct business in a calendar year within the city is 25 days. In the event that a higher regulatory fee is required of a transient peddler pursuant to another ordinance, statute or regulation, such higher regulatory fee shall apply. (Code 1977, § 24-10; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 91-23, § 1, 11-5-1991; Ord. No. 01-18, § 5, 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 15-17, § 1, 8-4-2015) Sec. 34-325. - License fee for local peddler. Any local peddler shall be licensed in the same manner and in the same amount as is required of any other local merchant as provided by the various laws and ordinances of the city. (Code 1977, § 24-11; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-326. - Application for a permit; solicitor. Any application for a permit to solicit funds for a charitable or religious organization, and any applicant for a permit to solicit for subscriptions, shall make application to the city. Such applicant shall provide the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the business or organization represented, the dates during which activities will be conducted within the city, the identity of all persons to solicit within the city, and such other information that the city may find necessary to identify the solicitors and define the activities to be conducted. Any such applicant who has not resided in the county for the preceding six months shall register at the city police department and shall be subject to police investigation of any and all solicitors listed in the application. Any solicitor's permit may be denied or revoked under any circumstances as shown in section 34-320. (Code 1977, § 24-12; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-327. - Issuance of license or permit. After all provisions of this article have been met by an applicant for a transient merchant's license or peddler's license, or a solicitor's permit, the city shall be authorized to issue a license or permit. Under no circumstances will the city issue a transient merchant or transient peddler a permit or license in excess of 25 additional days after the expiration of the 14th consecutive day in a calendar year. (Code 1977, § 24-13; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 15-17, § 1, 8-4-2015) Sec. 34-328. - Transient merchant, peddler and solicitor regulations. The following regulations shall apply to any transient merchant, local peddler, or transient peddler doing business within the city, and to any solicitor for a charitable or religious organization or for subscriptions who is required to obtain a license or permit: (1) No peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall be permitted to set up and operate a booth or stand on any public street or sidewalk, or in any other public area within the city, except with the written permission of the city manager. (2) No peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall stand or sit in or near the entrance to any house or place of business, and no peddler or solicitor shall stand or sit in any place which may disrupt or impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic. (3) No peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall offer to sell goods or services or solicit in vehicular traffic lanes of the city, and no such peddler or solicitor shall operate a "road block" directed towards vehicular traffic. (4) If any officer of the city police department or the finance department should determine that pedestrian or vehicular traffic congestion is such that public hazard or inconvenience would result from peddling, soliciting or selling in a congested area, such officer shall have authority to require any peddler or solicitor to move from the area. (5) No peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall enter a private residence, place of business, public building, or other premises within the city under false pretenses for the purpose of peddling goods or services, soliciting orders for the sale of goods or services, soliciting subscriptions, or soliciting contributions; no peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall remain in or on such premises after the owner, occupant, or other person in charge has requested the peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant to leave; and no peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall go in or on such premises when the owner, occupant, or other person in charge has displayed a "No Soliciting" sign or other similar sign on the premises. (6) Any stand or booth operated by or used by a transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor which is located on private property shall be located thereon with the expressed written permission of the property owner, and shall satisfy all zoning regulations of the city, health safety and building code requirements and regulations of the city, and of applicable state law. Upon request by the building and code manager, the designee of the building and code manager, or any law enforcement officer, the transient merchant, and transient, local peddler or solicitor shall present said written permission. In addition to all other requirements of this article, and of applicable law the transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall notify the police department of the city of the location of the stand or booth wherein such business is to be conducted. (7) No peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall harass or intimidate the public in any manner. (8) Each transient merchant, peddler, solicitor for subscriptions, and each solicitor for a charitable or religious organization shall be required to display a valid license or permit issued by the city, or a copy thereof, in a manner which can be clearly observed by any person being solicited for a sale, subscriptions, or contribution; however, each member or representative of a charitable or religious organization which has been issued a permit to solicit contributions within the city may, in lieu of displaying a copy of the permit, display an identification badge or insignia of the organization if such insignia has been established a statutory service or trademark, in a manner which can be clearly observed by any person being solicited. (9) When any officer of the police department or any other authorized city officer, deems that a peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant is in violation of any provision of this article, such officer shall have authority to direct the peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant to correct the violation immediately, and such peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall comply with the directive or be subject to the penalties prescribed by this article. (10) No transient merchant, transient peddler, or local peddler or solicitor shall operate or conduct business within the city at any time in violation of state law, rules or regulations, or at any time in violation of any other ordinance or regulation or special order of the city commission, or on any day prior to 8:00 a.m., or later than 8:00 p.m., or at any time on Sunday, except by specific appointment with or by invitation of the prospective customer. (11) No transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall conduct business or set up a sales booth or stand with the city except with the expressed written permission of the owner of the property where business is being conducted. (Code 1977, § 24-14; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 01-18, §§ 6, 7, 10-9-2001) Sec. 34-329. - Compliance required; penalty for violation. Any person doing business within the city as a transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler, solicitor, or in any other manner covered by this article who violates any provision of this article, or any merchant, peddler, or solicitor who makes any false statement in any application for a business license or permit shall be subject to revocation of any license or permit according to the procedures established by ordinance and shall, upon conviction be fined in an amount not to exceed $200.00, or imprisoned not exceeding 90 days, either or both, in the discretion of the court. Any such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or a portion thereof during which such violation of any of the provisions of this article is committed or continued. (Code 1977, § 24-15; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Sec. 34-330. - Exceptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: (1) Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the ordinary course of business; (2) Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers selling goods, wares, and merchandise according to law; (3) Bona fide residents of the state selling fruits, vegetables, dressed meats, fowl or farm products which were produced on land within the state, owned or controlled by such vendor. (Code 1977, § 24-16; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 6-7-1988) Secs. 34-331—34-348. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - YARD SALES
Sec. 34-349. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Neighborhood yard sale means a yard sale which is conducted by two or more persons living in the same general vicinity of each other where such persons have joined together to offer household goods for sale at the property of one of the participants in the yard sale. Yard sale means the sale or trading of clothing, furniture, household items, food, dishes, antiques or similar goods or merchandise, other than in the normal course of business, or the sale or trading of such goods, as outlined in this definition, by a person not regularly engaged in such business. Such goods or merchandise do not need to be attended for a sale to be deemed to be in existence. The term "yard sale" shall include garage sales, carport sales and similar types of sales or events. (Code 1977, § 37-1; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-350. - Location and manner of yard sale. (a) Every yard sale shall be held at a location and in a manner so as not to block the free flow of vehicular traffic and so as not to create or cause a dangerous or hazardous condition for vehicular traffic or for pedestrians. (b) The person who conduct a yard sale shall be responsible for compliance with subsection (a) of this section. (Code 1977, § 37-2; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-351. - Permit required. (a) Any person desiring to hold a yard sale shall obtain a complimentary permit from the director of planning and development. The application for the permit shall set forth the name and address of the person who will be conducting the yard sale, the address where the same is to be located, and the date upon which the yard sale will be conducted. The director of planning and development shall furnish such person with a copy of this article at the time of obtaining the yard sale permit. (b) In the case of a neighborhood yard sale, one of the persons who will participate in the neighborhood yard sale shall make application for the complimentary permit and shall set forth the name and address of the applicant; the address where the sale is to be held; the date or dates on which the neighborhood yard sale is to be held; and the names and addresses of all other persons who plan to participate in the sale. (c) The permit shall be obtained at least two business days prior to the commencement date of the yard sale. The applicant shall specify an alternate date (rain date) for such yard sale in the event the proposed sale cannot be held on the first selected date because of inclement weather. (Code 1977, § 37-3; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-352. - Number and duration. Yard sales shall be allowed not more than four times in any calendar year for any premises. No sale may run more than three consecutive days. (Code 1977, § 37-4; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-353. - Display area. All displays of yard sale merchandise shall be limited to that portion of the front yard area which is at least five feet back from the property line on all sides, and at least ten feet back from any curb or road edge. (Code 1977, § 37-5; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-354. - Religious and charitable organizations. Religious or charitable organizations exempt from federal taxation pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code may conduct an unlimited number of yard sales on the property of the organization or at other locations in areas zoned for commercial uses within the city with the express written consent of the owner of the premises where the yard sale is being conducted. (Code 1977, § 37-6; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-355. - Duties of community improvement director. The community improvement director shall maintain application forms and complimentary permits to be issued for yard sales. The community improvement director shall furnish to the police department a copy of all yard sale permits as and when the permits are issued. The community improvement director shall maintain a record of all permits issued which record of permits issued for yard sale shall be maintained for the space of at least 18 months and the community improvement director shall, before issuing any yard sale permit, check the listing record of previous permits issued to be certain that a requested permit is not being requested more frequently than permitted under the terms of this article and if such requested permit is for a date or time by the same applicant or at an address where a previous yard sale has been held less than 90 days prior to the date of the proposed sale, the community improvement director shall have the authority to refuse to issue the permit. (Code 1977, § 37-7; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-356. - Display of permit. The permit issued to any applicant for a yard sale shall be publicly displayed by the applicant during the time that the yard sale is being held or shall be available for inspection by a police officer upon demand. (Code 1977, § 37-8; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-357. - Temporary signs. Any person holding a yard sale may erect not more than three temporary directional signs during the time that the yard sale is being held, which directional signs may not be affixed to any public utility pole or street sign but each such sign shall be erected on its own stake or small post. Such directional sign may not be larger than one foot by two feet. Such temporary sign shall be removed promptly prior to the expiration of the permit for the yard sale. (Code 1977, § 37-9; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-358. - Termination of sales without permit. The mayor and city commissioners hereby grants authority to the chief of police and police officers to order the immediate termination of any yard sale being conducted without a valid permit being issued pursuant to the terms of this article. Any person who refuses to obey the order of the chief of police or other lawful officer of the city and immediately cease and terminate said yard sale and remove the public display of goods from their yard shall be subject to arrest for the charge of failing to obey a lawful order of a police officer and be subject to all the penalties for the violation of this article. The charge provided for in this section is in addition to any other charges that may be brought against such individual conducting a yard sale in violation of the terms of this article. (Code 1977, § 37-10; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Sec. 34-359. - Prohibited acts. (a) No individual, firm, corporation or other partnership shall be permitted to engage in the business of promoting or conducting yard sales for others for a fee or other consideration. No merchandise shall be purchased in anticipation of resale at a yard sale. (b) No yard sale shall be held on premises other than the premises of a least one of the persons conducting the yard sale except with the express written consent of the owner of the premises where the yard sale is being conducted. (Code 1977, § 37-11; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-16-2008) Secs. 34-360—34-376. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - TAXICABS[5] Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Local regulation of taxi services, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-191.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 34-377. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Driver means the person who actually drives a taxicab either for himself or an operator. Highway means any street, boulevard, avenue, drive, alley or public way of the city. License means the written authority granted by the city commission to engage in the taxicab business in the city. Operator means every person, firm, corporation or entity owning, controlling, operating or managing any one or more taxicabs, used in the transporting of persons for hire on public highways of the city. Permit means the written authority granted by the chief of police or his designee to drive a taxicab in the city. Taxicab means a motor vehicle for hire which operates within the corporate limits of the city including without limitation vans or limousines, which seats 14 or fewer passengers which operates on call or demand and transports passengers and their luggage, if any, between two or more points designated by the passenger and not operating on regular schedules and regular routes. Taxicab company owner means an individual, partnership, or corporation who owns the trade name under which the taxicab will operate and has purchased the necessary business license from the city which shows proof of proper insurance for the taxicab or the fleet of taxicabs encompassing the entire duration of the license period. Taxicab driver means any properly registered and permitted person in charge of or who drives a taxicab whether as an owner, agent, employee or otherwise. Taxicab stand means an approved covered bench or approved parking area located on or adjacent to city sidewalks at locations approved by the chief of police or his designee (in accordance with section 34-380) at which point taxicabs may park to await customers for not longer than one hour. These stands shall not have cabs parked for any time between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. any day of the week. Waiting time means the time during which a taxicab interrupts its journey at the request of a passenger so as to allow the passenger to conduct necessary business by either remaining with the taxicab or disembarking from the taxicab. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 1; Code 1977, § 35-1; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 07-20, § 1, 12-4-2007) Sec. 34-378. - Posting of rates. Every taxicab shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such a place as to be in view at all times of all passengers. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 8; Code 1977, § 35-3) Sec. 34-379. - Condition and appearance of taxicabs; inspections. Each taxicab must be maintained in good mechanical condition at all times and must present a neat appearance. The operator shall have each taxicab thoroughly inspected once each week by a competent automobile mechanic. Once each month the operator shall present each taxicab to the police department at police headquarters for inspection. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 9; Code 1977, § 35-4) Sec. 34-380. - Designation of stands by chief of police. The chief of police or his designee is delegated power and authority to designate and mark off in the business district parking places to be used exclusively for taxicabs for the taking on and the discharge of passengers. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 10; Code 1977, § 35-5) Sec. 34-381. - Scope of service required. All persons, operators and drivers engaged in the taxicab business in the city shall render an overall service to the public desiring to use taxicabs. They shall answer all calls received by them for service inside the corporate limits of the city as soon as they can do so, and if such service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall then notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reason therefor. Any operator or driver who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere in the corporate limits of the city at any time when such person has a taxicab available, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed a violator of this article. No license or permit shall be issued to an operator or to a driver who is not in a position to render full-time service to the exclusion of any other business except with the approval of the city commission. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 18; Code 1977, § 35-6) Sec. 34-382. - Regular place of business required. An operator must maintain a regular office or place of business satisfactory to the city commission as headquarters for his operations. Said office or place of business may store cabs ready for operation and may be a site for the repair of disabled vehicles under the following conditions: (1) Property must be fenced on all sides and shall have strips or netting or some other approved material to make the property not visible from any street on all sides except one, which must be fenced but may remain see-through for safety purposes only. (2) Unusable vehicles shall be parked behind separate fencing that must be totally shielded from public view. Such separate fencing shall be permitted to use only two sides of the external fencing and shall be completely enclosed. (3) Any vehicle parked upon the premises shall be permitted to remain only if operable. All inoperable cars shall be removed within ten days. (4) Nothing shall be sold from any premises constituting the office, place of business or taxicab stand. (5) No vehicles shall remain parked in view of the general public for more than ten days. (6) No alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on the premises for any purpose by owners or drivers. (7) The premises constituting the office or place of business shall at all times comply with chapter 26 and in the event more than one citation is issued for any property comprising a taxicab office, same shall constitute grounds for revocation of business permit and shall be grounds for immediate closure of business at location. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 19; Code 1977, § 35-7; Ord. No. 07-20, § 2, 12-4-2007) Sec. 34-383. - Carrying of additional passengers. No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in his taxicab, unless the person first employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of additional passengers. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 20; Code 1977, § 35-8) Sec. 34-384. - Receipts. The driver of any taxicab shall, upon demand by the passenger, render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the owner, cab number of the taxicab, amount of charges, date of the transaction and the driver's signature. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 21; Code 1977, § 35-9; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-385. - Maximum rates of fare. The maximum taxicab rates of fare are to be as follows, and whatever rates are charged shall be contained on a rate card in plain view of passengers in the interior of the taxicab: (1) A maximum rate shall be provided at $6.00 for any one trip from one point in the city limits to any other point in the city limits. Additional occupants travelling to the same destination will incur a charge of one-half of the charge up to $3.00 per occupant. (2) Waiting time shall not be more than $0.50 per minute after the first three minutes provided that the passenger shall have no more than one such three-minute period per trip. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 22; Code 1977, § 35-10; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 08-21, § 1, 7-1-2008) Sec. 34-386. - Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any permitted driver of any taxicab to misrepresent the name of his employer, or knowingly to receive or transport any persons who intend to commit an unlawful act in such vehicle, during the voyage or at the termination thereof, whether within such vehicle or not. It shall also be unlawful for any such driver to solicit or procure or to aid or assist in soliciting or procuring any person to ride in a licensed taxicab with the intent to commit an unlawful act therein at any time during the voyage or at the termination thereof, whether within the vehicle or not. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 23; Code 1977, § 35-11) Sec. 34-387. - Alcoholic beverage violations. It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of any taxicab to have in his possession or offer for sale any alcoholic beverages or to otherwise violate any provision of this Code or state law relating to alcoholic beverages. (Code 1977, § 35-12; Ord. of 12-1-1970, § 25) Sec. 34-388. - Immoral acts. It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any taxicab to transport from place to place within the city any person for any immoral purpose. (Code 1977, § 35-13; Ord. of 12-1-1970, § 25) Sec. 34-389. - Duties of taxicab drivers. (a) Age of driver. No driver under the age of 18 years will operate a taxicab on the streets of the city. (b) Transporting of prostitutes. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city for the purpose of soliciting or participating in the offense of prostitution. (c) Refusal to carry orderly person. No driver of a taxicab shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person upon request, unless he is previously engaged or is unable or forbidden to do so by provision of city ordinance or state law. If a person requesting taxi service is drunk or disorderly and the taxicab driver has reason to believe such person may do him bodily harm, he may refuse service to that person. (d) Conveying family members. When any taxicab is in service, no driver shall convey a member of his family or any other passenger without the payment of the regular charges as provided herein by such family member. (e) Number of passengers. No taxicab shall carry passengers in excess of its seating capacity, but infants in arms shall not be counted as passengers either for the purpose of collection of additional fares or for the purpose of counting seating capacity. Cargo such as groceries, luggage or large packages will reduce the passenger capacity when carried in the passenger compartment of the taxicab and will not be transported on the laps of passengers. All such cargo when carried in the passenger compartment will be placed on the floor or seats of the taxicab and passenger seating will be reduced in proportion to the available room in the taxicab. (f) Inspection of taxicabs. Taxicabs shall be maintained in such proper mechanical condition so as to be operated safely, and taxicabs shall also be maintained in a state of cleanliness and repair both inside and outside. It shall be the responsibility of each driver to ensure that equipment inspection is current at all times. Owners are required to make their own periodic inspections for cleanliness and keep a current log of all vehicles pending garage inspection dates. Owners and drivers of taxicabs shall yield to all reasonable requests to inspect equipment or provide inspection and/or repair information on any or all taxicabs identified by any police officer of the city police department. (g) Receipt and discharge of passengers. Drivers of taxicabs must not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall pull up to the sidewalk or curb on the right-hand side of the roadway and there receive or discharge passengers. (h) Soliciting patronage/jumping calls. It shall be unlawful for drivers of taxicabs to leave their vehicles for the purpose of soliciting patronage at any public place. It shall also be unlawful for a taxicab driver to use a radio or scanner for the purpose of usurping a call given out to another taxicab driver or another taxicab company. (i) Dress code. All taxicab drivers shall wear, as minimum dress, shoes, pants, shorts, skirt, or dress and shirt or blouse with either long sleeves or short sleeves. Drivers shall be clean in dress and clean in person at all times. (j) Display of permit. Taxicab drivers shall display their driver permits by affixing the permit provided for in this article to the interior of the taxicab in a manner and location so that the permit remains in view of the passenger at all times. (k) Deceiving of passengers prohibited. No driver shall deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger who may ride in this taxicab as to his destination or the rate of fare to be charged, nor shall he convey or cause to be conveyed any passenger to a place other than the one designated by him. All drivers shall comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of their passengers as to the speed of travel and the route to be taken. The driver shall keep the rate card in plain view at all times in the taxicab. (l) Transport of alcohol or illegal drugs prohibited. No driver of a taxicab shall purchase any type of alcohol or illegal drugs for any passengers, or knowingly transport any illegal drugs. Passengers who are of legal age and request a destination or stop where alcohol is legally sold must make their own purchases. Lawful purchases of alcohol by passengers may then be transported as any other baggage or groceries. (m) Property left in taxicab. Every driver of a taxicab shall thoroughly search the interior of such taxicab at the termination of each trip for any article of value which may be left in such taxicab by a passenger. Any article found therein shall be immediately returned to the passenger owning it, if he be known; otherwise, it shall be deposited with the cab company as soon as discovered. (n) Logs. Logs are to be maintained by both dispatchers and taxicab drivers. (1) Dispatchers shall maintain the log and certify the accuracy at designated shift intervals; (2) Each taxicab driver shall log calls received by cellular telephones or radio from a dispatcher and each taxicab driver shall log every other pickup with a dispatcher including a notation of passenger pickup times, location of pickup and destination, and passenger discharge times. (3) The owner shall maintain original logs in good condition for a minimum of six months. All logs shall be available at any time with reasonable cause for inspection by the city police department. (Code 1977, § 35-34; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-390. - Repairs or maintenance on rights-of-way prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any taxicab within the city to perform maintenance or repairs of said taxicab upon the streets, roads, rights-of-way, highways and alleyways within the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any taxicab within the city, to allow any other person to perform maintenance or repairs upon said taxicab on any streets, roads, rights-of-way, highways and alleyways within the corporate limits of the city. (c) For the purposes of this article, maintenance or repair shall not include repair of a flat tire or the removal of a disabled taxicab; or pumping gasoline into a taxicab that is out of gasoline. (d) For the purposes of this article, maintenance or repair of a taxicab shall include, without limitation, changing or replacing the motor oil, or any other fluids and parts. Any taxicab that is disabled, other than for a flat tire or out of gasoline, must be removed from the streets, roads, rights-of-way, highways and alleyways of the city. (Code 1977, § 35-14; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 10-3-1995) Sec. 34-391. - Identification of taxicabs. All taxicabs for each separate business shall adopt a single main color for all taxicabs owned by the company, to be approved by the chief of police to comply with this section. The chief of police shall have the power to recommend the city commission deny a taxicab owner's business license where the color scheme or the company name attempts to copy another color scheme or name of other taxicab companies so as to confuse the public as to the identity of different companies. Each taxicab shall be required to have the name of the company, the word "TAXI" in four-inch bold lettering and the telephone number of the company prominently displayed on both sides of all cabs. A lighted "TAXICAB" sign must be displayed on the top of the taxicab and must be lighted at all times when the taxicab is in service. Any taxicab which is removed or taken off the line and the taxicab liability insurance is canceled on such cab, shall have all signs, rate cards, phone numbers and markings removed from said vehicle before it may be operated as a private vehicle on the city streets. (Code 1977, § 35-15; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 07-20, § 3, 12-4-2007) Secs. 34-392—34-410. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE
Sec. 34-411. - Required; application; registration of vehicle; equipment inspections. (a) No owner shall operate, or allow others to operate a taxicab on the streets of the city without first obtaining a taxicab owner's business license. The taxicab owner's business license application form will be obtained from the city clerk's office in the city hall. The requirements of this section shall be in addition to any other license requirement set forth in this Code and applicable law. The application form shall require the following information: (1) Trade name of the taxi business to be operated. (2) Owner's name and home address, if an individual. (3) Names and home addresses of all partners, if a partnership. (4) Name and home address of corporation president and officers, if a corporation, as well as the registered agent and office of corporation. (5) Business address or addresses of company from which taxicabs will operate, where the 24-hour telephone switchboard will be, and the parking area or areas for the company's taxicabs when they are not being operated. (6) A statement that a monitored telephone will be provided to handle request for taxicab service from the general public at all times the business is open for business. (7) General description of identifying words and unique color scheme of the cab fleet. This must include as a minimum, name of company in four-inch or larger letters, telephone number of company in four-inch or larger letters and the word taxicab in four-inch or larger letters. All of said lettering shall be applied to both sides of the vehicle. (8) Name and policy number of the insurance carrier providing liability coverage for the taxicabs, as well as the amount of coverage, which in no event shall be less than the amount of coverage required by state law. (b) The chief of police or his designee shall review all applications for taxicab business license before submitting it to the city commission for approval or disapproval. The chief of police or his designee, when recommending denial of a license, must submit reasons for such recommendation in narrative form to the city commission. The city commission shall have final authority on issuance of all taxicab company owners' business licenses. (c) Upon approval by the city commission of the taxicab company owners' business licenses, the taxicab company owner must have on record with the city clerk and the city police department a certificate of insurance verifying insurance coverage covering all taxicabs to be used within the city and evidence that the policy premiums are paid for the duration of the license period applied for. Upon such proof and payment of the established fee, the city clerk will issue a taxicab company business license. (d) No taxicab shall be operated within the corporate limits of the city until the owner or driver has registered the taxicab with the city police department and said taxicab has been inspected by a garage or auto repair shop, approved and recorded with the city police department. The city police department shall issue a registration number for each registered taxicab which complies with the terms of this article. The registration number assigned by the city police department shall be prominently displayed on both sides and the back of each taxicab. (e) The chief of police shall have the power to cause to be bid out the contractible services of a licensed mechanic for the purpose of conducting semi-annual inspections of all taxicabs registered to operate in the city. The bid/contract process shall be considered at least once every other year or in the event of contract separation. (f) Taxicab equipment inspections shall be renewed semi-annually at a garage approved by the chief of police or upon reasonable request by any police officer in the course of an investigation. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 2; Code 1977, §§ 35-25, 35-52(e), (f); Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 14-05, § 1, 4-15-2014) Sec. 34-412. - Bond or policy. (a) No license to an operator shall be issued or continued in operation and force unless there is on file with the city clerk and in full force and effect an indemnity bond for each vehicle authorized in an amount, exclusive of interest and costs, of not less than $15,000.00 for bodily injury or death of one person in any one accident, and subject to such limit for one person, to a limit of not less than $30,000.00 because of bodily injury or death to two or more persons in any one accident, and if the accident has resulted in injury to or destruction of property, to a limit of not less than $10,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident. The bond shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or who shall sustain damage to property proximately caused by the negligence of an operator, his servants, agents, or employees. Such bond shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall have as surety thereon a surety company authorized to do business in the state. (b) The city clerk may, in his discretion, allow an operator to file, in lieu of such bond, a liability policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. Such policy shall conform to the provisions of this section relating to bonds. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 5; Code 1977, § 35-29; Ord. No. 87-06, § 1, 3-10-1987) Sec. 34-413. - Not a franchise. Nothing contained in this division shall be construed as a franchise or to give any vested right to any operator of taxicabs or to anyone else, and the right is reserved in the city commission to revoke any license granted under the provisions of this division. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 4; Code 1977, § 35-30) Sec. 34-414. - Transferability; replacement, substitution of taxicabs. Licenses, when issued, shall not be transferable without the consent of the city commission; provided, however, that holders of licenses may make replacements and substitutions of taxicabs, if the number of taxicabs operated does not exceed the number provided for in the license already issued to such holder. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 6; Code 1977, § 35-31) Sec. 34-415. - Denial, non-renewal, suspension and revocation of license. After the issuance of taxicab company business license, the chief of police shall have the authority to recommend a denial, revocation, suspension or refusal to renew any taxicab company owner's business license as a result of violations of this article or as a result of event, occurrence or circumstances which would make the taxicab company owner ineligible for a taxicab owner's business license in the first issuance. (1) An application for a license or a license issued under this division may be denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed, as applicable, for due cause as set forth in subsection (3) of this section. (2) The city commission shall furnish a license holder a notice setting forth the time, place and purpose of a meeting at which they intend to consider the revocation or suspension of a license. After a hearing, if the city commission determines due cause exists, they may suspend or revoke such license, or not renew the license or place the licensee on probation for a maximum of 12 months, with or without conditions, including, without limitation, the levying of civil monetary penalties, not to exceed $500.00. (3) A license may be denied, suspended, not renewed or revoked for any of the following reasons: a. Where the applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits information requested in the application for a license; b. For failure to pay all fees, taxes, penalties or other charges imposed by the provisions of this division and this Code; c. For failure to maintain all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of a license; d. For violation for any part of this division by the license holder, its agents, partners, officers, employees or contractors; e. Allowing the required insurance coverage to lapse shall result in the automatic suspension of the license until insurance coverage is reinstated and adequate evidence is provided to the chief of police that such coverage is in effect. (4) License holders under this division are responsible for violations of this division by their vehicle drivers whether such drivers are direct employees or independent contractors; (5) Licenses issued under this division are not transferrable. (Code 1977, § 35-32; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-416. - Renewals. Taxicab owner business licenses shall expire December 31 of each year; renewals are due January 1 of each year and delinquent March 1 of each year. Taxicab owner business licenses are purchased at the office of the city clerk at city hall. (Code 1977, § 35-52(a); Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Secs. 34-417—34-445. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT
Sec. 34-446. - Required; application. No driver shall operate a taxicab on the streets of the city without first obtaining and placing in plain view in the interior of his taxicab a driver's permit which shall be issued by the chief of police upon receipt of the following information to be signed and filed by the driver on an application form provided by the city police department: (1) Name, age and address of driver; (2) Name and address of the taxicab company under which the driver operates the taxicab. An established taxicab company must hold all required driver permits; (3) Whether the applicant for a taxicab driver permit has been convicted of any violation or any laws of the state, the United States or any other state, or any ordinance of the city, If there are any such violations, the applicant shall state the full details, including, without limitation, the offense, court, date of disposition and status; (4) Driver's license number issued by the state and its date of expiration; (5) A copy of this article shall be provided to each taxicab driver by the city police department at the time a taxicab driver applies for a taxicab driver permit. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 11; Code 1977, § 35-44; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-447. - Taxicab driver qualifications. Before operating a taxicab within the city, a driver shall: (1) Possess a valid Class I state driver's license; (2) Be mentally and physically competent to operate a motor vehicle; (3) Be familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances of the city; (4) Not have been convicted of a felony unless five years have elapsed since the completion of the felony sentence; (5) Not have been convicted of, entered a plea of nolo contendere to, or forfeited a bond in lieu of, any sexual or other crime of moral turpitude within past five years immediately prior to the application for a taxicab driver permit; (6) Not have been classified as a habitual offender by the state department of public safety or any similar department of any other state or of the United States for the five years immediately prior to the application for a taxicab driver permit; (7) Provide authorization and any information necessary to enable the chief of police or his designee to investigate the driver's background, criminal history, and traffic record; (8) Be of good character as determined by the aforesaid investigation; (9) Possess a taxicab driver's permit issued by the city police department; (10) Be at least 18 years of age. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 17; Code 1977, § 35-45; Ord. No. 76-15, § 1, 10-5-1976; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-448. - Application. Any person desiring to drive a taxicab, shall first make written application for a permit to the police department and file with the police department of the city a health certificate from a practicing physician showing good health and freedom from communicable diseases. The applicant must also file with the police department his fingerprints and his photograph. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 11; Code 1977, § 35-46) Sec. 34-449. - Investigation. The chief of police of the city shall cause to be conducted such investigation of the applicant for a taxicab driver's permit as he deems necessary. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 12; Code 1977, § 35-47) Sec. 34-450. - Fee. Before any taxicab driver's permit is issued, the applicant therefor shall pay an annual fee as established by the city commission. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 13; Code 1977, § 35-48) Sec. 34-451. - Issuance. If the application for a permit required by the provisions of this division is approved, the chief of police shall issue the same. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 13; Code 1977, § 35-49) Sec. 34-452. - Display. Each taxicab driver shall keep posted inside of the taxicab in a place that is visible to all passengers his permit issued under this division and his photograph. (Code 1952, ch. 23, § 13; Code 1977, § 35-50) Sec. 34-453. - Renewals. (a) Taxicab drivers' permit renewals begin July 1 of each year following the year of issuance. Permits expire on August 1 and a delinquent fee of $25.00 is added on September 15 of each year. The cost of an initial taxicab driver's permit is $25.00 (includes fingerprinting, photograph and history checks). Initial permits purchased within 90 days of the renewal date shall be in effect until the renewal date one full year following. Permits shall be applied for and issued through the city police department. Changes in management or ownership of the taxicab company must be registered with the city police department within three business days of such change in management or ownership. Such notice shall be accompanied with a payment of $5.00 as a changing fee. Drivers may operate for multiple companies but must be registered with each taxicab company in addition to the original company which filed the original permit application. (b) When an applicant originally applies for a driver's permit, and in every fifth year thereafter when he applies for a renewal of his permit, he shall file with his application or with his request for a renewal a physicians certificate certifying that he has no disease or mental or physical infirmity that adversely affects his ability to drive. (c) Whenever a taxicab driver is dismissed from the employment of a taxicab company, the taxicab company owner shall notify the city police department of such dismissal immediately by telephone and in writing within 48 hours. (Code 1977, § 35-52(b)—(d); Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-454. - Denial, non-renewal, suspension and revocation of permit. The chief of police shall have the power to deny, revoke, suspend or to refuse to renew any driver permit as a result of violations of this article or as a result of any occurrence which would make the taxicab company owner or driver ineligible for a permit in the first issuance, but no such revocation or non-renewal shall be made without first informing the taxicab company owner and the driver of the reasons therefore and without first giving such taxicab company owner or driver an opportunity to respond. (1) A denial, revocation, non-renewal or suspension or a permit by the chief of police shall be subject to appeal; (2) An application for a permit or a permit issued under this division may be denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed for due cause as set forth in subsection (4) of this section; (3) The chief of police or his designee shall furnish a permit holder a notice setting forth the time, place, and purpose of a meeting at which they intend to consider the revocation or suspension of a permit. After a hearing, if the chief of police or his designee determine due cause exists, they may deny, suspend, revoke the permit or place on probation for a maximum of 12 months, with or without conditions, the permit; (4) A permit may be denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed for any of the following reasons: a. Where the permit applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits information requested in the application for a permit; b. For failure to pay all fees, taxes, penalties or other charges imposed by the provisions of this division and this Code; c. For failure to maintain all or the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of a permit; d. Permits may be suspended or revoked for having three or more moving violations in any 12-month period; e. Where the applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits information regarding logs; f. Failure to stop and render aid or leaving the scene of an accident, as required under the laws of the state; g. Repeated violation of city ordinances, county laws, or state laws which affect the safety of persons traveling on the streets of the city. (Code 1977, § 35-33; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-455. - Penalty for violation of division. Any person who operates a taxicab upon the streets of the city without a permit as by this division required, or who drives a taxicab upon such streets while his permit is suspended or revoked, or who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to punishment as set forth in section 1-9. (Code 1977, § 35-53; Ord. No. 01-23, § 1, 11-20-2001) Sec. 34-456. - Certain exclusions from article provisions. Notwithstanding the other terms set forth herein, taxicab drivers, operators and owners who deliver passengers to points inside the corporate limits of the city, but do not pick up any passengers inside the corporate limits of the city for delivery of said passengers to points either inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall not be required to: (1) Obtain a taxicab owners business license required by section 34-411; (2) Obtain a taxicab driver's permit required by section 34-446; (3) Comply with identification of taxicab section 34-391; or (4) Comply with maximum rate of fare provisions of section 34-385. However, all such taxicab drivers, operators and owners which only deliver passengers inside the corporate limits of the city shall comply with section 34-389(a), (b), (e), (g), (k), (l), (m) and (n). (Code 1977, § 35-54; Ord. No. 02-08, § 1, 4-16-2002) Secs. 34-457—34-475. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - FIREWORKS STANDS
Sec. 34-476. - Temporary consumer fireworks retail sales stand license. The license fee for a distributor selling consumer fireworks from a temporary consumer fireworks retail sales stand is as established by the city commission and payable to the city. The distributor shall meet all requirements of O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1. Furthermore, the sales of consumer fireworks from such temporary consumer fireworks retail sales stands shall accrue to the benefit of a nonprofit group, and upon payment of such license fee, such license shall be issued by the city fire department. Further, no such license shall be issued prior to January 1, 2016. Any fees received under this section shall be expended for public safety purposes. (Ord. No. 15-28, § 1(18-142), 10-20-2015) ARTICLE XV. - FOOD TRUCKS
Sec. 34-477. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to allow for the licensing and regulation of "food trucks" operating within the city limits. In the interest of the public health, safety and welfare, the city commissioners may exercise limited discretion in evaluating the proposed operation of a "food truck," or the like, which requires a license in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. O17-25 , § 1, 11-7-2017) Sec. 34-478. - Definitions. Food means a raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, ice cream, ice, beverage, or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part, for human consumption. Food truck means a licensed, readily movable motorized wheeled vehicle or trailer, which is temporarily stored on a premise where food items are sold to the general public. Included in the definition are vehicles and equipment defined as "mobile food service unit" and/or "extended food service unit" contained and amended in Rules of Department of Public Health, Ga. Comp. R. and Regs. 511-6-1-.01 and 511-6-1-.08. (Ord. No. O17-25 , § 1, 11-7-2017) Sec. 34-479. - Food truck vendor requirements. (a) Prior to an application for any license to operate a food truck in the city, the food truck vendor shall first submit for inspection and be approved by the county health department or by the state department of agriculture if selling commercially packaged food. (b) The food truck vendor, being a business located in the city, must obtain an annual city business tax certificate as required by chapter 34 of this Code. During the food truck's hours of operation, the vendor shall at all times display a current business tax certificate. The food truck vendor shall renew any business tax certificate in accordance with chapter 34 of this Code. (c) The food truck vendor shall obtain and display the county health department-issued state department of public health mobile food service permit at all times during its hours of operations. The food truck vendor shall provide a copy of the mobile food service permit to the city building and codes department prior to obtaining a business tax certificate. (d) The food truck vendor shall obtain written authorization from the property owner or registered agent of the property for food vending. Such written authorization must be maintained and accessible in the truck at all times during the hours of operations. (e) Prior to the issuance of a business tax certificate, the food truck vendor shall make available the operating food truck for inspection by the city building and codes department and the city fire department. In order to obtain the business tax certificate, the food truck vendor shall provide proof that the truck has been inspected by the city building and codes department and the city fire department and that the truck is in compliance with the National Fire Protection Association and state fire codes. (f) Food truck vendors shall comply with all city, county, and state retail sales tax regulations. (Ord. No. O17-25 , § 1, 11-7-2017) Sec. 34-480. - Location requirements. (a) Food trucks shall locate on privately owned lots zoned C-2 highway commercial, C-4 central business, and MU mixed use districts, with all-weather surface (or gravel) parking areas, accessible by emergency vehicles, and having adequate legally designated off-street parking spaces, subject to the approval of the property owner and subject to the following: (1) Written notice to the county health department seven days prior to operations begin. Such notice shall state the expected dates of operation and shall specify the physical location of operations.
