Where this article or a franchise agreement specifies that a certain action will be taken by the commission or other named city entity, that action is reserved to the named entity. (c) All filings and reports required of franchisees or applicants pursuant to this article or a franchise agreement shall be made with the city manager unless otherwise specified. (Code 1977, § 18-97; Ord. No. 89-08, § 27, 6-6-1989) Sec. 36-75. - Applicability. (a) This article shall be applicable to all cable franchises issued by the city, whether or not such franchises were issued prior to June 6, 1989. However, this article shall not act to unilaterally abrogate contractual commitments of the city as contained in any franchise agreement. (b) A cable operator which holds a franchise agreement with the city that predates the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall notify the city within 90 days of the passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived of any provision of the article which it believes should be applicable to said franchisee by reason of the preexisting contractual commitment of the city. The city will formally notify the franchisee as to whether or not it agrees with the franchisee's interpretation. Failure of such a franchisee to so notify the city within that time period shall preclude the franchisee from later claiming any exception from adherence to all provisions of this article. The ordinance from which this article is derived shall be effective when finally approved by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 18-98; Ord. No. 89-08, § 28, 6-6-1989) Sec. 36-76. - Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. The city hereby requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the state. (Code 1977, § 18-99; Ord. No. 08-06, § 1, 3-4-2008) Sec. 36-77. - Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the city manager, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the secretary of state and each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five percent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. (Code 1977, § 18-100; Ord. No. 08-06, § 2, 3-4-2008)

div.head: Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 38-1. - Adoption of state law by reference; penalties for violation. Pursuant O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., known as the "Uniform Rules of the Road" are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. (Code 1977, § 20-1; Ord. No. 74-21, § 1, 10-1-1974; Ord. No. 83-29, §§ 1, 2, 8-2-1983) Sec. 38-2. - Enforcement of chapter. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to enforce all street traffic laws of the city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 3; Code 1977, § 20-2) Sec. 38-3. - Direction of traffic by police, firefighters. (a) Officers of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws; provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. (b) Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 4; Code 1977, § 20-3) Sec. 38-4. - Summons to specify violation charged. Notice to appear, complaint, or summons to a person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall specify the violation with which such person is charged. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 26; Code 1977, § 20-5) Sec. 38-5. - Zones of quiet. The chief of police shall have the authority temporarily to establish a zone of quiet upon any street where a person is seriously ill if requested to do so by a physician of the city. Such temporary zone of quiet shall embrace all territory within the radius of 200 feet of the building occupied by the person named in the request of such physician. Such temporary zone of quiet and any other zone of quiet declared by any ordinance of the city shall be designated by the chief of police by placing at a conspicuous place in the street a sign or marking bearing the words "Quiet Zone." (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 11; Code 1977, § 20-6) Sec. 38-6. - Driving in zones of quiet. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no person operating a motor vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or other warning device of such vehicle except in an emergency. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 60; Code 1977, § 20-7) Sec. 38-7. - Parade. (a) Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to organize, participate in or conduct any parade on the public streets, sidewalks or other public property or ways of the city unless an application for a permit has been previously filed and a permit has been granted to the applicant. However, under no circumstances shall more than one permit be issued to the same person or organization in any 11-month period. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Parade means any march or procession consisting of people, vehicles and carts, carriages or wagons pulled or drawn by animals or a combination thereof, except funeral processions, and hereinafter shall include any assemblage of persons, upon any public street, sidewalk or other public property or way which does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls. The term "parade" shall not include: (1) Governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions; and (2) Students participating in educational activities under the immediate supervision of school authorities. (c) Application. (1) Any person who seeks to sponsor a parade shall file an application for a parade permit with the city clerk. Such application shall be in writing, shall be at least seven days prior to the proposed parade date and shall contain the following information: a. The names, addresses and telephone numbers of all persons and organizations sponsoring, organizing and conducting the parade; b. The purpose of the parade: c. The date and time of the parade; d. The number and type of vehicles, carts, carriages or wagons pulled or drawn by one or more animals, marching units, bands, floats to be utilized in the parade including a description of any sound amplification equipment to be used; e. The estimated number of persons to participate in the parade; f. The maximum length of the parade; and g. A certification from the person or organization making the application that such person or organization anticipates no unusual problems concerning either police protection or traffic congestion to be experienced as a consequence of the parade, or if such statement cannot be made, the reasons therefor. (2) If the applicant for a parade permit expects or believes that animals are to be marching, proceeding, participating or otherwise included in the parade in any respect, the applicant shall disclose such expectation and belief on the application. However, such disclosure shall not authorize any use of animals other than that set forth in this chapter. (d) Investigation of, and report on applicant. The city clerk shall forward the application to the chief of police who shall investigate the application and make a report to the city manager. The report shall indicate whether the requirements of subsection (c) of this section have been met and shall state the official position of the police department regarding the certification specified in subsection (c)(7) of this section. If it is the opinion of the chief of police that the parade will require additional personnel above and beyond that number of police officers normally scheduled to be on duty on the date of the proposed parade, such information shall also be included in the report. (e) Issuance; denial. The city manager shall review the report of the chief of police and if all of the requirements specified in this section have been satisfied by the applicant, the city manager shall issue a parade permit, unless the city manager reasonably finds that: (1) The parade will be of a size or nature that requires the diversion of an excessive number of police officers of the city that allowing the parade would deny reasonable police protection to the city. (2) The parade will interfere with another parade for which a permit has been issued. (3) The information contained in the application is found to be false in any material detail. (4) The purpose of the parade is illegal or is in any way prohibited by law. (5) The applicant refuses to agree to abide by and comply with the conditions of the permit. (f) Notice of denial; appeal. (1) If an application of a permit pursuant to this section is denied, the city shall give the applicant timely written notice of the denial, and the reasons for such denial. (2) Upon the denial of a parade permit, the applicant may appeal such decision to the city within five business days of the date of such decision. (3) The city shall consider the appeal at its first regularly scheduled meeting which is at least three days from the date of appeal. Upon such appeal, the city may reverse, affirm or modify in any regard the decision to deny the permit. (4) If the appeal is denied, the applicant may apply to the superior court of the county for certiorari. (g) Revocation. Any permit for a parade issued pursuant to this section may be summarily revoked on the day of the parade by the chief of police when by reason of disaster, public calamity, riot or other emergency, the chief of police determines that the safety of the public or property requires such revocation. If a permit is so revoked, the permittee shall be allowed to reapply for a new parade permit. (h) Bond of applicant. If it is the official position of the chief of police that additional personnel shall be required for traffic and pedestrian control, the city manager shall require the applicant to post a bond in an amount deemed by the city manager sufficient for and conditioned on the payment by the applicant of the additional costs incurred by the city for such service. (i) Regulations. (1) For the purpose of controlling traffic and pedestrian congestion and/or providing for the public health, safety and general welfare, the following regulations shall pertain to all parades conducted within the city: a. Except for a historically established parade, all parades shall be conducted with a specific route in accordance with subsection (j) of this section. Each historically established parade shall follow either the route followed by such parade in the next previous occurrence of such parade (i.e., traditional route) or the route set forth in subsection (j) of this section. The application shall state whether the applicant desires the change from the traditional route. b. Parades shall be conducted only between the hours set forth in the application. c. All parade participants shall assemble for the parade at one location to be designated by the chief of police. d. Except for nationally recognized veteran's organizations, representatives of local, state and federal law enforcement agencies, and representatives of a military unit of the United States of America, no parade participant shall carry arms or other weapons. No parade participant shall carry bricks, bats, sticks, rocks, bottles, or other such items which may be used as weapons. e. The materials used in the construction of floats in the parade shall be of fire retardant materials and shall be subject of such requirements concerning fire safety as may be determined by the fire chief. f. Once commenced the parade shall not stop along the parade route, but shall continue to move at a fixed rate of speed, and any willful delay or willful stopping of said parade, except when reasonably required for the safety and orderly conduct of the parade, shall constitute a violation of the permit. g. The parade shall strictly follow the route designated in subsection (j) of this section. h. Literature, publications, leaflets, other written materials, candy, food or food products shall not be distributed along the parade route from floats, vehicles, and so forth. i. Speeches shall be allowed only at the conclusion of the parade and at a location designated by the chief of police. j. Speeches, rallies or other activity to be conducted at the conclusion of the parade shall be limited to a total time of 30 minutes, after which the parade participants shall disperse. k. In no event shall speeches, rallies, etc., be conducted in the public streets, or along the sidewalks of the city. l. The permittee shall advise all participants in the parade, either orally or by written notice, of the terms and condition of the permit, prior to the commencement of the parade, and shall sign an acknowledgement that the permittee has read, and understands and will comply with the regulations specified in this section and the conditions of the permit and has advised all participants as so required in this subsection. m. No animal shall walk, march, proceed or otherwise participate in any parade, unless the animal is pulling or drawing a cart, carriage, or wagon except at the request of the sponsoring agency. n. No unit, float or vehicle shall join the parade once commenced. No person or organization shall participate in the parade or be part of the parade without the express permission of the parade sponsors. (2) Any other reasonable regulation or restriction deemed necessary by the city manager for the protection and safety of the parade participants, viewing public, or for the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city may be imposed by the city manager. However, such additional regulations or restrictions shall be specified in writing to the applicant with all reasons therefor clearly enumerated. (j) Parade route. (1) Except as set forth herein for historically established parades, all parades shall travel along the following parade route: parades shall commence at Mary Street, proceed easterly along Elizabeth Street to Plant Avenue; thence northeasterly along Plant Avenue from Elizabeth Street to Carswell Avenue; thence westerly along Carswell Avenue to Tebeau Street; thence southerly along Tebeau Street to Isabella Street; thence along Isabella Street to Mary Street Park. Parades shall terminate at Mary Street Park. (2) Historically established parades are those parades that have been in existence for a period of not less than five years before the approval of the ordinance from which this section is derived and are held once in each calendar year and each such parade is authorized to follow the same parade route that was established at the next previous occurrence of such parade or the parade may follow the route set forth in subsection (j)(1) of this section. At the time of filing the application, the applicant must state if the parade route will follow the route above set forth. The historically established parades are Christmas Parade, Martin Luther King, Jr. Holiday Parade, Midget Bowl Parade and the Waycross Shrine Club Parade. (3) A historically established parade may request a variation of its traditional route for reasons of health and safety by including such request in the application required in subsection (c) of this section. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 15; Code 1977, § 20-8; Ord. of 8-7-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 92-15, § 1, 5-5-1992; Ord. No. 93-01, 1-5-1993; Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 2-19-2002; Ord. No. 03-06, § 1, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 07-22, § 1, 12-4-2007) Sec. 38-8. - Towing. The connection between towed vehicles shall not exceed 16 feet in length. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 24; Code 1977, § 20-12) Secs. 38-9—38-34. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES
Sec. 38-35. - Resolution of conflict. Throughout this article, in the event of conflict between the chief of police and the city engineer, the city commission will resolve the conflict. Sec. 38-36. - Authority to place, maintain, etc.—Electric devices. As an aid in facilitating the movement of traffic on the streets of the city and in reducing accidents, the chief of police and the city engineer are hereby authorized and directed to place and maintain electric traffic control devices and signals at such locations as may be designated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 28; Code 1977, § 20-26) Sec. 38-37. - Same—Other devices. The chief of police of the city and the city engineer shall place and maintain, other than electrically operated traffic control devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances, and, with the approval of the city manager, may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as they may deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 4; Code 1977, § 20-27) Sec. 38-38. - Same—Designation of crosswalks; establishment of safety zones; marking of traffic lanes. The chief of police and the city engineer are hereby authorized: (1) To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in their opinion there is a particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as they may deem necessary. (2) To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at any such place as they may deem necessary, for the protection of pedestrians. (3) To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as they may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city and the laws of the state to indicate by white lines on street pavements parking spaces for vehicles. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 30; Code 1977, § 20-28) Sec. 38-39. - Same—Restricted turn signs. The chief of police and the city engineer are hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left, or U turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 31; Code 1977, § 20-29) Sec. 38-40. - Same—Turning markers. The chief of police and the city engineer are authorized to place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 32; Code 1977, § 20-30) Sec. 38-41. - Same—Stop signs; reduced speed signs. (a) Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates or describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the chief of police and the city engineer to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting such through street or that portion thereof described and designated as such by this chapter or any ordinance of the city. (b) The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazard exists upon other than through streets and to determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such stop intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required, or, in the event the chief of police and the city engineer determine that reduced speed rather than a stop is adequate for safe operation at any such intersection, they shall determine such safe speed by engineering investigation and shall erect signs upon the approaches to such intersection giving notice of such speed. (c) Every such stop sign shall bear the word "Stop" in letters of not less than six inches in height. Every stop sign shall be located as near as practical at the property line of the street at the entrance to which the stop must be made. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 33; Code 1977, § 20-31) Sec. 38-42. - Same—Limited parking signs. Whenever by this chapter or any ordinance of the city any time limit parking is imposed, it shall be the duty of the chief of police and the city engineer to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective until such signs are erected. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 34; Code 1977, § 20-32) Sec. 38-43. - Manual and specifications for traffic control devices. All traffic control devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state department of transportation or as provided by the laws of the state or ordinances of the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 35; Code 1977, § 20-33) Sec. 38-44. - When devices required for enforcement purposes. No provisions of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective without signs being erected to give notice thereof. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 37; Code 1977, § 20-35) Secs. 38-45—38-61. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING, AND PARKING
Sec. 38-62. - Parking lines; angle and parallel parking. On streets where white lines are shown for guidance, parking must conform to such lines. The driver must park his vehicle entirely within the boundaries designated by such lines. No person shall park and leave unattended a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curb-side wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the edge of the roadway, except upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking, and on such streets vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the edge of the roadway indicated by such marks or signs. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 65; Code 1977, § 20-47) Sec. 38-63. - Passenger zones and freight loading zones. The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger zones and freight loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable, as follows: (1) At any place within any business district. (2) Elsewhere in front of an entrance to any place of business or in front of any hall or place used for the purpose of public assembly. a. In no event shall more than one-half of the total curb length in any block be reserved for loading zone purposes. b. All loading zones shall be indicated by yellow paint lines on curbs and by appropriate signs, reading "Loading Only" or "Passenger Loading Only." c. When such zone is in front of a hotel, railroad passenger station or bus station, the restrictions shall apply at all times. When such zone is in front of an entrance to a place of business or a theater or other place of public assembly the restrictions shall apply at all times except when such theater, place of business, or such other place of public assembly is closed. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 13; Code 1977, § 20-48) Sec. 38-64. - Standing for loading only. (a) No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of passengers or materials in any place marked as a loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to loading zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes, or for loading and unloading of passengers exceed five minutes. (b) No vehicle shall take on or discharge passengers when such vehicle is on a street except at the right margin of the roadway; provided, however, that on a one-way street a vehicle may take on or discharge passengers at either margin of the roadway. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 69; Code 1977, § 20-49) Sec. 38-65. - Unattended motor vehicles. No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, and removing the key, or when standing upon any perceptible grade without effectively setting the brake thereon and turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 70; Code 1977, § 20-50) Sec. 38-66. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for principal purpose of: (1) Displaying it for sale; (2) Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 72; Code 1977, § 20-52) Sec. 38-67. - Parking of vehicles transporting inflammable or explosive substances. No person shall park a vehicle which is used for transporting gasoline, acid, gas, or other substance that is inflammable, explosive, or otherwise hazardous to persons or property, and leave the same unattended on any street of the city, except in an emergency which must not exceed 30 minutes. (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 73; Code 1977, § 20-53) Sec. 38-68. - Parking of trucks, tractor trailers, and similar vehicles, and hovercrafts, boats, jet skis, and similar watercraft in residential districts. (a) Purpose. The purpose of this section is to regulate the parking of trucks, trailers, other similar vehicles and equipment of a certain size, hovercrafts, boats, jet skis and similar watercraft upon roadways within residential neighborhoods. Said vehicles, equipment, hovercraft and watercraft tend to block the view of other vehicles and children playing in these neighborhoods as well as negatively impacting the aesthetics of the residential neighborhood. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Prohibited vehicles, hovercraft and watercraft means a truck, tractor, tractor trailer, trailer body, bus, commercial vehicle, recreational vehicle, motor home, travel trailer, camper or any similar vehicle or equipment having an overall length in excess of 20 feet or a height of more than nine feet, or any hovercraft, boat, jet skis or similar watercraft. Pickup trucks and sports-utility vehicles (SUVs) are not prohibited vehicles for purposes of this section. (c) On-street parking prohibited. The parking of any prohibited vehicle, hovercraft or watercraft on any street within any residential district in the city from the hours of 6:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. daily is prohibited. No person shall park any prohibited vehicle, hovercraft or watercraft for more than one hour between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. upon any public street within any residential district in the city. (d) Off-street parking prohibitions. It shall be unlawful for anyone to store any prohibited vehicle, hovercraft or watercraft, except as delineated in subsection (d)(1)—(6), of this section, on properties in residential zoning districts unless they comply with the following rules: (1) Such storage of prohibited vehicles, hovercraft or watercraft shall not be located within any front yard or side yard, within the front eight feet of any rear yard, within three feet of any property line, nor closer to the right-of-way line of a side street than the set-back distance required for the main structure on the same lot. (2) Only one such travel trailer, recreational vehicle, motor home or camper shall be permitted to be stored outdoors in any required yard setback areas of a lot on any residential zoning district. (3) The city manager shall have the authority to waive, in whole or in part, the provisions of subsection (1) above as it relates to recreational vehicles, travel trailers or motor homes in the event of a hardship related to physical constraints of the property or the health of a property owner at, said residence. The property owner shall be required to provide proof of a hardship sufficient to warrant a waiver. Any waiver granted by the city manager shall be for a term of no longer than 14 days and only one such waiver shall be granted in any 12 month period. (4) Any such vehicle, hovercraft or watercraft stored in accordance with this subsection (d), shall not be occupied and shall not be provided with utility connections other than required for vehicle maintenance and shall not be used for storage of any non- recreational material. (5) This subsection (d) shall not apply to the storage of any construction vehicles engaged in construction for an active construction site. (6) Only one commercial vehicle of a rated capacity not exceeding two tons with two axles, owned or used by a resident of the premises, shall be permitted to be regularly parked or garaged on a lot in any residential zoning district. For purposes of this section, a commercial vehicle is a bus and/or vehicle containing advertising matter intending to promote the interest of any business, whether or not said vehicle is registered as a commercial vehicle with any state division of motor vehicles. (e) Truck parking in residential zones prohibited. In all residential zoning districts, the parking of tractor-trailer trucks, either tractor or trailer, whether coupled or uncoupled, is prohibited on public or private property. Tractor-trailer trucks are those commonly called "semi"; one unit, the tractor, being the power unit and another unit, the semi-trailer, carrying the freight, and having a GVW of 33,000 pounds or greater. The temporary parking of a commercial vehicle that is parked temporarily in conjunction with a commercial service, sale or delivery is permitted. (f) Exceptions. This section shall not apply to any governmental entity or agency. (Code 1977, § 20-54; Ord. of 4-16-1968, § 1; Ord. No. 08-35, § 1, 12-2-2008; Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 16-07 , § 1, 5-17-2016) Sec. 38-69. - Placement and parking of portable storage units. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Portable storage units means portable sheds or trailers that are designed to be loaded with materials and placed on a residential or commercial property for the purpose of storing materials. (b) Permit required: application; insurance; fee. Before placing a portable storage unit on his property for more than three days, a person must submit an application and receive a permit from the city. There is a fee as established by the city commission for each day beyond an initial period of three days. An application can be obtained from the department of community development and improvement. (c) Duration. Permits will be granted for a period of no more than ten days. Before the expiration of the ten-day period, applicants may seek to extend their permits for an additional ten days by seeking an extension for cause from the director of community improvement. Extension of a permit will cost an amount as established by the city commission for each day granted. (d) Location. Portable storage units are prohibited from being placed in streets or the front yard of a residential property. Portable storage units must be kept in the driveway of a residential property at the furthest accessible point from the street. All locations must be paved off-street surfaces. Portable storage units placed on commercial property must be placed on the side or back of a building in a manner that does not block traffic or entry and exit into the commercial premises. The applicant for a permit in subsection (b) of this section must obtain preapproval of the location by the city enforcement officer in the following situations: (1) If the property does not have a driveway. (2) If the location of the unit in the driveway is in front yard of the property. (3) If the property is a corner lot. (e) Number of units. Only one portable storage unit may be placed at any residential or commercial property at one time. (f) Construction sites. Up to three portable storage units may be used at a location during times when the portable storage units are being used for storage of materials and tools related to a construction project. Such portable storage units require no fee or license and may be placed at the construction site for no more than 120 days and shall be removed when construction is completed. (Code 1977, § 20-55; Ord. No. 08-34, § 1, 12-2-2008) Secs. 38-70—38-96. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED VEHICLES
Sec. 38-97. - Prohibition; nuisance. No person shall park, store, place, or allow to remain on the public streets, alleys, or other public places in the city, or in the open upon private property, any disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicles or parts of motor vehicles, and the parking, storing, placing, or allowing to remain upon such designated places of such disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicles or parts of motor vehicles is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Code 1977, § 20-66; Ord. of 12-19-1967, § 1) Sec. 38-98. - Impoundment, expenses. The chief of police is authorized to tow away or cause to be towed away any disabled, wrecked or junked motor vehicles or parts of motor vehicles found on the public streets, alleys, or other public places within the corporate limits of the city in violation of this article, and to store and impound the same until the expenses of towing and storage shall be paid by the owner of such property. The expense of such towing and storage shall be paid by the owner of such property, and such expenses may be assessed against such owner and collected in the same manner as city taxes are assessed and collected. (Code 1977, § 20-67; Ord. of 6-15-1965, § 2) Secs. 38-99—38-126. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES
Sec. 38-127. - Applicability of chapter provisions. Every person riding a bicycle shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. (Code 1952, ch. 6, § 9; Code 1977, § 20-101) Sec. 38-128. - Operating at unusual speed or in disorderly manner. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride any bicycle at an unusual speed, or in a disorderly manner, or so as to endanger the life or limbs of another. (Code 1952, ch. 6, § 15; Code 1977, § 20-106) Sec. 38-129. - Riding on sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 6, § 16; Code 1977, § 20-107) Secs. 38-130—38-156. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SCHEDULES
Sec. 38-157. - Through streets designated. The following streets and portions of streets are hereby declared to be through streets for the purpose of this chapter:
;hn0; (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 9; Code 1977, § 20-119; Ord. No. O17-09 , § 1, 5-16-2017) Sec. 38-158. - One-way streets designated. The following streets and portions of streets are hereby declared to be one-way streets and vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited:
;hn0; (Code 1952, ch. 13, § 10; Code 1977, § 20-120; Ord. of 3-2-1954, § 1; Ord. of 7-15-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 73-7, § 1, 6-19-1973; Ord. No. 73-17, § 2, 11-20-1973; Ord. No. 73-22, § 2, 12-18-1973; Ord. No. 77-4, § 1, 8-2-1977; Ord. No. 78-6, § 1, 3-7-1978; Ord. No. 81-38, § 1, 12-1-1981; Ord. No. 01-25, § 2, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 08-31, § 1, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 15-27, § 1, 10-20-2015) Sec. 38-159. - Load limits. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle, truck or tractor-trailer combination, having a manufacturer's recommended load capacity of 1½ tons or more, upon the following streets:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 40-1—40-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SEWERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 40-23. - Disposing of sewage by delivery to city facility. All persons disposing of sewage by delivering same to the city sewage treatment facility shall be charged at rates determined by the city commission from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. Among the various factors to be included in determining the rates charged shall be the cost to treat the sewage delivered to the sewage treatment facility. (Code 1977, § 32-1; Ord. No. 01-02, § 1, 1-16-2001; Ord. No. 05-15, § 1, 6-21-2005) Secs. 40-24—40-49. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SEWER USE CHARGES
Sec. 40-50. - Applicability. Each person owning any building inhabited or used within the city by human beings as a place of residence or otherwise, that shall be connected with or available for connection to any line of the sewerage system, shall be considered and declared to be, for the purpose of enforcement of this division, a user of such system and shall pay such fees, rates and charges therefor as are established by this division or as are hereafter modified by ordinances of the city. (Code 1977, § 32-86; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-01), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-51. - Minimum charge. All users of the system shall pay a minimum charge for sewer service which is equal to or greater than his proportionate share of operation and maintenance costs for the system. (Code 1977, § 32-87; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-02), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-52. - User charge system to take precedence over previous agreements. The user charge system adopted by the city shall take precedence over any previous agreements with any user served by the city. (Code 1977, § 32-88; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-03), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-53. - Records. The city shall maintain system revenue and expense records as required by federal guidelines, and make such records available as required by authorized agencies. (Code 1977, § 32-89; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-04), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-54. - Updating of system. The city shall provide for an updating and refinement of its user charge system not less frequently than biennially in order to assure proportionality of charges among user classes and adequacy of revenues to meet requirements. (Code 1977, § 32-90; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-05), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-55. - Statements; posting of fee schedules. The city shall provide each user individually with a statement of his sewer use unit charge no less frequently than annually. In addition, a schedule of all sewer use fees shall be posted at city hall, and shall be available from the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 32-91; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-06), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-56. - Determination of charges. The rates, charges and surcharges for the use and service of the city's sewerage system, as well as fees for connection thereto, shall be as determined by the city commission from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 32-92; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-07), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-57. - Payment. The charges established by this division for sewer service shall be payable monthly at the same time and in the same manner as water bills are paid to the city at the office of the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 32-93; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-08), 4-5-1983) Sec. 40-58. - Owner of property liable for unpaid charges; unpaid charges constitute a lien; disconnection of service line. (a) The owner of the property upon which any building or structure is located, the owner-occupant of which has incurred liability for charges imposed under the provisions of this division, shall be liable for the payment of such charges. In the event the owner of the property upon which any building or structure is located shall lease said premises and the tenant and/or occupant applies for and places said sewer services in the name of the tenant and/or occupant and shall pay a deposit equal to two months' service, based on a six-usage-month average of prior service to said address (or any such other amount as determined by the city commission from time to time), then any unpaid charges shall be first deducted from said deposit and the tenant and/or occupant in whose name the sewer service has been connected shall be liable for any charges remaining unpaid. In the event the owner of any property upon which any building or structure is located leases said premises and retains sewer services in the name of said owner, then any unpaid charges for said services shall be the responsibility of the owner of said premises, said owner of the premises shall be deemed the user of such services and shall be liable for same. For purposes of this division, the term "owner-occupant" includes, but is not limited to, any person having any undivided or other ownership interest in and to the property. (b) All charges payable by a user of sewer service under the provisions of this division, which shall be and remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after the same become due and payable shall be and are hereby declared a lien upon the lot or other tract of land owned by such user and to which such sewer service is delivered and shall be enforced in the same manner as are delinquent taxes by the issuance of execution. In addition to the enforcement remedy of issuing executions, the city clerk is hereby authorized to issue an order and to have the water connection which feeds the sewer line cut off, as in the case of a delinquent water user. (c) For purposes of this division, the term "lease" includes, but is not limited to, permitting the occupancy of a building or structure whether or not said occupants pay for the occupancy through rent or otherwise. (Code 1977, § 32-94; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2(10-09), 4-5-1983; Ord. No. 92-28, § 1, 8-18-1992) Secs. 40-59—40-89. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - INDUSTRIAL WASTES
Sec. 40-90. - Purpose and objectives of division; administration. (a) The purpose of this division is to regulate the use of public and private sewers and drains, private wastewater disposal, the installation and connection of building sewers, and the discharge of waters and wastes into the public sewer system and provide penalties for violations thereof in the city. All connections of lateral or other sewer lines to the sewerage system of the city service area, whether within or without the city limits, shall be made subject to such terms and conditions as the city may prescribe. The division enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws required by the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the general pretreatment regulations (40 CFR 403). (b) The objectives of this division are: (1) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will interfere with operation of the system or contaminate the resulting sludge; (2) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system; (3) To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludges from the system; (4) To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the POTW is subject; (5) To provide for the regulation of direct and indirect contributors to the municipal wastewater system through issuance of permits to certain nondomestic users and through enforcement of general requirements for the other users; and (6) To authorize monitoring and enforcement activities, user reporting, and provide for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. (c) Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this division. Any powers or duties granted to or upon the city manager may be delegated by the city manager to a duly authorized representative. (Code 1977, § 32-111; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-91. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. Authorized representative of the user means: (1) If the user is a corporation, limited liability company or other entity note named or described herein: a. The president, secretary treasurer, or vice-president of the corporation, limited liability company, or other such entity in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation, limited liability company or other such entity; or b. The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than 250 persons or having a gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding $25,000,000.00, if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. (2) If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: any partner unless the partnership is a limited partnership or limited liability partnership in which case it shall be the general partner or proprietor, respectively. (3) If the user is a federal, state, or local government facility: a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their designee. (4) The officers and officials described in subsections (1) through (3) of this definition may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for the environmental matters for the company, and the written authorization is submitted to the city. Biochemical oxygen demand or BOD means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under EPA approved laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed as a concentration (e.g., mg/l). Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of buildings and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection or service connection. Categorical standards means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR 405—471. City municipality policy means the governmental body having jurisdiction over the maintenance and operations of the water and sanitary sewer system within the city and adjacent areas. Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. Composite means the makeup of a number of individual samples, so taken as to represent the nature of sewage or industrial wastes. Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. Effluent means the discharge flow of a pretreatment facility. Equalizing units means those devices or structures constructed to regulate evenly, either or both, the strength and volumes of wastes. Existing source means any source of discharge, the construction or operation of which commenced prior to the publication by the EPA of proposed categorical pretreatment standards, which will be applicable to such source if the standard is thereafter promulgated in accordance with section 307 of the Act. Flammable means defined by existing fire regulations to be enforced pursuant to the ordinances and laws of the city. Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Flush toilet means the common sanitary flush commode in general use for the disposal of human excrement. Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and serving of foods. Grab sample means a sample which is taken from a wastestream without regard to flow in the wastestream and over a period of time not to exceed 15 minutes. Health officer means the director of the board of health or other person designated and their duly appointed assistants. The health officer may be a person designated by the city and their duly appointed assistants of the health officer. Hours of operation means the normal number of hours per day that an industry or commercial establishment operates. Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) and (c) of the Act into the POTW (including holding tank waste). Industrial/commercial user means all users not embraced within the definition of a residential or domestic user as herein defined are declared to be industrial or commercial users. Infiltration/inflow means groundwater and surface water which leaks into the sewers through cracked pipes, joints, manholes, or other openings. Interference means a discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and therefore, is a cause of a violation of the city's NPDES permit or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder, or any more stringent state or local regulations if any: section 405 of the Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act, including, without limitation, title II, commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA); any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. National prohibitive discharge standard means any regulation developed under the authority of 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR 403.5. Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. New source means: (1) Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: a. The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; b. The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or c. The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. (2) Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)b or c of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. (3) Construction of a new source as defined under this section has commenced if the owner or operator has: a. Begun, or caused to begin as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 1. Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; 2. Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or b. Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection. Pass through means a discharge which exits the POTW into the waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit for its POTW. Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assignees. pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions. Pit privy means shored vertical pit in the earth completely covered with a fly-tight slab on which is securely located a fly-tight riser covered with hinged fly-tight seat and lid. Pollutant means dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural and industrial wastes, and certain characteristics of wastewater (e.g., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, or odor). Pretreatment or treatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration may be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, process changes by other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d). Appropriate pretreatment technology includes control equipment, such as equalization tanks or facilities, for protection against surges or slug loadings that might interfere with or otherwise be incompatible with the POTW. However, where wastewater from a regulated process is mixed in an equalization facility with unregulated wastewater or with wastewater from another regulated process, the effluent from the equalization facility must meet an adjusted pretreatment limit calculated in accordance with 40 CFR 403.6(e). Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a sewer which is owned and controlled, or controlled by the city. Polluted water means that wastewater leaving the user's premises to which contaminants have been added so as to render the water nonpotable. POTW (publicly owned treatment works) means any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal and/or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. This includes sewers, pipes, and other conveyances only if they convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant. POTW treatment plant means that portion of the POTW which is designed to provide treatment (including recycling and reclamation) of municipal and/or industrial waste. Receiving waters means those waters into which wastes are discharged. Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater, and surface water that are not intentionally admitted. Septic tank means a subsurface impervious tank designed to temporarily retain sewage or similar waterborne wastes together with: (1) A sewer line constructed with solid pipe, with the joints sealed, connecting the impervious tank with a plumbing stub out; and (2) A subsurface system of trenches, piping, and other materials constructed to drain the clarified liquid from the tank and distribute it underground to be absorbed or filtered. Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater. SIC is an acronym for standard industrial classification. Significant industrial user means: (1) Any industrial user of the city's wastewater disposal system who is: a. A user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or b. A user that discharges an average of 25,000 gpd or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling, and boiler blow down wastewater); contributes a process waste stream which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or is designated as such by the city on the basis that it has reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. (2) Upon a finding that an industrial user meeting the criteria in subsection (1)b of this definition has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the city may at any time, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from an industrial user or POTW in form and content reasonably acceptable to the city manager, and in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6), determine that such industrial user is not a significant industrial user. Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent, or in quantity of flow which adversely affects the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater facilities. Storm sewer means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sanitary and/or polluted industrial wastewater. Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, wastewater or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. Total suspended solids or TSS means all solids contained in sewage except colloidal and dissolved solids. Unpolluted water means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. Wastewater means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of the source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. The equivalent term is "sewage." Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. (Code 1977, § 32-112; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-92. - Abbreviations. The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings:
;hn0; (Code 1977, § 32-113; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-93. - Use of public sewers required. (a) All premises shall be provided, by the owner thereof, with at least one toilet. All toilets shall be kept clean and in sanitary working condition. (b) No person shall dispose of human excrement except in a toilet. (c) It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, including septic tank effluent or cesspool overflow to any open drain or well-penetrating water bearing formation, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division. (d) Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. (e) The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the city's jurisdiction and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the city is hereby required at the owner expense to install suitable toilet facilities herein, and to connect such facilities directly with the public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, within 30 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within 100 feet of the property line. (f) All sinks, dish washing machines, lavatories, basins, shower baths, bathtubs, laundry tubs, washing machines, and similar plumbing fixtures or appliances shall be connected to the public sewer. (g) The provisions of this article shall apply equally to those users of the city's sewage system within the limits of the city and to those who the city may choose to serve outside of said corporation lines. (Code 1977, § 32-114; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-94. - Private wastewater disposal. (a) Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 40-93, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of the city and the state department of human resources. (b) Septic tanks shall be constructed, repaired, altered, enlarged, and maintained in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the health officer. Septic tanks shall be maintained in sanitary working order. (c) No person shall construct, repair, alter, or enlarge any septic tank unless he shall hold a valid permit for such work issued by the health officer. The health officer may withhold the issuance of such a permit pending the inspection and approval by the health officer of the site and location of the proposed work. Before any septic tank or any part thereof may be covered after it has been constructed, repaired, altered, or enlarged, it shall be inspected and approved by the health officer. (d) The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of human resources of the state. No permit shall be issued for any private wastewater disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than that allowed by the health officer. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. (e) No septic tank or other subsurface disposal facility shall be installed where a public sewer is accessible within 100 feet to the premises involved, nor in any place where the health officer deems the use of same to be a menace to human health or well-being. (f) At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within 30 days after notice. Any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall then be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. (g) The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (h) Flush toilets shall be provided at all times with sufficient running water under pressure to flush the toilet clean after each use. (i) No pit privy shall be installed in the following locations: (1) Where a public sewer is accessible to the premises involved; (2) In areas where the health officer deems the use of pit privies to constitute a nuisance or menace to the public health; (3) Where a pit privy may pollute any water supply; or (4) Where the use of pit privies is not in keeping with the standard of sanitation in adjacent areas. (j) Any premises that has a septic tank, privy; or any other sewage, industrial waste, or liquid waste disposal system located thereon that does not function in a sanitary manner shall be corrected within 30 days from the receipt of written notification from the health officer. (k) Premises with private water systems shall not be connected with the public sewage system. (l) No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. (Code 1977, § 32-115; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-95. - Building sewers and connections. (a) No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. (b) The owner or his agent shall make application for a permit to connect to, open into, use, alter or disturb a public sewer or appurtenance on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the discretion of the city manager. A permit and inspection fee as specified in the fee schedule shall be paid at the time the application is filed. (c) All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city and hold the city harmless for any loss or damage to the public sewer system that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. (d) A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every property except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway. The front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city shall not be obligated or liable for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. (e) Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city manager, to meet all requirements of this division. (f) The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of building sewer, and the method to be used in construction shall conform to the requirements of the building, plumbing code and other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of ASTM, (American Society of Testing and Materials) and Water Environment Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. (g) Additionally, the following materials and methods shall apply to building sewers within the city: (1) The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe, ASTM (American Society of Testing and Materials) Specification A74, latest revision, or equal; ductile iron pipe, American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Specification A21.51, latest revision, or equal; or polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe, ASTM Specification D3034, latest revision. All joints shall be tight and waterproof. (2) Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe or ductile iron pipe with bolted mechanical joints. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that plastic pipe may be acceptable is laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle upon advance approval by the city manager. (3) The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the city manager, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot. Furthermore, the applicable requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety Act (OSHA) shall be followed. (4) The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost, and the building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and with straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. Building sewers shall not be placed in the same trench with water service lines. (5) An excavation required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the city manager. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM Specification C12, latest revision, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected and approved by the city manager. (6) All joints and connections shall be made gas tight and watertight. a. Push-on joints for cast iron soil pipe shall have neoprene gaskets in accordance with the requirements of ASTM C-564. b. Push-on joints for ductile iron pipe shall also have neoprene gaskets and be installed according to the manufacturer's recommendations. c. PVC pipe joint material shall be of the bell and spigot type, sealed with a rubber "O"-ring gasket, having a composition and texture which is resistant to the common ingredients of sewage, industrial wastes (including oils), and groundwater, and which will endure permanently under the conditions likely to be imposed by this use. Installation of gasket shall be done in accordance with the pipe manufacturer's instructions using all the necessary materials, lubricants, and equipment recommended by the manufacturer. d. Other jointing materials may be used only when approved by the city manager. (h) The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such a branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly located "Y" branch is available, the city shall, at the owner's expense, cut a neat hole into the public sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees, and install a 45-degree elbow with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at an elevation of at least 0.1 foot above the invert of the public sewer. A neat smooth joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the city manager. (i) Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be laid by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. (j) No person shall make connection of roof down spouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or a building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the city manager for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. (k) The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city manager when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the city manager. (l) All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. (m) From time to time by resolution approved by the city commission, the city will define the availability of sewers and establish costs, fees, and charges associated with sewer permits or construction. (n) The connection of the property sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building code, plumbing code and other applicable rules and regulations of the city or if the city has not adopted applicable codes, rules and regulations the procedure set forth in appropriate specifications of ASTM and the WEF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials are subject to approval by the city manager before installation. (o) If any private sewer permits the entrance of infiltration or inflow to the public sewer, the city may: (1) Require the owner to repair the private sewer; (2) Charge the owner a sewer rate that reflects the costs of the additional expense of sewage treatment from the owner's property; (3) Require the owner to disconnect his sewer from the city sewer system; or (4) Any combination of subsections (o)(1), (2) and (3) of this section. (Code 1977, § 32-116; Ord. No. 01-02, § 2, 1-16-2001) Sec. 40-96. - Restricted use of the public sewers. (a) A user may not introduce into any public sewer any pollutant which cause pass through or interference of the POTW. These general prohibitions and the specific prohibitions in subsection (d) of this section apply to each user introducing pollutants into the POTW whether or not the user is subject to other national pretreatment standards or any national, state, or local pretreatment requirements. (b) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. (c) Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated storm sewers or to a natural outlet. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process water may be discharged, upon approval of the state environmental protection division, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. (d) Specific prohibitions. Except as herein provided, no person shall discharge any of the following described waters or wastes into any public sewer: (1) Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed cup flash point of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit or 60 degrees Celsius using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. (2) Pollutants which will cause corrosive or structural damage to the POTW; but in no case discharges with pH lower than 5.0, or higher than 9.5. (3) Solids or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause obstruction to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference. (4) Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference with the POTW. (5) Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW resulting in interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that the temperature at the POTW plant influent exceeds 40 degrees Celsius or 104 degrees Fahrenheit. (6) Petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil that will cause interference or pass through at the POTW. (7) Pollutants which will result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in quantities that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance, capable of creating a public nuisance or preventing entry into sewers for their maintenance, inspection, and repair. (8) Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the POTW. (9) Any waters or wastes containing in excess of 1.0 milligram per liter of any of the following hazardous or dangerous gases: hydrogen sulfide, sulfur dioxide, or nitrous oxide. (10) Any nondomestic waters, wastes or materials containing toxic organic and inorganic priority pollutants, unless issued a written permit by the city manager which provides numerical limits on the quantity of such pollutants. Such limits will be calculated based on national pretreatment standards, local conditions of the POTW; and the presence of any pollutants causing pass through or interference with the POTW. (11) Any waters containing quantities of radium, naturally occurring or artificially produced radioisotopes in excess of presently existing or subsequently accepted limits for drinking water as established by the National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measuring. (12) Any concentrated dye wastes, or other wastes which are highly colored, and adversely affect the treated effluent of the POTW. (13) Detergents, surfactants, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW. (e) Local discharge limits. (1) Using EPA approved methodology the city has established local discharge limits for the pollutants of concern to the POTW. These limits are designed to protect the receiving stream, prevent interference with POTW operations and protect the quality of the sludge produced by the POTW. These limits apply to all users of the system. The local discharge limits for pollutants of concern are shown in the table below. Discharge limits for these and other pollutants by industrial customers will be determined individually based on specific pollutants identified in the wastewater discharge permit application and current loading rates. For industrial users subject to national categorical pretreatment standards, the local limit will be compared to the categorical limit and the lower value will be used. The city reserves the right to set higher discharge limits for individual industrial users provided that the following conditions apply: a. There are no other industrial users discharging the pollutant of concern or if there are other significant industrial users discharging the pollutant of concern they are discharging below the established limit; b. If any other significant industrial users are discharging the pollutant of concern they agree to accept a lower limit; and c. The total combined loading on the POTW will not exceed the established maximum head works loading. Pollutants of Concern
