No person other than the owner thereof, or an agent or employee of the city manager, or any employee of a person holding a contract with the city for collection of solid waste, shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storage of solid waste or recyclable materials pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where same shall have been placed by the owner thereof, unless permission to do so has been granted by the city manager or his designee. (Code 1977, § 13-3; Ord. No. 97-25, § 1, 8-19-1997; Ord. No. 98-27, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-1998; Ord. No. 06-12, § 1, 6-6-2006; Ord. No. 09-06, § 1, 9-15-2009) Sec. 40-136. - Collection. (a) Commercial and industrial limitations. No person shall contract for the collection, transportation or disposal of solid waste who does not possess a current license for such business operation in the city. Applications for licenses shall be written and shall be considered after evidence has been presented to show that the applicant has received a current permit, appropriate to the type of business concerned, as required under solid waste regulations of the state department of natural resources, pursuant to O.C.G.A. ch. 43-16. A license shall then be issued in accordance with criteria established by the city commission. Applicants shall pay the charge for the business license at the time of filing the application. (b) Persons with disabilities. The city will provide a special service for residents who have disabilities and are unable to push the roll-out container to the street on collection day provided that: (1) There are no other persons in the household who are able to roll the cart out; (2) A statement of disability from a doctor must be on file with the public works department. The disability form may be obtained from the public works department. (Code 1977, § 13-4; Ord. No. 97-25, § 1, 8-19-1997; Ord. No. 09-06, § 1, 9-15-2009) Sec. 40-137. - Deposit for roll-out containers. Every applicant for water or sewer service in the city, other than an owner of property, is hereby required to pay the city, at the time of such application, in addition to all other sums due to the city with such application, the greater of $50.00 or the amount equal to the purchase cost for one new 95-gallon roll-out container. Upon submitting such application, and payment of the said sums, the applicant will be issued a roll-out container with the serial number being kept on file with the city. Upon voluntary termination of such service, and payment of all sums due to the city, and upon return of the said roll-out container to the city in good condition, ordinary wear and tear excepted, the applicant shall be refunded the deposit fee. (Code 1977, § 13-7; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 6-20-2000) Sec. 40-138. - Return of roll-out container. Every utility customer of the city to whom, or for the benefit of whom a 95-gallon roll-out container has been issued, shall be responsible to return the said container to the city upon termination of utility service, in good condition, ordinary wear and tear excepted. If the customer fails or refused to return the container to the city, loses the container, or the same is damaged or destroyed, the customer shall be required to pay to the city the greater of the sum of $50.00 or the amount equal to the purchase cost of a new 95-gallon roll-out container. (Code 1977, § 13-8; Ord. No. 00-14, § 2, 6-20-2000) Sec. 40-139. - Special collection services for white or brown goods. (a) Applicants for the collection and the removal of white goods and brown goods above the weekly five-item limit shall first contact the public works department and make arrangements to pay the special collection fee established by the city, and based on the size of the load to be determined by the driver and supervisor, by agreeing to have the charges placed on the utility bill or by making payment in advance for such removal and pickup. Special collections shall be done only on Tuesdays and Fridays of each week. (b) Any person placing white goods or brown goods on the right-of-way for pickup without first having scheduled a pickup with the public works department shall be charged an amount as established by the city commission in addition to the costs for removal. (Code 1977, § 13-9; Ord. No. 00-14, § 3, 6-20-2000; Ord. No. 07-21, § 1, 12-4-2007) Sec. 40-140. - Yard trash pickup. All customers of the city water and/or sewer department shall be required to pay a monthly fee with the regular monthly utility bill for the collection of yard trash, in order to protect and guard the health, safety and sanitation of the citizens of the city. The monthly charge shall be established by the city commissioners from time to time. Upon the refusal of any such customer to pay the monthly fee for yard trash, the city may withhold water and/or sewer service and/or terminate such service. (Code 1977, § 13-10; Ord. No. 00-14, § 4, 6-20-2000) Sec. 40-141. - Unpaid charges constitutes a lien; disconnection of service lines. All charges payable by a person under the provisions of this article, which shall be and remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after the same become due and payable shall be and we are hereby declared a lien upon the lot or other tract of land owned by such person and to which such service is delivered or made available and shall be enforced in the same manner as are delinquent taxes by the issuance of execution. In addition to the enforcement remedy of issuing executions, the city clerk is hereby authorized to issue an order and to have the water connection which feeds the line cut off, as in the case of a delinquent water use. (Code 1977, § 13-10.1; Ord. No. 00-14, § 5, 6-20-2000) Secs. 40-142—40-165. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - GARBAGE AND REFUSE COLLECTION
Sec. 40-166. - Charges. The charges which shall be imposed for garbage and refuse collection by the city shall be as determined by the city commission from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. The failure of any person to accept or take advantage of the services of the sanitation department shall not relieve such person from the payment of such charges unless authorized by the city commission. The city shall bill each person for services rendered during the preceding month, which may be as a portion of the city's utility bill. (Code 1977, § 13-11; Ord. No. 99-14, § 1, 5-4-1999) Sec. 40-167. - Relief of collection charges. When a request for relief of charges levied by the city for garbage and refuse collection is made by the occupant of a single-family, multifamily, duplex or a detached commercial establishment, the relief shall be granted only to those units which have individual water meters and meet the following criteria: (1) The water service has been disconnected and the water meter removed. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Garbage means the following: (1) All household kitchen and business refuse, whether animal or vegetable; dead fowl or animals; all other decaying and decomposing substances, including animal feces. (2) Waste paper, cartons, cans, bottles, rags, glass, crockery and all other items which are commonly disposed of in waste receptacles. Refuse from demolished, renovated or newly constructed buildings. (4) Ashes and other refuse resulting from the burning of coal, wood or coke. (5) Discarded furniture and appliances. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or entity other than tenants or occupants of the premises on which garbage or refuse containers are stored, or the regularly authorized agents, employees or licensees of the city to disturb any refuse and containers or to remove their covers or any of the contents thereof, or to cause such garbage or refuse containers or their contents to be strewn or scattered on the lawns, sidewalks or streets. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or entity to strew, disturb or scatter garbage within the city, or to engage in scavenger activities within the city. (d) Any person, firm, corporation or entity found guilty of violating this section by the municipal court shall be punished as set forth in section 1-9. (Code 1977, § 13-13; Ord. No. 99-14, § 1, 5-4-1999) Secs. 40-169—40-189. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL SERVICE
Sec. 40-190. - Commercial waste service provider. All owners and occupants of commercial businesses receiving commercial solid waste dumpster collection and disposal services shall be required to utilize the services provided by the city's designated commercial waste service provider. (Ord. No. 13-02, § 1(13-14), 6-25-2013) Sec. 40-191. - Charges for services. No. 13-02, § 1(13-15), 6-25-2013) Sec. 40-192. - Administrative fee assessment. In addition to the charges imposed for garbage and refuse collection by the city for commercial dumpster customers as set forth in section 40-191, the city shall be authorized to add on a 15 percent administrative fee to cover its costs for all billing and collections procedures and activities. ARTICLE IV. - WATER[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 40-214. - Scope of provisions. All pertinent provisions of this article are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the city shall furnish any water service to any person; or whereby the city shall make any water connections or perform any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of any water service pursuant to the rules and regulations of the city commission. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(e), (m); Code 1977, § 36-1) Sec. 40-215. - Service to comply with technical provisions. Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this article shall be in accordance with and in compliance with all applicable technical provisions of this Code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations. (Code 1977, § 36-2) Sec. 40-216. - Right of entry. Any authorized inspector of the city shall have free access at any time to all premises supplied with any water service by the city for the purpose of examination in order to protect the water services from abusive use. (Code 1977, § 36-3) Sec. 40-217. - Termination of service authorized. The city shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect any water service for the following reasons: (1) Failure to meet the applicable provisions of law. (2) Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to water service. (3) Nonpayment of bills. (4) Willful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise. (5) Molesting any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of water service. (6) Theft or diversion and/or use of service without payment therefor. (7) Vacancy of premises. (Code 1977, § 36-4) Sec. 40-218. - Liability of city for damage. The city shall not be liable for any damage of any customer of any water service furnished by the city due to backflow of the sewerage system, failure of supply, interruption of service or any other cause outside the direct control of the city. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(i); Code 1977, § 36-4) Sec. 40-219. - Application for utility service required. Any person desiring any water service furnished by the city shall make application for the same to the city water department. Such application shall contain the applicant's name, address, the uses for which such service is desired and such other information as may be required. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(e); Code 1977, § 36-6) Sec. 40-220. - Damage, trespass of equipment. It shall be unlawful for any person, not having authority to do so, to open any water hydrant or tamper with any water service furnished by the city to consumers, or to in any other way molest, damage or trespass upon any equipment or premises belonging to the city connected with any water service. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(g); Code 1977, § 36-7) Sec. 40-221. - Temporary interruption of service. The city reserves the right to cut off any water service without notice in case of emergencies. When an interruption in service is necessary for the maintenance and improvement of the water system, affected customers shall be notified as circumstances permit. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(h); Code 1977, § 36-8) Sec. 40-222. - Water service not available to debtors. The city may decline or fail or cease to furnish water service to any person who may be in debt to the city for any reason. (Code 1977, § 36-9; Ord. No. 15-10 § 1(36-9), 7-7-2015) Sec. 40-223. - Sale of service by customer. It shall be unlawful for any person to resell any water service obtained from the city to others except only by special arrangement with the city commission. (Code 1952, ch. 25, §§ 1(b), 2(h); Code 1977, § 36-10) Sec. 40-224. - Connections to service. Connections for any water service furnished by the city shall be made only under the supervision of the water department. (Code 1977, § 36-11) Sec. 40-225. - Separate connections. Every building, structure or consumer in the city shall have a separate water service connection. (Code 1977, § 36-12) Sec. 40-226. - Unlawful connections. Any person who shall make any connection in any manner to the water system without the prior knowledge and consent of the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(g); Code 1977, § 36-13) Sec. 40-227. - Unlawful use. No person, other than employees of the city, shall be authorized to connect, turn on, turn off or disconnect any water service offered by the city, or remove, replace or repair any equipment connected to any such service. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(j); Code 1977, § 36-14) Secs. 40-228—40-247. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES Subdivision I. - In General
Sec. 40-248. - Deposits required. Along with the application for water service, the applicant therefor may be required to pay to the city a deposit in an amount equal to the charges for an average two-month period; provided, however, that in the event such service increases to a point where such deposit is not equal to the charges for an average two-month period, the required deposit may be increased to conform thereto. (Code 1977, § 36- 36; Ord. of 3-16-1971, § 3) Sec. 40-249. - Refund of deposit. Refunds of deposits made for water service shall be made upon the termination of such water service only after payment of all indebtedness to the city for such water service. Application of deposit may be made in partial or total settlement of accounts when supply is cut off for nonpayment of bill, or for any infraction or violation of any ordinance, rule or regulation of the city relative to water services offered by the city. (Code 1977, § 36-27) Sec. 40-250. - Effect of transfer, moving. There shall be no transfer, or so-called transfer, from one location to another of deposits made for water service and in each case, said transfer shall be considered a new application for service and shall be treated as such. When premises are vacated, any amounts due for water service shall be paid in full and water service shall not be commenced at another place until this is done. Such removal from one place to another shall be considered as a new request for water service and applicants shall be required to make the current deposit that shall be in effect at the time such request is made. (Code 1977, § 36-28) Sec. 40-251. - Determination of charges. The rates and charges for the consumption of water services furnished by the city, as well as the charges and fees for connection thereto, shall be as determined by the city commission from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 36-29; Ord. of 1-21-1958, § 3; Ord. of 3-16-1971, § 2) Sec. 40-252. - Use assumed. All premises connected to any water service of the city shall be assumed to be using such water service and the owner or occupant shall remain connected with the water service. (Code 1952, ch. 25, §§ 1(f), 2(d); Code 1977, § 36-30) Sec. 40-253. - When payment due. All bills for water services furnished by the city shall be due and payable prior to 12:00 midnight of the tenth day following the date of such bill; provided, however, that if such due date shall fall on a Sunday or legal holiday observed by the city, then such bill shall be due and payable by 12:00 midnight of the following business day. (Code 1952, ch. 25, §§ 1(c), 4(c); Code 1977, § 36-31) Sec. 40-254. - Disconnection for nonpayment. In the event bills for water services shall not be paid when the same become due, the city shall have the right to disconnect and discontinue all water services furnished by the city to the consumer so in arrears. (Code 1952, ch. 25, §§ 1(c), 4(b); Code 1977, § 36-32) Sec. 40-255. - Reconnection after disconnection; fee. When water service to any customer is disconnected, the same shall not be reconnected except upon payment of the amount due, and in addition thereto, any late fee, reconnection fee or padlock fee as determined by the city commission by resolution from time to time, and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1977, § 36-33; Ord. No. 78-7, § 1, 3-7-1978; Ord. No. 84-39, § 1, 12-18-1984) Sec. 40-256. - Owner of property liable. In the event the owner of the property upon which any building or structure is located shall lease said premises and the tenant and/or occupant applies for and places said water services in the name of the tenant and/or occupant and shall pay a deposit equal to two months' service, based on a six-usage-month average of prior service to said address (or any such other amount as determined by the city commission from time to time), then any unpaid charges shall be first deducted from said deposit and the tenant and/or occupant in whose name the water service has been connected shall be liable for any charges remaining unpaid. In the event the owner of any property upon which any building or structure is located leases said premises and retains water services in the name of said owner, then any unpaid charges for said services shall be the responsibility of the owner of said premises, said owner of the premises shall be deemed the user of such services and shall be liable for same. For purposes of this division, the term "lease" includes, but is not limited to, permitting occupancy of the building or structure whether or not said occupants pay for the occupancy through rent or otherwise. For purposes of this division, the term "owner-occupant" includes, but is not limited to, any person having any undivided or other ownership interest in and to the property. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(a); Code 1977, § 36-34; Ord. No. 92-7, § 1, 8-18-1992) Sec. 40-257. - Liens. All charges payable by a user of water service under the provisions of this division, which shall be and remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after the same become due and payable, shall be and are hereby declared a lien upon the lot or other tract of land owned by such user and to which such water service is delivered and shall be enforced in the same manner as are delinquent taxes by the issuance of executions. In addition to the enforcement remedy of issuing executions, the city clerk is hereby authorized to issue an order and to have the water connection which feeds the water line cut off. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 4(k); Code 1977, § 36-35; Ord. No. 91-07, § 1, 4-16-1991) Sec. 40-258. - Voluntary discontinuance of service. Consumers wishing to discontinue the use of water service shall give written notice thereof at the city hall. Failure to do so shall render them liable for the payment of all bills until such notice has been given. (Code 1977, § 36-36) Sec. 40-259. - Procedure for disconnection and reconnection. (a) Any past due amount of bill for water services in excess of $10.00 subjects the water services of the consumer to being disconnected and cut off 15 days after the due date. (b) Notice of disconnection and termination of water services will be sent on the consumer's water service bill and no additional notice is required to be sent. (c) All termination and cut-offs of water services will be handled on two days each month: Cycle 1 will have a termination and cutoff date of the 25th of the month and Cycle 2 will have a termination and cutoff date of the tenth of the month. (d) In the event water service is disconnected for any reason, water service will not be reconnected until all past due amounts are paid in full, including any and all user fees and other charges and taxes assessed upon the property, together with a disconnection fee as established by the city commission. (e) Upon payment of the past due balance, all past due amounts and disconnection fee, water service will be reconnected within a minimum of 24 hours absent any emergencies or exigent circumstances, and the city does not guarantee same day reconnection of water services. (Ord. No. 15-10, § 1(36-37), 7-7-2015) Secs. 40-260—40-281. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Meters
Sec. 40-282. - Furnished and installed by city. Meters for the measurement of water services furnished by the city shall be furnished and installed by, and shall remain the property of, the city. (Code 1952, ch. 25, §§ 2(g), 4(g); Code 1977, § 36-43) Sec. 40-283. - Maintenance. The cost of repairing and maintaining meters will be borne by the city, except when meters are damaged due to hot water backing into them, or due to carelessness on the part of the consumers, property owners or their agents, when the cost of such repairs will be billed to the property owner and if not paid within 30 days the city shall cut off the supply of water. Before water service is restored a reconnection fee as determined by the city commission from time to time, as well as all other charges due, shall be paid. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 2; Code 1977, § 36-44) Sec. 40-284. - Unfunctioning meter. If any meter should get out of order or for any reason fail to register and water is being used, the consumer will be billed at the average monthly consumption for the 12 months immediately preceding, as shown by meter when in order. Serviceable meters shall be installed as soon as practical. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 2(c); Code 1977, § 36-45) Sec. 40-285. - Access. If the city meter reader is unable to secure a reading of a meter after two calls, due to the building being locked, vacant, the occupant not permitting entrance to the premises or due to a vicious dog, or ingress to the meter is obstructed in any manner whatsoever, the water may be shut off by the city and an average bill as provided in section 40-284 rendered. In case water is cut off for any of the reasons provided in this section, it shall not be turned on again until free access to the meter is provided. (Code 1952, ch. 25, § 2(e); Code 1977, § 36-46) Secs. 40-286—40-303. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - WATER USE RESTRICTIONS
Sec. 40-304. - Authority to implement; levels of restriction. (a) At any time, and from time to time, the city commission is empowered to implement by resolution the following water use restrictions on water customers of the city water system, requiring compliance with the restrictions under the following levels and moving from one level to another or for such periods as conditions may reasonable require. The notification by the city's water supplier of a shortage and the need to implement water use restrictions, or the loss of adequate water supply to the city, or that one or more city water tanks become empty and shall be reported to the next city commission meeting, at which time the city commission may modify the restriction if it deems it appropriate. (b) Levels of restriction on use of water. (1) Level 1a: Voluntary restrictions. a. Be water use conscious. b. Weekends: No use of outside water. c. Weekdays: No use of outside water from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. d. Reduction of water use through education of public by press, radio, TV, direct mail, etc. e. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (2) Level 1b: Voluntary restrictions. a. Be water use conscious. b. Weekends: No use of outside water. c. Weekdays: No use of outside water from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. for anyone. No use of outside water at other times except on odd-numbered days by houses with odd-numbered addresses and on even-numbered days by houses with even-numbered addresses. d. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail, etc. e. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (3) Level 2: Mandatory restrictions. a. Be water use conscious. b. Weekends: No use of outside water. c. Weekdays: No use of outside water from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. d. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail, etc. e. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (4) Level 3a: Mandatory restrictions. a. Be water use conscious. b. Weekends and weekdays: No outside water from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. for anyone. c. No use of outside water at other times except odd-numbered days by houses with odd-numbered. d. Addresses and on even-numbered days by houses with even-numbered addresses. e. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail and etc. f. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (5) Level 3b: Mandatory restrictions. a. Be water use conscious. b. Weekends and weekdays: No outside water from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. for anyone. c. No use of outside water at other times except odd-numbered days by houses with odd-numbered. d. Addresses and on even-numbered days by houses with even-numbered addresses. e. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail and etc. f. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (6) Level 4: Mandatory restrictions. a. No use of outside water. b. Be water use conscious. c. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail and etc. d. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (7) Level 5: Mandatory restrictions. a. No use of outside water. b. Be water use conscious. c. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail and etc. d. Exemptions: Business uses, including golf course greens, and home flower and vegetable gardens. (8) Level 6: Mandatory restrictions. a. No use of outside water. b. Be water use conscious. c. Reduction of water use through education of public-by press, radio, TV, direct mail and etc. d. Exemptions: Essential health uses only. (c) Enforcement shall be by the city police personnel and water department personnel, and may consist of warnings, fines of not less than $100.00 to not more than $250.00 for each offense, or discontinuance of water service by removal of the water meter and payment of fines and reinstallation of meter charges of $100.00 or any combination of the foregoing. (d) This section shall apply to all city water customers regardless of whether or not they reside inside the city limits or their property served with city water is inside the city limits. All citations issued for violations shall be returnable to the municipal court. The city hereby delegates concurrent jurisdiction over such offenses to the county government within which the property served with city water lies if it is outside the city limits. If a citation is issued by county personnel for a violation of this section, it may also be returnable to the magistrate's court of the county where the property served lies. (e) The rules of the state department of natural resources environmental protection division, chapter 391-3-30, pertaining to outdoor water use, including sections 391-3-30-01 through 391-3-30-06, inclusive, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference as fully as if set forth verbatim herein. (Code 1977, § 36-60; Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 3-20-2001; Ord. No. 04-13, § 1, 7-20-2004) Sec. 40-305. - Outdoor uses during drought and non-drought periods. (a) Persons may irrigate outdoors daily for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. (b) Subsection (a) of this section shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: (1) Commercial agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; (2) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; (3) Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations adopted pursuant thereto; (4) Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the environmental protection division of the department to provide reclaimed wastewater; (5) Irrigation of personal food gardens; (6) Irrigation of new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; (7) Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; (8) Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; (9) Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; (10) Irrigation of horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; (11) Irrigation of athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; (12) Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or (13) Hydroseeding. (c) Any person guilty of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. Secs. 40-306—40-328. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - WATER SYSTEM BACKFLOW PREVENTION BY CONTAINMENT
Sec. 40-329. - Adoption. For the purpose of establishing uniform rules and regulations, the city commission hereby adopts the water system backflow prevention by containment policy and procedure ("policy and procedure") and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set forth at length herein, and from the date on which the ordinance from which this division shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling with respect to activities described therein, including, without limitation, to control and contain contaminants or pollutants from the city's water system and potable water supply system, and to provide protection against impurities, hazardous contaminants and nonhazardous pollutants. (Code 1977, § 15-81; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-330. - Abatement of violations. The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to abate any violation of the policy and procedure whether or not such violation is one specifically recognized by ordinance or not. (Code 1977, § 15-83; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-331. - Notice. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises or property which is in violation of said policy and procedure, and to demand the abatement of the violation within ten days of the notice. (Code 1977, § 15-84; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-332. - City may abate upon failure of person served notice to abate. If the person served by the notice issued pursuant to the provisions of this division does not abate the violation within the time set forth in the notice, the city may proceed to abate such violation. (Code 1977, § 15-85; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-333. - Recovery of cost or expense. Any cost or expense incurred by the city in the abatement of a violation pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be paid by the owner of the property involved, and the city shall have a lien against such property for all such costs or expense. (Code 1977, § 15-86; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-334. - Collection. In the event the owner or occupant of the property upon which a violation existed, which violation was abated by the city as provided in this division, the city clerk shall issue an execution against such property owner for the costs and expenses incurred by the city in such abatement, such execution to be signed by the city clerk and directed to the city manager or his designee as in the case of taxes due the city. (Code 1977, § 15-87; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Sec. 40-335. - Clerk to maintain copy of policy and procedure. The city clerk shall maintain a copy of the policy and procedure and make the same available for public inspection and review. (Code 1977, § 15-88; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 5-5-1998) Subpart B - LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE

div.head: Chapter 101 - GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 101-1. - Applicability of chapter 1. The provisions of chapter 1 of this Code apply to this subpart. Sec. 101-2. - Status. Subpart B of this part is a codification of ordinances pertaining to land development. Subpart A of this part is a codification of other ordinances. Failure to include an ordinance in this subpart that relates to land development does not excuse noncompliance with such ordinance. Inclusion of an ordinance in this subpart that does not pertain to land development does not excuse noncompliance with such ordinance. Inclusion of an ordinance in subpart A of this part that pertains to land development does not excuse noncompliance with such ordinance. Secs. 101-3—101-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Zoning, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; planning, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 101-23. - Effect on existing planning and zoning authorization. (a) The ordinance from which this article is derived shall become effective upon its adoption by the city commission. All powers and authority granted by this article to the city planning department and city-county planning commission and city board of zoning appeals shall be cumulative. (b) Any ordinance of the city commission heretofore legally enacted under the authority of any state statute or constitutional provision shall remain in force and effect after the ordinance from which this article is derived becomes effective until the city commission has brought such ordinance into conformity with the provisions of this article. Provided, however, that after the ordinance from which this article is derived becomes effective, such ordinance shall be administered under the provisions of this article and any amendment to any such ordinance shall be made under the provisions of this article. Any reference in the existing zoning and subdivision ordinances to the "Waycross Planning Commission" is hereby amended to read "Waycross-Ware County Planning Commission." (Code 1977, § 25-16; Ord. No. 82-17, § 7, 7-20-1982) Secs. 101-24—101-49. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CITY PLANNING DEPARTMENT
Sec. 101-50. - Creation and direction. The city commission does hereby create and establish the department of planning for the city. A planning director shall be responsible for supervising and administering the affairs of the planning department. The director shall be appointed by the city manager and confirmed by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 25-22; Ord. No. 82-17, § 1, 7-20-1982) Sec. 101-51. - Principal powers and duties. It shall be the function and duty of the planning department to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity or the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the development of incorporated Waycross. In particular, the planning department shall have the power and duties to: (1) Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city commission, after consideration and recommendation by the city-county planning commission, a comprehensive plan or parts thereof for the development of incorporated Waycross. (2) Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city commission, after consideration and recommendation by the city-county planning commission, a zoning ordinance and zoning maps for incorporated Waycross. (3) Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city commission, after consideration and recommendation by the city-county planning commission, regulations for the subdivision of land within incorporated Waycross, and to aid in administering the regulations that may be adopted. (4) Perform such other planning functions and duties as may be required by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 25-23; Ord. No. 82-17, § 2, 7-20-1982) Sec. 101-52. - Plans, reports and recommendations; additional powers. The city planning department may make, publish and distribute maps, plans and reports and recommendations relating to the plan and development of incorporated Waycross to public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, education, professional and other organizations and citizens. It may recommend to the city commission programs for public improvements and the financing thereof. All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the planning department, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. In general, the planning department shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote the planning of incorporated Waycross. (Code 1977, § 25-24; Ord. No. 82-17, § 3, 7-20-1982) Secs. 101-53—101-77. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CITY-COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION
Sec. 101-78. - Creation; appointment of members. (a) Established; composition. There is hereby established the city-county planning commission which shall consist of nine members. The members appointed by the city commission shall be residents of the city and the members appointed by the county board of commissioners shall be residents of unincorporated Ware County. (b) Terms; vacancy. The term of each member shall be three years and appointments shall rotate so that a majority of five members will alternate each year between the two governing bodies. In the event a vacancy occurs, such vacancy shall be filled by the respective governing body for the unexpired term. (Code 1977, § 25-30; Ord. No. 82-17, § 4, 7-20-1982) Sec. 101-79. - Organization; rules; staff; officers. One member of the city-county planning commission elected by the members of the city-county planning commission shall serve as chairman of the planning commission for a term of one year or until his successor is elected. The city-county planning commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman or at such other times as the planning commission may determine, shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be public record. The county planning director will serve as the secretary of the city-county planning commission. (Code 1977, § 25-31; Ord. No. 82-17, § 5, 7-20-1982) Sec. 101-80. - Powers and duties. It shall be the function and duty of the city-county planning commission to consider and otherwise review and comment on all comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and all plans for physical, social and economic growth prepared by the city planning department. In particular, the planning commission shall have the power and duty to review, comment and make recommendations on: (1) Comprehensive plan or parts thereof for the development of incorporated Waycross; (2) Zoning ordinance and zoning maps for incorporated Waycross; (3) Regulations for the subdivision of land within incorporated Waycross, and to aid in administering the regulations that may be adopted. The city commission may refer any matter or class of matters to the city-county planning commission, serving incorporated Waycross, before final action thereon by the city commission. (Code 1977, § 25-32; Ord. No. 82-17, § 6, 7-20-1982)

div.head: Chapter 103 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Building codes generally, O.C.G.A. title 8, ch. 2; telecommunications towers, O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 66B.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 103-1—103-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 103-19. - Scope; purpose; applicability. (a) Scope. The provisions of this section shall govern the administration and enforcement of the minimum standards codes, hereinafter referred to as the "technical codes," which have been adopted by the city, and the city has elected to enforce, and such other codes that the city has adopted or may hereafter adopt. (b) Code remedial. (1) General. These technical codes are hereby declared to be remedial, and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health, and general welfare through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and other hazards attributed to the built environment, including without limitation alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use and occupancy of buildings, structures, or premises, and by regulating the installation and maintenance of all electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems, which may be referred to as service systems. (2) Quality control. Quality control of materials and workmanship is not within the purview of these technical codes nor this chapter except as such quality control relates to the purposes stated herein. (3) Permitting and inspection. The inspection or permitting of any building, system, or plan, under the requirements of these codes, shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building, system or plan or their adequacy. Neither the city nor any employee thereof shall be liable in tort or otherwise for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building, system, or plan, nor for any failure of any component of such, which may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting. (c) Applicability. (1) General. Where, in any specific case, different sections of these technical codes specify different materials, methods of construction, or other requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. Where there is a conflict between a general requirement and a specific requirement, the specific requirement shall be applicable. (2) Federal and state authority. The provisions of these technical codes shall not be held to deprive any federal or state agency, or any applicable governing authority having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of these codes or of any remedy then existing for the enforcement of its orders, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law. (3) Maintenance. All buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems, both existing and new, and all parts thereof, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All devices or safeguards which are required by the technical codes when constructed, altered, or repaired shall be maintained in good working order. The owner or his designated agent, shall be responsible for the maintenance of buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems. (d) Compliance . It is unlawful for any person to engage in the construction or erection of any building, whether commercial, business or residential unless such construction is accomplished in strict compliance with the various construction codes adopted by this chapter. (Code 1977, § 7-101; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. 97-05, §§ 1B, C, 2-4-1997) Sec. 103-20. - Building department. (a) Establishment. There is hereby established an office commonly referred to as the building department which is operated within the department of community improvement, and the person in charge shall be known as the building and code manager. The inspectors in this department are sometimes referred to herein as building officials. (b) Employee qualifications. The qualifications for all code enforcement personnel shall be established by the personnel policies of the city. (c) Restrictions on employees. An officer or employee connected with the department, except one whose only connection is as a member of the board established by these codes, shall not be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material, or appliances for the construction, alteration, or maintenance of a building, structure, service, system, or in the making of plans or of specifications thereof, unless he is the owner of such. This officer or employee shall not engage in any other work which is inconsistent with his duties or conflict with the interests of the department. (d) Records. The building and code manager shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of the department. The records of the department shall be open to public inspection, consistent with applicable state law. (e) Liability. Any officer or employee, or member of the construction board, charged with the enforcement of the codes, acting for the applicable governing authority in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself personally liable, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability, for any damage that may occur to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit claim brought against any officer or employee or member because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of the codes shall be defended by the legal representative of the governing authority until the final termination of the proceedings. (f) Reports. The building and code manager shall submit annually a report covering the work of the building department during the preceding year, and may incorporate in said report a summary of the decisions of the construction board during said year. (Code 1977, § 7-102; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996) Sec. 103-21. - Existing buildings. (a) General. Alterations, repairs, or rehabilitation work may be made to any existing building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system without requiring the building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system to comply with all the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. The building and code manager shall determine or cause to be determined the extent to which the existing system shall be made to conform to the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. One factor used to determine the extent to which the existing system shall be made to conform shall be whether or not the cost of repairs, alterations and rehabilitative work exceeds 50 percent of the value (100 percent) used by Ware County or Pierce County, whichever applies, for ad valorem tax purposes. (b) Change of occupancy. If the occupancy classification of any existing building or structure is changed, the building, electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems shall be made to conform to the intent of the technical codes as required by the authorized building and code manager. (c) Special historic buildings. The provisions of the technical codes relating to the construction, alteration, repair, enlargement, restoration, relocation, or moving of buildings or structures shall not be mandatory for existing buildings or structures identified and classified by the state or local jurisdiction as historic buildings when such buildings or structures are judged by the building officials to be safe and in the public interest of health, safety, and welfare regarding any proposed construction, alteration, repair, enlargement, restoration, relocation, or moving buildings. (Code 1977, § 7-103; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. O17-05 , § 1, 4-4-2017) Sec. 103-22. - Licensure required; exception for homeowner. (a) Any person, before engaging in the work of contracting shall be licensed by the state examining board or licensed by the city or employed and supervised by such person with approved licenses. (b) This shall not prevent the homeowner from doing minor repairs and maintenance within his own property boundaries, providing such maintenance work is done by the homeowner and is used exclusively by homeowner or his immediate family. Such privilege does not convey the right to violate any provisions of this Code. (Code 1977, § 11-16; Ord. No. 86-11, § 1, 2-18-1986) Sec. 103-23. - Powers and duties of the building and code manager. (a) General. The building and code manager serves as the building official and is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of the technical codes and to render interpretations of the technical codes, which are consistent with its intent and purpose. The building officials (inspectors) are directed by the building and code manager to enforce provisions and to render interpretations of the technical codes. (b) Right of entry. (1) Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of these codes, or whenever the building and code manager has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any condition or code violation which makes such building, structure, premises, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems unsafe, dangerous, or hazardous, the building and code manager may enter or cause to be entered such building, structure, or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the building and code manager by these technical codes, provided that if such building or premises is occupied, they shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such building, structure, or premises is unoccupied, they shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of such and request entry. If entry is refused, the building and code manager shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. (2) When the building and code manager shall have first obtained a proper inspection warrant or other remedy provided by law to secure entry, no owner or occupant or any other persons having charge, care, or control of any building, structure, or premises shall fail or neglect, after proper request is made as herein provided, to promptly permit entry therein by the building and code manager for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to these codes. (c) Stop work orders. Upon notice from the building and code manager, work on any building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system that is being done contrary to the provisions of the technical codes or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, the building and code manager shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. (d) Revocation of permits. (1) Misrepresentation of application. The building and code manager may revoke a permit approval, issued under the provisions of these codes, in case there has been any false statements or misrepresentation as to the material fact or the construction fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. (2) Violation of code provisions. The building and code manager may revoke a permit upon determination that the construction, erection, alteration, repair, moving, demolition, installation or replacement of the building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems for which the permit was issued is in violation of, or not in conformity with, the provisions of these codes. (e) Unsafe buildings or systems. All buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems which are unsafe, unsanitary, or do not provide adequate egress, or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use, constitute a hazard to safety or health, are considered unsafe buildings or service systems. All such unsafe buildings, structures, or service systems are hereby declared illegal and shall be abated by repair and rehabilitation or by demolition in accordance with the provisions of the adopted International Property Maintenance Code. (f) Requirements not covered by codes. Any requirements necessary for the strength, stability, or proper operation of an existing or proposed building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system, or for the public safety, health, and general welfare, not specifically covered by the technical codes, shall be determined by the building and code manager. (g) Alternative materials and methods. The provisions of the technical codes are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by them, provided any such alternate has been reviewed by the building and code manager. He shall approve any such alternate, provided he finds that the alternate for the purpose intended is at least the equivalent of that prescribed in the technical codes, in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire resistance, durability, and safety. The building and code manager shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claim made regarding the alternate. (Code 1977, § 7-104; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. 08-38, § 1, 11-4-2008) Sec. 103-24. - Permits. (a) Permit application. (1) When required; exception. a. When required. Any owner, authorized agent, or contractor who desires to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of a building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert, or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system, the installation of which is regulated by the technical codes, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the building department and obtain the required permit for the work. b. Exception. Permits shall not be required for the following mechanical work: 1. Any portable heating appliance: 2. Any portable ventilation equipment; 3. Any portable cooling unit; 4. Any steam, hot, or chilled water piping within any heating or cooling equipment regulated by the code; 5. Replacement of any part which does not alter its approval or make it unsafe; 6. Any portable evaporative cooler; 7. Any self-contained refrigeration system containing ten pounds (4.54 kg) or less of refrigerant and actuated by motors of one horsepower (746 W) or less. (2) Temporary structures. A special building permit for a limited time shall be obtained before the erection of temporary structures such as construction sheds, seats, canopies, tents, and fences used in construction work or for temporary purposes such as reviewing stands. Such structures shall be completely removed upon the expiration of the time limit stated in the permit. (3) Work authorized. A building, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing permit shall carry with it the right to construct or install the work, provided the same are shown on the drawings and set forth in the specifications filed with the application for the permit. (4) Minor repairs. Ordinary minor repairs may be made with the approval of the building and code manager without a permit, provided that such repairs shall not violate any of the provisions of the technical codes. Minor repairs are defined as repairs which in the aggregate cost less than $1,000.00 if no inspections are required by the building and code manager. (5) Information required. Each application for a permit, with the required fee, shall be filed with the building department on a form furnished for that purpose, and shall contain a general description of the proposed work and its location. The application shall be signed by the owner, or his authorized agent. The building permit application shall indicate the proposed occupancy of all parts of the building and of that portion of the site or lot, if any, not covered by the building or structure, and shall contain such other information as may be required by the building and code manager. (6) Mail application process for certain permits. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-29, in addition to applying in person for a heating, ventilation, air conditioning, plumbing or electrical permit, an applicant can apply for such permit by mail, which application shall include payment for any fees as established by the city in accordance with state law. (7) Time limitations. An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned six months after the date of filing for the permit, unless before then a permit has been issued. One or more extensions of time for periods of not more than 60 days each may be allowed by the building and code manager for the application, provided the extension is requested in writing and justifiable cause is demonstrated. (b) Drawing and specifications. (1) Requirements. When required by the building and code manager, two or more copies of specifications, and of drawings drawn to scale with sufficient clarity and detail to indicate the nature and character of the work, shall accompany the application for a permit. Such drawings and specifications shall contain information, in the form of notes or otherwise, as to the quality of materials, where quality is essential to conformity with the technical codes. Such information shall be specific, and the technical codes shall not be cited as a whole or in part, nor shall the term "legal" or its equivalent be used, as a substitute for specific information. All information, drawings, specifications, and accompanying data shall bear the name and signature of the person responsible for the design. (2) Additional data. The building officials may require details, computations, stress diagrams, and other data necessary to describe the construction or installation and the basis of calculations. All drawings, specifications, and accompanying data required by the building officials to be prepared by an architect or engineer shall be affixed with their official seal. (3) Design professional. The design professional shall be an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of the state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering and shall affix his official seal to said drawings; specifications, and accompanying data, for the following: a. All Group A, E, and I occupancies. b. Buildings and structures three stories or more high. c. Buildings and structures 5,000 square feet (465 m 2 ) or more in area. For all other buildings and structures, the submittal shall bear the certification of the applicant that some specific state law exception permits its preparation by a person not so registered. (4) Structural and fire resistance integrity. Plans for all buildings shall indicate how required structural and fire resistance integrity will be maintained where a penetration of a required fire resistance wall, floor, or partition will be made for electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing, signal, and communication conduits, pipes, and systems and also indicate in sufficient detail how the fire integrity will be maintained where required fire resistance floors intersect the exterior walls. (5) Site drawings. Drawings shall show the location of the proposed building or structure and of every existing building or structure on the site or lot. The building and code manager may require a boundary line survey prepared by a qualified surveyor. (6) Hazardous occupancies. The building and code manager may require the following: a. General site plan. A general site plan drawn at a legible scale which shall include, but not be limited to, the location of all buildings, exterior storage facilities, permanent access ways, evacuation routes, parking lots, internal roads, chemical loading areas, equipment cleaning areas, storm and sanitary sewer accesses, emergency equipment and adjacent property uses. The exterior storage areas shall be identified with the hazard classes and the maximum quantities per hazard class of hazardous materials stored. b. Building floor plan. A building floor plan drawn to a legible scale which shall include, but not be limited to, all hazardous materials storage facilities within the building and shall indicate rooms, doorways, corridors, exits, fire rated assemblies with their hourly rating, location of liquid tight rooms, and evacuation routes. Each hazardous materials storage facility shall be identified on the plan with the hazard classes and quantity range per hazard class or the hazardous materials stored. (c) Examination of documents. (1) Plan review. The building officials shall examine each application for a permit and the accompanying documents, consisting of drawings, specifications, computations, and additional data, and shall ascertain by such examinations whether the construction indicated and described is in accordance with the requirements of the technical codes and all other pertinent laws or ordinances. (2) Affidavits. The building and code manager may accept a sworn affidavit from a registered architect or engineer stating that the plans submitted conform to the technical codes. For buildings and structures the affidavit shall state that the plans conform to the laws as to egress, type of construction, and general arrangement and, if accompanied by drawings, show the structural design, and by a statement that the plans and design conform to the requirements of the technical codes as to strength, stresses, strains, loads, and stability. The building and code manager may without any examination or inspection accept such affidavit, provided the architect or engineer who made such affidavit agrees to submit to the building and code manager, copies of inspection reports as inspections are performed and upon completion of the structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems a certification that the structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system has been erected in accordance with the requirements of the technical codes. Where the building and code manager relies upon such affidavit, the architect or engineer shall assume full responsibility for the compliance with all provisions of the technical codes and other pertinent laws or ordinances. (d) Issuing permits. (1) Action on permits. Building officials shall act upon an application for a permit without reasonable or unnecessary delay. If the officials are satisfied that the work described in the application for a permit and the contract documents filed therewith conform to the requirements of the technical codes and other pertinent laws and ordinances, a permit shall be issued to the applicant. (2) Refusal to issue permit. If the application for a permit and the accompanying contract documents describing the work do not conform to the requirements of the technical codes or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the building and code manager shall not issue a permit, but shall return the contract documents to the applicant with the refusal to issue such permit. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reason for refusal. (3) Special foundation permit. When application for permit to erect or enlarge a building has been filed and pending issuance of such permit, the building and code manager, may at his discretion, issue a special permit for the foundation only. The holder of such a special permit is proceeding at his own risk and without assurance that a permit for the remainder of the work will be granted nor that corrections will not be required in order to meet provisions of the technical codes. (4) Public right-of-way. A permit shall not be given by the building and code manager for the construction of any building, or for the alteration of any building where said building is to be changed and such change will affect the exterior walls, bays, balconies, or other appendages or projections fronting on any street, alley, or public lane, or for the placing on any lot or premises of any building or structure removed from another lot or premises, unless the applicant has made application to the office of the city engineer and/or director of public works for the lines of the public street on which he proposes to build, erect, or locate said building; and it shall be the duty of the building and code manager to see that the street lines are not encroached upon except as provided for in the adopted minimum standards codes. (e) Contractor's responsibilities. It shall be the duty of every contractor who shall make contracts for the installation or repairs of building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, sprinkler, or plumbing systems, for which a permit is required, to comply with the state or local rules and regulations concerning licensing which the applicable governing authority may have adopted. In such case that the state requires a contractor to have obtained a state license before they are permitted to perform work, the contractor shall supply the local government with their license number before receiving a permit for work to be performed. (f) Conditions of permit. (1) Permit intent. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with the work and not as authority to violate, cancel, alter, or set aside any of the provisions of the technical codes, nor shall issuance of a permit prevent the building and code manager from thereafter requiring a correction of errors in plans, construction, or violations of the codes. Every permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within six months after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time the work is commenced. One or more extensions of time, for periods not more than 60 days each, may be allowed for the permit. The extension shall be requested in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated. Extensions shall be in writing by the building and code manager. (2) Permit issued on basis of an affidavit. Whenever a permit is issued in reliance upon an affidavit or whenever the work to be covered by a permit involves installation under conditions which, in the opinion of the building and code manager, are hazardous or complex, the building and code manager shall require that computations shall supervise such work. In addition, they shall be responsible for conformity with the permit, provide copies of inspection reports as inspections are performed, and upon completion make and file with the building and code manager written affidavit that the work has been done in conformity with the reviewed plans and with the structural provisions of the technical codes. In the event such architect or engineer is not available, the owner shall employ in his stead a competent person or agency whose qualifications are reviewed by the building and code manager. (3) Plans. When permits are issued, both sets of plans shall be endorsed in writing or by stamp "Reviewed for Code Compliance." One set of drawings so reviewed shall be retained by the building department and the other set shall be returned to the applicant. The permit drawings shall be kept at the site of work and shall be open to inspection by the building officials. (g) Fees. (1) Prescribed fees. A permit shall not be issued until the fees prescribed by the city commission have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be issued until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building, structure, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, or gas system, etc., has been paid. (2) Work commencing before permit issuance. Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing, etc., system before obtaining the necessary permits, shall be subject to a penalty of 100 percent of the usual permit fee in addition to the required permit fees. (3) Accounting. The building and code manager shall keep a permanent and accurate accounting of all permit fees and other monies collected, the names of all persons upon whose account the same was paid, along with the date and amount thereof. (4) Schedule of permit fees. On all buildings, structures, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, and gas systems or alterations requiring a permit, a fee for each permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing application, in accordance with the fee schedules as set by the city commission. (5) Building permit valuations. If, in the opinion of the building and code manager, the valuation of building, alteration, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems appears to be underestimated on the application, permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimates to meet the approval of the building and code manager; or if the applicant agrees to the valuation based on reasonable and acceptable square footage rates for the type of work to be performed. Permit valuations shall include total cost, such as electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing equipment, and other systems, including materials and labor. (Code 1977, § 7-105; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. 97-05, § 1D, 2-4-1997) Sec. 103-25. - Concealment of work. It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal or cause to be concealed, in such manner that the inspector cannot satisfy himself that the provisions of this chapter have been complied with, any work until after the work has been inspected and approved by the inspector. (Code 1977, § 11-38) Sec. 103-26. - Inspections. (a) Existing building inspections. Before issuing a permit, the building and code manager or his designee may examine or cause to be examined any building, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems for which an application has been received for a permit to enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, install, or change the occupancy. All buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems shall be inspected from time to time, during and upon completion of the work for which a permit was issued. The building and code manager or his designee shall make a record of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical codes. (b) Manufacturers and fabricators. When deemed necessary by the building officials, an inspection of materials or assemblies at the point of manufacture or fabrication may be made. A record shall be made of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical codes. (c) Inspection service. The building and code manager may make, or cause to be made, the inspections required by subsection (f) of this section. Reports may be accepted of inspectors of recognized inspection services provided that after investigation, their qualifications and reliability are satisfactory. A certificate called for by any provision of the technical codes shall not be based on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such service. (d) Inspections prior to issuance of certificate of occupancy or completion. The building officials shall inspect at various intervals all construction or work for which a permit is required, and a final inspection shall be made of every building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system upon completion, prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or completion. (e) Posting of permit. Work requiring a permit shall not commence until the permit holder or his agent posts the permit card in a conspicuous place on the premises. The permit card shall be protected from the weather and located in such position as to permit the building officials to conveniently make the required entries thereon. This permit card shall be maintained in such position by the permit holder until the certificate of occupancy or completion is issued. (f) Required inspections. Upon notification from the permit holder or his agent, the following inspections and such other inspections as necessary, shall be made by the building officials and they shall either release that portion of the construction or shall notify the permit holder or his agent of any violations which must be corrected in order to comply with the technical codes: (1) Building. a. Foundation inspection. To be made after trenches are excavated and forms erected. b. Frame inspection. To be made after the roof, all framing, fireblocking, and bracing have been so concealed, and before any fixtures or gas appliances have been connected. This inspection shall include a pressure test. c. Final inspection. To be made on all new gas work authorized by the permit and such portions of existing systems as may be affected by new work or any changes, to ensure compliance with all the requirements of this Code and to assure that the installation and construction of the gas system is in accordance with reviewed plans. (2) Energy. a. Foundation inspection. To be made before slab concrete is poured in place. To verify float perimeter insulation has been installed correctly on any slab on grade foundations. b. Frame inspection. To be made before exterior wall insulation is concealed by wall board to check installation of exterior walls insulation and to inspect that all holes and cracks through the structure envelope have been sealed in an appropriate manner as to restrict air passage. c. Final inspection. To be made after the building is completed and ready for occupancy. To verify installation and R-value of ceiling and floor insulation. To verify correct SEER ratings on appliances. (g) Written release. Work shall not be done on any part of a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining a written release from the building officials. Such written release shall be given only after an inspection has been made of each successive step in the construction or installation as indicated by each of the foregoing three inspections. (h) Reinforcing steel, structural frames, insulation, plumbing, mechanical, or electrical systems. Reinforcing steel or structural frame work of any part of any building or structure shall not be covered or concealed without first obtaining a release from the building officials. (i) Plaster fire protection. In all buildings where plaster is used for fire protection purposes, the permit holder or his agent shall notify the building department after all lathing and backing is in place. Plaster shall not be applied until the release has been received from the building officials. (j) Building and mobile home vacancy permits and inspections required. The owner or renter shall be required to obtain a vacancy permit and inspection for any building or mobile home that has not had power and/or water supplied to the building or mobile home for a period of six months or more before the power and/or water can be supplied to the mobile home or building. Once the owner or renter has obtained the vacancy permit, the city building department shall, at the owner's or renter's request, schedule an inspection of the existing conditions of the mobile home or building to ensure compliance with all current technical codes and any other city codes and ordinances. (Code 1977, § 7-106; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. 16-06 , § 1, 4-5-2016) Sec. 103-27. - Certificates. (a) Certificate of occupancy. (1) Building occupancy. A new building shall not be occupied or a change made in the occupancy, nature or use of a building or part of a building until after the building and code manager has issued a certificate of occupancy. Said certificate shall not be issued until all required electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing, and fire protection systems have been inspected for compliance with the technical codes and other applicable laws and ordinances and released by the building officials. (2) Issuing certificate of occupancy. Upon satisfactory completion of construction of a building or structure and installation of electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing systems in accordance with the technical codes, reviewed plans and specifications, and after the final inspection, the building and code manager shall issue a certificate of occupancy stating the nature of the occupancy permitted, the number of persons for each floor when limited by law, and the allowable load per square foot for each floor in accordance with the provisions of the technical codes. (3) Temporary/partial occupancy. A temporary/partial certificate of occupancy may be issued for a portion of a building which may safely be occupied prior to final completion of the building. (4) Existing building certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy for any existing building may be obtained by applying to the building department and supplying information and data necessary to determine compliance with the technical codes for the occupancy intended. Where necessary, two sets of detailed drawings, or a general inspection, or both, may be required. When, upon examination and inspection, it is found that the building conforms to the provisions of the technical codes and other applicable laws and ordinances for such occupancy, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued. (b) Certificate of completion. Upon satisfactory completion of a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system, a certificate of completion may be issued. This certificate is proof that a structure or system is complete and for certain types of permits is released for use and may be connected to a utility system. This certificate does not grant authority to occupy or connect a building, such as a shell building, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (c) Service utilities. (1) Connection of service utilities. No person shall make connections from a utility, source of energy, fuel or power to any building or system which is regulated by the technical codes for which a permit is required, until released by the building officials and a certificate of occupancy or completion is issued. (2) Temporary connection. The building and code manager may authorize the temporary connection of the building or system to the utility source of energy, fuel, or power for the purpose of testing building service systems or for use under a temporary certificate of occupancy. (3) Authority to disconnect service utilities. The building and code manager shall have the authority to authorize disconnection of utility service to the building, structure, or system regulated by the technical codes, in case of emergency where necessary to eliminate an immediate hazard to life or property. The building and code manager shall notify the serving utility, and whenever possible the owner and occupant of the building, structure, or service system of the decision to disconnect prior to taking such action.
