Development means the act of building or installing structures and/or installing site improvements. Easement means a grant by a property owner for the use for a specific purpose (or purposes) of a piece of land by the general public, a corporation, or a person. Lot means a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land, intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for building development. Mobile home means a movable dwelling unit so designed and constructed that it may be readily transported on its own chassis along the public streets and highways. Mobile home park means a parcel of land under single management which has been planned and improved for the rental or lease of lots and the provisions of services for mobile homes for transient and/or non-transient use. Mobile home subdivision means a parcel of land developed under single ownership where lots are sold for the use of mobile homes and where such services as water, sewage, recreational facilities, and laundry facilities may be provided by management for a service charge. Planning commission refers to the Waycross-Ware County Planning Commission, as established by the city and county governments in accordance with Georgia General Act No. 358, 1957, as amended. Public way means any piece of land over which the general public has a right of usage, whether acquired through prescription, by adverse use of the general public, or otherwise. Street means a public way dedicated to and accepted by a governing body for the use of vehicular and pedestrian traffic by the general public and may be designated as a street, highway, parkway, road, avenue, drive, boulevard, lane, place, etc. (1) Arterial is a street designed for rapid, continuous movement of all types of traffic but with less control over the access points from streets and adjacent property than controlled access thoroughfares. (2) Connector street is one designed for uninterrupted movement of traffic at moderate speeds, with some control over access from adjoining areas. (3) Controlled access thoroughfare is a street designed for fast, continuous movement of all types of traffic, with control over access to abutting property and the spacing of street intersections. (4) Cul-de-sac is a service street having one end open to traffic, with the other end permanently terminated by a turnaround. (5) Marginal access street is generally parallel and adjacent to controlled access thoroughfares, arterials, or connector streets, for the purpose of providing access to abutting properties and of separating high speed from local traffic. (6) Service street is one which is intended to provide direct access to abutting property. (7) Local access street is a low volume service street in residential subdivisions with off-street parking. Subdivider means a person, firm, corporation, or association undertaking the process of subdivision of a lot, tract, or parcel of land for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development, whether immediate or future. Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract, or parcel of land into two or more lots or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or in the future, of transfer of ownership or for development and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included in this definition: (1) The subdivision of land for agriculture, horticultural, or forestry purposes, provided no lot produced is less than five acres and no new street is involved. (2) The combination or recombination of previously platted adjoining lots or portions thereof where the resultant lots comply with the minimum standards of lot dimension and lot area required under applicable laws and no new street is involved. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § I(E); Ord. No. 08-04, § 1, 2-19-2008) Secs. 113-5—113-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 113-27. - Filing and inspection fee. The subdivider shall be assessed a fee as established by the city commission plus an additional amount per residential lot or other parcel payable to the secretary of the planning commission, to help defray the cost to the agencies of local government in reviewing preliminary and final plats and in inspecting the installation of improvements. Such fee must be tendered prior to application for preliminary plat approval. Payment of such fee does not relieve the subdivider of the full responsibility for providing supervision for the installation of improvements nor limit his responsibility for full compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VII(A); Ord. No. 93-06, § 6, 4-20-1993) Sec. 113-28. - Remission and apportionment of fees. The secretary of the planning commission shall remit fees collected under section 113-27 to the city at such time and in such manner as may be prescribed by the chief administrator of the city. The city shall receive the entire filing and inspection fee where the subdivision lies wholly within the city limits. Where the city limits passes through a residential subdivision, the fee shall be apportioned to the city and county in direct proportion to the number of residential lots or portions thereof lying within the respective jurisdiction, each portion of a lot to be counted as a whole lot and to be counted only for that jurisdiction within which one-half or more (in area) of it lies. In the case of a group housing development, a shopping center, or any other subdivision not having normal size residential lots and through which city limits passes, the fee to the city and to county shall be in direct proportion to the gross acreage lying within the respective jurisdiction. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VII(B); Ord. No. 93-06, § 6, 4-20-1993) Secs. 113-29—113-59. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - VARIANCES
Sec. 113-60. - Conditions required. (a) The planning commission may vary the provisions of this chapter where all the following conditions exist: (1) There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property; (2) The literal interpretation of this chapter would make impossible a reasonable and acceptable development of the property in question and thus cause unusual and unnecessary hardship to the subdivider; and (3) The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare and not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this chapter. (b) In granting a variance, the planning commission may require compliance with such conditions as necessary to secure conformity with subsection (a)(3) of this section. The variance, with any conditions upon it is contingent and with the reasons upon which it is based, shall be recorded in the minutes of the planning commission. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § V) Secs. 113-61—113-78. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 113-79. - No subdivision of land prior to plat approval. The owner or agent of any land to be subdivided within the jurisdiction of this chapter who transfers or sells or agrees to sell or negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat of subdivision of such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county (with respect to lands within the corporate limits of the city, situated, lying and being in Ware County, Georgia) or in the office of the superior court of Pierce County (with respect to lands within the corporate limits of the city, situated, lying and being in Pierce County, Georgia) shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by section 1-9; each separate sale or exhibition of a plat shall constitute a separate offense; and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. The city, through its attorney or other official designated by the city commission may seek to enjoin such transfer or agreement by appropriate action. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VI(A); Ord. No. 93-06, § 5, 4-20-1993; Ord. No. O17-05 , § 1, 4-4-2017) Sec. 113-80. - Planning commission to approve plat prior to recording. No plat or plan of subdivision within the jurisdiction of this chapter shall be filed or recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court of Ware County (with respect to lands within the corporate limits of the city, situated, lying and being in Ware County, Georgia) or in the office of the superior court of Pierce County (with respect to lands within the corporate limits of the city, situated, lying and being in Pierce County, Georgia) until it has been approved by the planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the secretary of the planning commission. The clerk of the appropriate superior court shall not file or record a plat of a subdivision which does not have the written approval of the planning commission thereon. Any person who files or records a plat of subdivision without such approval is guilty of violating this chapter and upon conviction before the municipal court shall be punished as provided by section 1-9, provided that the subdivider shall bear entirely the guilt should he represent the plat as approved by the planning commission when such is not the case. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VI(B); Ord. No. 93-06, § 5, 4-20-1993; Ord. No. O17-05 , § 1, 4-4-2017) Sec. 113-81. - Street access required prior to building permit issuance. No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or unless such street corresponds in its location and line with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by said planning commission or with a street located and accepted by the city. Any building erected in violation of this section shall be deemed an unlawful structure, and the building inspector, city attorney or other official designated by the city commission may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VI(C); Ord. No. 93-06, § 5, 4-20-1993) Sec. 113-82. - Acceptance of streets by city. The city commission or any other public authority shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave, or light any street or lay or authorize the laying of any water mains, sewers, connections, or other facilities or utilities in any street within its jurisdiction unless such street shall have been accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or unless such street corresponds in its location and line with a street shown or a subdivision plat approved by the planning commission or on a street plat made and adopted by the planning commission; provided, however, that the city commission may locate and construct or may accept any other street if the ordinance or other measure for such approval is first submitted to the planning commission for its review and comment; a street so submitted to have the status of an approved street as fully as though it had been originally shown on a subdivision plat approved by the planning commission or on a plat made and adopted by the planning commission. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § VI(D); Ord. No. 93-06, § 5, 4-20-1993) Secs. 113-83—113-107. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PLAT PROCEDURE AND DATA
Sec. 113-108. - Preapplication procedure. (a) Prior to the filing of application for approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider should consult informally with the planning commission's staff in order to be fully advised of the objectives of the regulations and his obligations under them and to receive assistance in planning his subdivision. If the proposed subdivision is to involve individual sewage systems, the subdivider should also consult informally with the county health department. The object of such consultation is to fully explain to the subdivider the procedures for obtaining approval of his plat and the requirements upon which approval is contingent, in order that he might be spared needless expenditures in connection with an unacceptable plat. (b) After the initial consultation described in subsection (a) of this section, two copies of the plans and data specified in section 113-109 shall be submitted to the planning commission as part of the preapplication procedure. This step does not require formal application, fee, or filing of a plat. (c) The planning commission shall determine the plat location of any public sites or open spaces, or of any rights-of-way for connectors, arterials, or controlled access thoroughfares, for which it shall require reservation or dedication under section 113-145 or 113-140(j), respectively. (d) Within 20 days after receipt of all the prescribed preapplication plans and data, the office of the planning commission shall inform the subdivider that the plans and data submitted (or as modified) do or do not meet the objectives of this chapter and explain any lack of conformity therewith. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(A)) Sec. 113-109. - Plans and data for preapplication procedure. Preapplication review of the proposed subdivision shall be based upon the following plans and information, which shall be submitted in the form specified by the planning commission: (1) General subdivision information which shall describe or outline the existing conditions on the site and the development proposed for the site, as necessary to supplement the drawings required in subsections (2) and (3) of this section, and which may include the following: existing restrictive deed covenants; land characteristics to include topographic suitability for building; available community facilities and utilities; a description of the subdivision proposed, to include acreage, number of residential lots, typical lot width and depth, and the extent of and justification for business areas, parks, playgrounds, and other public areas; and, statements concerning proposed protective covenants and proposed utilities and street improvements. (2) A location map covering the tract proposed for subdivision and the surrounding area and depicting existing community facilities serving or influencing the proposed subdivision, to include the following information: location of the proposed subdivision; main traffic arteries and public transportation lines; shopping centers and such facilities as elementary and high schools, parks and playgrounds, railroad stations, airports, hospitals and churches; name of the subdivider, title, scale, north arrow and date. (3) A sketch plan which shall show in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, alleys, easements, lots and other features and which shall show streets and platting in immediately surrounding areas. The sketch plan may be a free hand pencil sketch made directly on a print of the boundary survey and shall include: a. Boundary lines, with bearings (may be magnetic) and distances along them and with reference to control points. b. Location and width of street rights-of-way. c. Location, width, and purpose of easements. d. Location of structures which will remain in place, such as houses, barns, commercial buildings, railroads, towers, and retaining walls. e. Certification of registered land surveyor, date of survey, scale of map, and north arrow. f. Topographic contour lines at an interval of one foot for slopes of six percent or less, or, of two feet for slopes greater than six percent, where the planning commission determines that this information is necessary to determine the suitability of the proposed subdivision design and development. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(B)) Sec. 113-110. - Procedure for approval of preliminary plat. As the first step in the procedure for preliminary plat approval, the subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat, together with the other material specified in section 113-111. (1) At least 20 days prior to the meeting of the planning commission at which it is to be initially considered, six copies of the preliminary plat and any required supplementary material shall be submitted, in accordance with the provisions of section 113-111, to the office of the planning commission with a written request for approval. A receipt for the filing fee required by section 113-27 shall also be included with the preliminary plat. (2) Copies of the preliminary plat shall be distributed by the staff of the planning commission to the county health department, the city (county) engineer, and the water department. Each of these agencies shall have ten days after receiving the preliminary plat to review it and shall communicate their findings to the planning commission. (3) Prior to approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat, the planning commission shall afford a hearing to the person of name and address designated on the plat to receive notice of such hearing and shall give notice of the hearing by registered mail to said address at least five days before the date fixed therefor, stating date, place, and time of such hearing. (4) The planning commission shall determine the plat location of any public sites or open spaces, or of any rights-of-way for connectors, arterials, or controlled access thoroughfares for which it shall require reservation or dedication, where this has not been done in the preapplication procedure. (5) Within 30 days of receipt of the preliminary plat with application for approval, the planning commission shall notify the city (county) of any streets and public sites or open spaces and the city (county) board of education of any school sites which the subdivider will be required to reserve for purchase in accordance with sections 113-140(j) and 113-145. The city (county) or city (county) board of education shall then have 30 days within which to reach an agreement with the subdivider on the price to be paid the subdivider for such streets, public sites or open spaces upon termination of the reservation. Should the city (county) or city (county) board of education be unable to agree, within the specified time, on the price to be paid for land to be reserved, the city (county) or city (county) board of education and the subdivider shall each select an appraiser and these two appraisers shall select a third; and the three appraisers shall by majority decision arrive at a fair price for the street, public site, or open space in question, as of the time of reservation. The expense of employing the three appraisers shall be shared equally by city (county) or city (county) board of education and the subdivider. This procedure shall in no way limit the city (county) or city (county) board of education in the application of eminent domain procedure under state law, nor deny the subdivider free access to the courts. (6) Within 30 days after submission of the preliminary plat, the planning commission shall give its approval, disapproval, or approval subject to listed modifications, in accordance with the findings of the agencies listed in subsection (2) of this section, relating to their areas of responsibility and as determined by the administrative regulations of each agency. Failure of the planning commission to act on the preliminary plat within the 30 days shall be deemed approval of it, unless the applicant for approval has waived this requirement and consented to extension of such period. (7) The action of the planning commission shall be noted on each copy of the preliminary plat and copies returned to the subdivider, the county health department, the city (county) engineer, and the water department, with one copy retained by the planning commission. (8) Approval of the preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat. Rather, it should be deemed an expression of approval of the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat, the approval of which depends upon the fulfillment of the site improvement and other requirements of this chapter. (9) The installation of site improvements is to proceed only in accordance with an approved preliminary plat and the required data submitted therewith. No street or alley grading shall be done upon land to be dedicated to the public use or which would cause a connection to be made to a public street or alley until: a. Acceptable plans and profiles have been submitted to the city (county) engineer; and b. A street construction permit has been issued by the city (county) engineer. (10) Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one year, provided that this shall not apply to a preliminary plat of a subdivision within which improvements are to be installed in stages with a final plat for each stage. In such case, the planning commission will prepare a schedule indicating the time period allowed for the final plat of each stage, provided that the overall time limit for such a preliminary plat shall not exceed three years and may be as short as one year, at the discretion of the planning commission in consideration of the complexity of site improvement in the particular case and the number of stages involved. The planning commission may grant extensions of the time period within which the preliminary plat approval is effective, each such extension not to exceed a period of one year. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(C)) Sec. 113-111. - Plats and data required in preliminary plat procedure. (a) Data on existing conditions. The following data on existing conditions within and adjacent to the proposed subdivision, if not previously submitted in connection with the preapplication procedure (section 113-108), shall be required for approval of the preliminary plat, except when otherwise specified by the planning commission, and shall be submitted in the form specified by the planning commission: (1) Boundary lines of the proposed subdivision, with true bearings and distances along them and with reference to control points. The map on which they are shown will also show datum plane, certification of registered land surveyor, date of survey, scale of map, and north arrow. (2) Location, width and purposes of easements. (3) Width and location of street rights-of-way and roadways on and adjacent to the tract; names of streets; width and location of railroad rights-of-way; approximate location of highways or other public improvements proposed by public agencies for future construction; location of walks, curbs, gutters, culverts, etc.; types of street surfacing; and, any established centerline elevations, elevations of street surfacing, and topographic contour lines at an interval of one foot for slopes of six percent or less, or, of two feet for slopes greater than six percent. (4) Utilities on and adjacent to the tract, to include location, size and invert elevation of sanitary, storm and combined sewers; location and size of water mains; and, location of gas lines and fire hydrants; and such other information on utilities as the planning commission may specify. If existing water mains and sewers do not fall within the plat, indicate the direction and distance to and size of the nearest ones, also showing the invert election for sewers. (5) Location of and test data from soil percolation test shall be as prescribed by the county health department and on a form or forms provided by that agency. (6) Such topographic features of the tract as watercourses, marshes, and areas which have in the past been subject to slow drainage after normal rainfall. (7) Location of and test data resulting from subsoil borings to a depth of six feet to determine groundwater level and subsurface rock formations. Test data shall be that prescribed by the county health department on forms provided by that agency. (8) Location and designation within the tract of structures to remain in place, such as houses, barns, commercial buildings, railroads, towers, and retaining walls. (9) Approximate location of houses and accessory buildings and nonresidential buildings and land uses adjacent the tract. (10) Delineation of adjacent subdivisions with recorded plats, referring to the subdivision plat by the recorded name, number by which filed, and date of recording and delineation of adjacent unplatted parcels, referring to the apparent owner of each. (11) Key plan showing location of the tract with distances to nearby street intersections or other obvious geographical features. (12) Description according to official records of tract to be subdivided, acreage within said tract, names and addresses of owners of said tract, and title under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded. (b) Preliminary plat. The preliminary plat of the subdivision shall be at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet or any less number of feet in increments of ten as may be appropriate, to be submitted in six copies. The size of sheet for the plat shall be as specified by the planning commission; and when more than one sheet is required, an index sheet showing the entire subdivision shall be included with each plat, with each sheet of the plat keyed thereto. The preliminary plat shall include or be accompanied by data on existing conditions (subsection (a) of this section), by preliminary sections, profiles, and utility plans (subsection (c) of this section), and by the draft of protective covenants (subsection (d) of this section), all supplementary information to be submitted in six copies; and the preliminary plat shall include the following with respect to the proposed subdivision: (1) Streets: names, right-of-way and roadway widths and similar data for alleys, of any. (2) Other rights-of-way or easements: location, width and purpose. (3) Utilities: location, size of lines, and invert elevations (for sewer lines), if not shown on other exhibits. (4) Lots: lot lines, numbers, and dimensions. (5) Block: block number or letter designations. (6) Sites for public buildings and open spaces: sites, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for schools, playgrounds or other public use. (7) Parcels other than normal residential lots: parcels, if any, to be used for multiple family dwellings, shopping centers, churches, industry or other public or non-public uses exclusive of single-family dwellings. (8) Building setback lines. (9) Site data: Number of residential lots, typical lot size and the sizes of sites to be used for other than single-family residential purposes. (10) Title, numerical scale, graphic scale, north arrow, date. (11) Name and address of person to be notified of hearing to be held prior to action by planning commission. (c) Preliminary sections, profiles, and utility plans. When required by the planning commission, the preliminary plat shall be accompanied by profiles showing existing ground surface and proposed street grades, including extensions to the centerlines of intersecting streets; typical cross sections of the proposed grading, roadway and sidewalk; and preliminary plans of proposed water mains, sanitary sewers, and stormwater sewers, with the size of each utility line indicated and also the invert elevation of sewer lines. All elevations shall be based on a datum plane approved by the city (county) engineer. (d) Protective covenants. A draft of deed or plat covenants, whereby the subdivider proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development, or to establish property owners' associations if such are to be used, shall accompany the preliminary plat. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(D)) Sec. 113-112. - Procedure for approval of the final plat. (a) At least 20 days prior to the meeting of the planning commission at which it is to be considered, the subdivider shall submit to the office of the planning commission an application for approval of the final plat and the plat and data required under II-F, including an original tracing of the final plat drawn on linen, or other material of equal or better durability and dimensional stability, one paper reproducible, and six copies. The final plat shall be drawn in black drawing ink on sheets dimensioned 24 inches by 36 inches and shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals 100 feet or less number of feet in increments of ten, as may be appropriate to the size of the subdivision and plat sheet size. Where necessary, the plat may be drawn on several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing by keyed sections the portion of the subdivision covered by each sheet. The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved by the planning commission; and if desired by the subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the preliminary plat which he proposes to record at the time, provided, however, that such a final plat conforms to the time limitations specified in subsection 113-110(10) and all other requirements of this chapter. (b) Completed installation of improvements. (1) Prior to approval of the final plat by the planning commission, the subdivider must have completed installation of improvements required in article V of this chapter; or else the subdivider may, in lieu of actual installation, select one of the following alternatives: a. Post a completion bond or make an escrow deposit in an amount equal to the portion of the cost of improvements to be borne by the subdivider. The bond or escrow agreement (in the case of an escrow deposit) shall provide for and secure to the city (county) the installation of site improvements in accordance with the time limitations specified below and the other requirements of this chapter and shall be payable to the city (county) in the event the requirements of this chapter are not met. Withdrawals by the subdivider may be made from an escrow account in direct proportion to the cost of work completed and accepted by the city (county) engineer. b. Present evidence that the owner specified on the final plat has satisfactory title, and an executed loan commitment from a lending institution which provides that the site improvements will be installed within the time limits specified below and the other requirements of this chapter, that the agreement will be subject to the usual standard lending procedures, and that the release of the loan proceeds to the subdivider to be used in making the improvements will be contingent upon approval of the installed facilities by the city (county) engineer. c. Present a performance bond wherein the contractor for the site improvements guarantees their installation to the subdivider, in accordance with a contract which is not subject to termination and in accordance with the time limits specified below and the other requirements of this chapter, and an assignment to the city (county) of any proceeds resulting from payment of the bond, which assignment has the written approval of the surety company given as security on the bond. (2) With regard to each of the three preceding alternatives, construction and installation of street paving shall be accomplished within one year of the date of final plat approval; and construction and installation of storm drainage and all other site improvements shall be accomplished within six months of the date of final plat approval. Time lost because of labor strikes or material shortages resulting from government control of distribution shall be subtracted from the time periods specified. Whether improvements are installed before or after final plat approval by the planning commission, the subdivider shall in all cases, and in addition to the preceding alternative devices to secure installation of site improvements (completion bond, escrow deposit, loan commitment from a lending institution, or assigned contractor's performance bond), post a maintenance bond or make an escrow deposit in the amount of ten percent of the total cost of all improvements other than those to be installed by the city (county) as provided in an executed agreement, such bond to be payable to the city (county) in the event deficiencies in improvements are revealed within a period of one year from the date of installation, in an amount sufficient to effect the repairs or replacements necessary to correct such deficiencies. (3) Completion, performance, and maintenance bonds shall be with a surety company entered and licensed to do business in the state and shall be approved by the city (county) attorney prior to their acceptance by the city (county). (4) The amount of completion bond, escrow account or maintenance bond shall be computed by the city (county) engineer and shall be based upon the cost of each site improvement as determined by the city (county) engineer or upon the cost of each site improvement as shown on a certified bid by a reputable contractor with ten percent bid bond attached and covering all required improvements. The city (county) engineer shall furnish the above figures within 30 days of the subdivider's request for such figures, provided that the planning commission has approved the preliminary plat and provided that an extension of time may be granted by the subdivider. (5) It should be noted that the actual installation of improvements, or the alternative to installation specified herein, is prerequisite only to approval of the final plat. (c) Copies of the final plat shall be forwarded to the city engineer, Ware County health department (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Ware County, Georgia) or Pierce County health department (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Pierce County, Georgia) and the city water department for review, comment, and recommendation as to approval or disapproval prior to final action by the planning commission. These agencies to have ten days after receipt of the final plat to submit their comments and recommendations. (d) Prior to approval or disapproval of the final plat, the planning commission shall afford a hearing to the person of name and address designated to receive notice of such hearing (by subsection 113-113(c)(2)) and shall give notice of the hearing by registered mail to said address at least five days before the date fixed therefor, stating date, place, and time of such hearing. (e) The planning commission shall approve or disapprove this final plat within 30 days after its submission to that body, and failure of the planning commission to act on the final plat within these 30 days shall be deemed approval of it, unless the applicant for approval has waived this requirement and consented to extension of such period. If the plat is disapproved, the grounds for disapproval shall be stated upon the records of the planning commission. (f) Approval of the final plat by the planning commission shall not constitute acceptance by the city (county) of the dedication of any streets or other public grounds. (g) Upon approval of the final plat, the planning commission shall affix a certificate of approval to the original lien and shall forward the original to the city commission (county commission) for its action upon the offers of dedication shown thereon. (h) Upon disapproval of the final plat, the planning commission shall transmit to the city commission (county commission) an explanation of the grounds of disapproval as stated in the records of the planning commission. (i) When offers of dedication shown on the final plat have been accepted by the city commission, the original tracing with the certificate of approval of the planning commission and a statement accepting offers of dedication affixed thereto, will be returned to the subdivider, who shall reproduce, from the original seven copies. The original tracing, paper reproducible (subsection 113-112(a)), and eight copies shall then be retransmitted to the planning commission, which shall cause the original tracing and one copy, along with the date specified in subsection 113-113(b) and (d), to be filed with the clerk of superior court of Ware County (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Ware County, Georgia) or clerk of superior court of Pierce County (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Pierce County, Georgia), provided that the planning commission has received satisfactory evidence that the prescribed fees have been paid. The paper reproducible will be forwarded to the city engineer and the remaining copies will be distributed in the following manner, at least: (1) One copy retained by the subdivider; (2) One copy to the water department; (3) Three copies to the Ware County health department (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Ware County, Georgia) or three copies to the Pierce County health department (with respect to those tracts or parcels situate, lying and being in Pierce County, Georgia); (4) One copy to the city engineer; and (5) One copy to the planning commission. (j) The data specified in subsection 113-113(b), (c) and (d) shall be submitted in seven copies typed or printed on letter-size bond paper (eight and one-half inches by 11 inches), each copy and each page thereof to be referenced to the final plat by subdivision name, and date application is made for approval, each page of each copy to be numbered consecutively. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(E); Ord. No. 93-06, §§ 2, 3, 4-20-1993; Ord. No. O17-05 , § 1, 4-4-2017) Sec. 113-113. - Plats and data required in final plat procedure. (a) The final plat shall show the following: (1) Primary control points and benchmarks with necessary descriptions and locations of such control points, including all dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data necessary for proper location. (2) Sufficient information to reproduce the plat on the ground, including tract boundary lines with error of closure shown thereon and not to exceed one foot in 3,000; right-of-way lines of streets, easements and other rights-of-way; property lines of residential lots and other sites; dimensions of lots and sites, and widths of streets and easements, all correct to the nearest one-tenth of a foot; bearings or deflection angles on all lines and radii and central or delta angles of all curves, with bearings and central or delta angles accurate to the nearest minute. (3) Location of monuments, with designation of type. (4) Name of each street or other right-of-way and purpose of any easements. (5) Purpose for which sites other than residential lots are to be used, dedicated or reserved. (6) Minimum building setback lines on all lots and other sites. (7) Number to identify each lot or site and number or letter to identify each block. (8) Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land and platted land, giving reference to recorded subdivision plats by the recorded name, number by which filed, and date of recording. (9) Statement for subsequent use of the planning commission, upon approval of the final plat, similar to the following: "Approved by the Waycross-Ware County Planning Commission on the ___________ day of ________, 20___." ___________ Secretary, Waycross-Ware County Planning Commission (Name to be printed) ___________ Secretary, Waycross-Ware County Planning Commission (Name to be signed) (10) Title, numerical scale, graphic scale, north arrow and date. (b) The following statements and certificates, properly executed, shall accompany the final plat and the application for approval and shall be subsequently filed as part of the approved final plat and properly referenced thereto. (1) Statement by applicant certifying ownership of the property within the plat and offering for dedication those streets and other sites for public use designated on the plat, similar to the following: "It is hereby certified that the following person or legal entity is owner of the property within the accompanying subdivision plat, to be known as _____ Subdivision, and hereby offers for dedication to public use forever all streets, alleys, and easements shown on the plat and all other public sites and open spaces designated on the plat as offered for dedication; and hereby acknowledges this plat and offer of dedication to be _____ free act and deed." ___________ Typed or Printed Name of Owner ___________ Signature of Owner (2) Certification by a surveyor licensed to practice in the state certifying to accuracy of plat and survey, similar to the following: "It is hereby certified that the accompanying plat, to be known as _____ Subdivision, is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property prepared from an actual survey of the property made under my supervision on the ground and that the error of closure is stated correctly on the plat." ___________ Typed or Printed Name of Surveyor ___________ Registration No. ___________ Signature of Surveyor (3) Certificate by the county health department similar to the following: "It is hereby certified that the accompanying plat, to be known as _____ Subdivision, along with other documentary evidence required, meets all regulations of the Ware County Board of Health." ___________ Typed or Printed Name of Director of Public Health or Representative ___________ Signature of Director of Public Health or Representative (c) The following statements and certificates, properly executed, shall accompany the final plat and application for approval but need not later be filed with the final plat. (1) Certification of approval of required improvements by city (county) engineer, similar to the following: "It is hereby certified that all the improvements required by chapter 113 of the Waycross City Code have been installed in compliance therewith or that such installation has been guaranteed in compliance with section 113-112(b)." ___________ Typed or Printed Name of City (County) Engineer ___________ Signature of City (County) Engineer (2) Statement by applicant specifying the person to be notified of the hearing by the planning commission on the final plat, similar to the following: The following person shall be notified at the address shown of the hearing by the planning commission upon the final plat of _____ Subdivision prior to action upon said plat. ___________ Typed Name of Person Designated ___________ Address of Person Designated ___________ Typed Name and Signature of Subdivider Applicant (d) Restrictive covenants, in form for recording with the plat or insertion in deeds shall accompany the final plat and the application for approval. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § II(F)) Secs. 113-114—113-139. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 113-140. - Streets and alleys. (a) The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the major street plan or other street and highway plans approved by the planning commission and shall conform to applicable regulations of the state or local governments respectively. (b) Where a street is not shown in any street or highway plan approved by the planning commission, the arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall: (1) Be designed and located in proper relation to existing streets and shall provide, where appropriate, for the continuation or projection of existing streets; or (2) Conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved or adopted by the planning commission to meet a particular situation where topographic or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable. (c) The arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall be so designed that adequate access is provided to adjacent unplatted areas by streets extended to the subdivision boundary where appropriate. (d) Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed controlled access thoroughfare or arterial as shown on a street or highway plan approved by the planning commission, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, lots backing onto the thoroughfare or arterial with a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of the abutting properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. The nonaccess reservation shall be at least 15 feet in depth in addition to the normal lot depth requirement and shall be a part of the platted lots but shall have the following restrictive covenant to be filed with the plat: "The nonaccess reservations as designated on the plat shall be reserved for the planting of trees or shrubs by the owner; the building of structures thereon is prohibited." (e) Where a subdivision abuts or contains a railroad right-of-way, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, provided that where such street intersects a controlled access thoroughfare or arterial, the minimum distance from said railroad right-of-way shall not be less than 250 feet. (f) Each service street shall be so designed that use by through traffic will be discouraged. (g) Private streets and reserve strips controlling access to streets shall not be permitted except where control is placed with the city (county) under conditions approved by the planning commission. (h) Each lot in a subdivision shall be served by a publicly dedicated street (excepting streets in a mobile home park) of a right-of-way width not less than 50 feet. (i) Street width shall be specified by the planning commission in conformity with the following:
(j) Dedication or reservation of right-of-way shall conform to the following: (1) Right-of-way for controlled access thoroughfares and arterials, as shown on the series of major street plan maps which have been approved by resolution of the city and county governing bodies, shall be reserved for purchase by the city (county) at fair market value for the entire width or the portion thereof lying within the subdivision, in accordance with subsection (i) of this section regarding right-of-way widths, the location of such right-of-way to be determined on the plat by the planning commission during the preapplication procedure, or the preliminary plat procedure, if the former has not been followed. Where there is an existing right-of-way abutting the subdivision of less width than that required, the planning commission may require reservation of such additional right-of-way width lying within the subdivision as it may determine, not to exceed the total right-of-way width which may be required under subsection (i) of this section. (2) Additional right-of-way width for connector streets shown on the series of major street plan maps which have been approved by resolution of the city and county governing bodies, over that required for service streets, shall be paid for as provided for under section 113-110(5), the location of such rights-of-way to be determined during review of preapplication data, or the preliminary plat procedure, if the former has not been submitted. (3) Right-of-way for all proposed service streets, marginal access streets, and alleys lying within the subdivision shall be offered for dedication to the city (county). (4) Reservation of street right-of-way shall be for a period of one year from date of final plat approval, unless this limitation shall be waived by the subdivider, upon termination of which the city (county) shall purchase the right-of-way at the price previously agreed upon. (k) When a deflection in the alignment of a street occurs, the street shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure sight distance of not less than 400 feet for controlled access thoroughfares, arterials, and connector streets, and not less than 100 feet for service streets and marginal access streets, and of such greater radii as the city (county) engineer shall determine for special cases. In no case shall a controlled access thoroughfare, arterial, or connector street have a centerline radius of less than 500 feet or a service street or marginal access street have a centerline radius less than 100 feet except upon written recommendation of the city (county) engineer. (l) A tangent of at least 100 feet shall be introduced between reverse curves on all controlled access thoroughfares and arterials. (m) Streets shall be laid out so far as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and no street shall intersect any other street at an angle less than 60 degrees. (n) For intersecting streets with their centerlines offset, where it is impossible to obtain continuous pavement alignment (by offsetting the pavement within the right-of-way), the minimum centerline offset shall be 125 feet. (o) Culs-de-sac (permanent dead-end streets) shall be no longer than 600 feet and shall be provided at the closed end with a circular turnaround having a roadway diameter of at least 80 feet and a right-of-way diameter of at least 100 feet; or if 300 feet or less in length, culs-de-sac may be provided with a "Y"-type turn-around as approved by the city (county) engineer. (p) Temporary dead-end streets which are extended to the boundary of the subdivided property with the expectation of being extended onto the adjoining property when it is subdivided shall be no longer than 600 feet (measured from the nearest street intersection) and shall be provided with a temporary circular turn-around having a roadway diameter of at least 80 feet, or a "Y"-turn-around as approved by the city (county) engineer if the street is no longer than 300 feet. Rights-of-way for the turnarounds for such streets may be the same as roadway dimensions, with appropriate provision for reversion to adjoining property owners of any turn-around right-of-way in excess of required street right-of-way width upon extension of the street. (q) Streets which are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named in the city's urban area shall bear the names of existing streets, and in no case shall the names of proposed streets which are not in alignment with named existing streets duplicate the names of existing streets, irrespective of the suffix, avenue, drive, court, road, street, etc. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission. (r) Alleys may be required to service lots used for business purposes, if appropriate. Alleys shall not be provided in residential blocks except where the subdivider presents evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided. Dead-end alleys shall not be approved; and alleys shall not intersect a controlled access thoroughfare or an arterial. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(A)) Sec. 113-141. - Easements. (a) Except where streets or alleys are provided and suitably located to contain utilities, the subdivider shall provide utility easements across lots (centered on rear or side lot lines where possible), such easements to be at least 15 feet wide. (b) Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, an easement conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse or drainage vehicle shall be provided of such width, alignment and improvement as may be determined by the planning commission upon consideration of any recommendation by the city (county) engineer. The watercourse or drainage vehicle within the easement shall be of adequate size and grade to hydraulically accommodate maximum expected volumes of flow according to sizes and design details recommended by city (county) engineer, and the easement shall be wide enough to accommodate such watercourses or drainage vehicles and also provide space for access by maintenance equipment. (c) Slope easements shall be required by the planning commission when specifically recommended by the city engineer (county engineer). (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(B)) Sec. 113-142. - Blocks. (a) The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: (1) Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the types of use contemplated; (2) Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions; (3) Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of vehicular and pedestrian traffic; and (4) Limitations and opportunities of topography. (b) Block lengths shall not exceed 1,600 feet nor be less than 500 feet except where exceptional topography or other conditions peculiar to the site make such dimensions impracticable. (c) Pedestrian ways or cross walks not less than ten feet wide may be required at locations approved by the planning commission when deemed essential to provide adequate pedestrian access or circulation to schools, shopping centers, churches or transportation facilities. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(C)) Sec. 113-143. - Lots. (a) Lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation, and the minimum depth of building setback from the street shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. The lots shall be so dimensioned and proportioned as to provide adequate building sites and useable open space for the type buildings contemplated. (b) Every lot shall abut on a public street (excepting mobile home parks) for a distance not less than 30 feet. (c) Every lot shall conform to the width and area requirements of the city's zoning ordinance, except that: (1) Residential lots which are served by a public water system but not served by a public sanitary sewer shall be no less than 90 feet in width at the building setback line and no less than 15,000 square feet in area or such greater area as the county health department may determine, based on ground percolation tests. (2) Residential lots which are not served either by a public water system or a public sewerage system shall be no less than 100 feet in width at the building setback line and no less than 20,000 square feet in area or such greater area as the county health department may determine, based on ground percolation tests. (3) Depth and width of lots to be used for commercial and industrial purposes shall provide adequate space for off-street parking and service facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated and shall be such that ingress and egress points are designed for safe use and in conformity with applicable local regulations. (4) The minimum distance between building setback line and street right-of-way line shall be no less than 30 feet, as applied to a residence with the principal entrance facing that street, and be no less than 15 feet as applied to the side of a residence not containing the principal entrance. The plat shall show a setback width of 30 feet or more, with suitable notation of the 15 foot minimum requirement for side streets. (d) Corner lots for residential use shall be at least 20 percent wider (at the building setback line) than other lots, except where interior lots are greater than 120 feet in width, in order to permit appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets. (e) Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines where not impracticable in designing lots to meet the dimension and area requirements of this chapter. (f) Double frontage lots (lots bounded on opposite sides by streets) shall be prohibited except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from controlled access thoroughfares or arterials in accordance with the provisions of section 113-140(d) (which requires nonaccess easements) or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. Corner lots are not included within the term "double frontage." (g) Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided, and a proportion of two to one shall normally be considered a desirable ratio. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(D)) Sec. 113-144. - Large scale developments. The requirements of this chapter with regard to lot, block, and street design may be modified in the case of a plan and program for a tract of at least ten acres to be subdivided and developed under the control of one person, corporation, association, or other entity as a residential neighborhood unit and which provides in its design for adequate vehicular and pedestrian circulation, light, air, open space, and service needs for its potential inhabitants, with adequate guarantee, in the form of restrictive deed covenants or otherwise, that the design will not be substantially altered in the future. Plans for such developments shall be submitted to and approved by the planning commission and shall be submitted to the city (county) for acceptance of offer of dedication, whether or not such plat is to be recorded; and no building permits shall be issued until such approval and acceptance have been given. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(E)) Sec. 113-145. - Public sites and open spaces. (a) Where features of the comprehensive plan, such as school sites, parks, playgrounds or sites for other public building and open spaces, as approved by the city or county board of education, are located in whole or in part within a proposed subdivision, any portion of which lies within the city, the planning commission shall determine on the preapplication plan or the preliminary plat of the subdivision (according to the procedure being followed) the boundaries of the portions of such features included within the subdivision and shall provide for the acquisition of such public sites and open spaces according to the following provisions: (1) Where acquisition upon the approval of the final plat is possible, this is the recommended procedure. (2) Where acquisition is not immediately possible, the public sites and open spaces shall be reserved for a period of five years from the date of final plat approval, within which time the city or county board of education may purchase the public site or open space from the subdivider at the price previously agreed upon by the procedure specified in section 113-110(5). The subdivider shall be paid interest at the rate of six percent per annum on the amount as determined by section 113-110(5) for the sites being reserved, such interest to run for the period of time between approval of the final plat by the planning commission and termination of reservation. The reserved site should be platted in lots as part of the overall subdivision, so that in case it is not acquired, it can be efficiently used for building lots. (b) In case there is a need for public sites or open spaces not designated on the comprehensive plan, but which are considered essential by the planning commission, the planning commission shall attempt to arrange voluntary reservation of such sites with the subdivider. The time period of reservation would, in such a case, be determined by negotiation, and although the city (county) or city (county) board of education would be under no obligation to purchase, a price to be applied in the event of purchase shall be agreed upon within 60 days of application for preliminary plat approval. The reserved site should be platted in lots as part of the overall subdivision, so that in case it is not acquired, it can be efficiently used for building lots. (c) Due regard shall be shown to the preservation of all natural features, such as large trees, historical spots, lakes and ponds, and similar community assets, which if properly included in the overall design of the subdivision, will add attractiveness and value to the property. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(F); Ord. No. 93-06, § 4, 4-20-1993) Sec. 113-146. - Land subject to flooding. Land subject to flooding shall not be platted for residential occupancy, nor for the use of any type of building to which flooding would cause substantial property damage or danger to human life. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(G)) Sec. 113-147. - Mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions. The requirements of this chapter with respect to lot, block, and street design shall apply to mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions with the following exceptions: (1) Streets. a. The internal streets serving the mobile homes and complementary facilities shall have a right-of-way width of 50 feet. b. A gridiron-type street system will not be acceptable, nor any other type of site planning which would result in a monotonous, unattractive development. c. The park or subdivision shall abut for a distance of at least 200 feet any street upon which there are ingress and egress points. d. Privately-owned streets shall service all lots and parcels within a mobile home park, but shall meet the improvement standards specified in article V of this chapter. Private streets shall not be permitted within a mobile home subdivision. e. A deflection in the alignment of a service street shall be connected by a curve having minimum centerline radius of not less than 80 feet. f. The requirement for a 100-foot tangent between reverse curves is not applicable. g. Dead-end streets shall have an 80-foot-diameter turnaround, but the right-of-way may be the same dimension. h. The street system within a mobile home park shall provide direct access to areas to be occupied by transient mobile homes, so that it is not necessary to pass through areas of nontransient homes in order to reach them. (2) Easements. Utility easements (section 113-141(a)) shall not be required in a mobile home park but shall be required in a mobile home subdivision. (3) Block. Limitations on the lengths of blocks shall not apply. (4) Lots a. Each mobile home lot shall have a minimum area of 2,000 square feet and a minimum width of 30 feet. Recreation areas provided for the common use of residents of the mobile home park or subdivision shall be permitted to reduce the minimum area of the mobile home lot by an area equal to the total area of the recreation areas divided by the total number of lots in the park or subdivision, such reduction not to exceed 300 square feet. b. Each park or subdivision shall have not less than 25 mobile home lots. c. Mobile home lots shall be so proportioned as to provide space for a mobile home stand of ten feet by 50 feet, a patio of 180 square feet, and a driveway and one automobile parking space, and shall meet any yard and open space requirements of the zoning regulations pertaining to mobile homes. d. Parcels to be provided for commercial and service facilities shall be of size and design necessary to serve only the particular park or subdivision. e. Minimum length of lot abutment on a public street (section 113-143(b)) shall not be required. f. The minimum building setback provision (section 113-143(c)(4)) shall not apply. (5) Buffer. Surrounding the park or subdivision (excepting only ingress and egress points) there shall be a planting easement of at least 15 feet upon which buildings shall not be permitted and which shall be planted and permanently maintained in trees and shrubbery that will within five years after planting, be six feet in height and obscure objects behind the easement at a distance of 50 feet. In the case of a mobile homes subdivision, an association of property owners shall be created through deed or plat covenant and shall have the responsibility of maintaining the trees and shrubbery, such association to have appropriate organization and adequate powers, as determined by the planning commission, to perform its duties. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § III(H)) Secs. 113-148—113-177. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - GATED RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISIONS Subdivision I. - In General
Sec. 113-178. - Purpose. Consistent with the overarching goals of this chapter, this division is intended to allow for private street and/or gated developments as one type of residential development alternative to allow the city to expand housing types and promote smart residential subdivision growth within the city. (Ord. No. 08-01, § I(A), 1-15-2008) Sec. 113-179. - Jurisdiction. The provisions of this division shall apply to the city, including, without limitation, portions of the city which lie in Pierce County, Georgia, and any portions which may be annexed hereafter, and further includes property which may lie in any other county of the state which is subsequently annexed into the city. (Ord. No. 08-01, § I(B), 1-15-2008) Secs. 113-180—113-199. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Standards
Sec. 113-200. - Applicability. Unlike other developments in the city, a gated residential development, where a gate is placed at the outer periphery of the development in order to restrict access, may be allowed to have private streets that are not owned and maintained by the city. All gated residential developments must be developed in accordance with the regulations of this subdivision, other applicable regulations of this chapter, and the city's zoning ordinance. (Ord. No. 08-01, § II(intro. ¶), 1-15-2008) Sec. 113-201. - Entrances. The design and layout of any gatehouse, entry gates, external fence, walls, and berms shall be located outside any public street right-of-way and shall be designed to blend in, to the greatest degree feasible, with the proposed development and be attractive to motorists and pedestrians from adjoining public streets. Gatehouses and entry gates shall be located outside any required buffer areas. Entry gates shall be set back sufficiently far from public street entrances to allow for stacking of at least three vehicles out of the public travel lanes. An additional setback between the point of the access control device and the entry gate shall be required to allow a vehicle which is denied access to safely turn around and exit onto a public street. Pedestrian access to the gated residential development shall be provided at its entrance outside of the vehicle travel lanes. Entry gates shall have sufficient minimum gate widths and openings to allow safe passage of all vehicles permitted to use public roadways. Overhead barriers or obstructions shall not be allowed above entry gates. (Ord. No. 08-01, § II(A), 1-15-2008) Sec. 113-202. - Design standards. With the exception of the placement of a gate and guardhouse in a private street right-of-way, all private roads, traffic signs and markings shall meet all applicable minimum right-of-way, pavement, construction, and design standards for public roads as established by the city. The city reserves the right to have streets inspected during the construction phase to ensure that they are being built in accordance with all applicable standards. (Ord. No. 08-01, § II(B), 1-15-2008) Sec. 113-203. - Maintenance. Prior to the approval of a final plat, the subdivider shall submit to the city evidence that the subdivider has created a homeowners' association whose responsibility it will be to maintain common areas, private utilities, private streets, curb and gutter and sidewalks within the subdivision. Such evidence shall include filed copies of the articles of incorporation, declarations, and homeowners' association bylaws. The maintenance and upkeep of any guardhouses or entry structures, and subdivision walls, fences, or berms located at the external periphery of the subdivision as well as internal streets, curb, gutter, sidewalks and utilities shall be the sole responsibility of the subdivider and/or any duly incorporated and active homeowners' association. (Ord. No. 08-01, § II(C), 1-15-2008) Sec. 113-204. - Access. (a) The subdivider and homeowners' association shall guarantee access to all private streets by emergency and law enforcement vehicles. Access procedures must ensure immediate access through the entry gates for emergency and law enforcement vehicles responding to emergencies. Approach and departure areas on both sides of a gated entrance must provide adequate setbacks and proper alignment to allow free and unimpeded passage of emergency vehicles through the entrance area. The subdivider shall provide documentation from city fire chief or his designee that proposed entry gates and access procedures meet all city standards for access by emergency and law enforcement vehicles. (b) The subdivider and homeowners' association shall guarantee access to all private streets by the city, county agencies, state agencies, and all public utility companies. City, county and state officials and staff shall be permitted entry to the gated residential development to perform zoning, inspections and other governmental regulatory activities. Public utility company vehicles and personnel shall be permitted entry to the gated residential development to perform installation and maintenance activities of public utility infrastructure. A statement to this effect shall appear on or accompany the final plat. (c) If the homeowners' association fails to maintain reliable access for the provision of emergency or other public services, the city may enter the gated residential development and open, disable or remove any gate or device, which is a barrier to access, at the sole expense of the homeowners' association. The declaration of covenants, conditions and restrictions and any other relevant documents of the homeowners' association shall include this provision. (Ord. No. 08-01, § II(D), 1-15-2008) Secs. 113-205—113-226. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED SITE IMPROVEMENTS AND CONTRIBUTIONS
Sec. 113-227. - Installation. The installation of the site improvements specified hereunder, or sufficient guarantee of the installation thereof, as provided by section 113-112(b), is required prior to approval of the final plat. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(intro. ¶)) Sec. 113-228. - Monuments. (a) Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves in streets, and at intermediate points as required by the city (county) engineer. Monuments shall be of reinforced concrete with dimensions at least four inches by four inches by 24 inches with solid metal center pins of one-fourth inch diameter and four inches length and flushed with the top of monuments, which shall be flushed with the finished grade. (b) Lot corners shall be marked with solid iron rods, or equivalent, not less than five-eighths inch outside diameter and 24 inches in length and driven flush with the finished grade. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(A)) Sec. 113-229. - Street and alley improvements. (a) Required paving. (1) Pavement widths shall conform to the following:
(2) Paving shall be required for all service streets and marginal access streets within a subdivision any portion of which lies within the city district or the county urban district and shall conform to the following requirements: a. All service and marginal access streets within areas of primarily residential use shall be properly graded and provided with a minimum of six inches of compacted, approved sand clay or soil cement base and a double surface bituminous treatment, all in accordance with city (county) standards. b. All service and marginal access streets serving industrial and commercial areas shall be graded and paved in accordance with city (county) standards relating thereto. (3) Provided that the entire right-of-way of a proposed or existing connector street (as specified by the planning commission under section 113-140(i)) has been dedicated to or purchased by the city (county) and provided that the street provides access to adjoining lots, the subdivider shall grade and pave such street in accordance with city (county) standards and shall be reimbursed one-half the cost of these improvements. If such street does not provide access to adjoining lots, the subdivider may be required, at the option of the city (county), to grade and pave such street, with reimbursement of the total cost thereof. (4) With respect to the platted portion of a street extended past a street intersection to a subdivision boundary where the adjacent property is unplatted and which need not be opened for circulation within the particular subdivision, the planning commission may relieve the subdivider of the street improvements otherwise required thereon. Such improvements shall be installed by the subsequent subdivider of adjacent land whose street connects therewith. (b) Grading. Regardless of whether paving is required in the particular district (section 113-141(a)), proper grading shall be carried out in accordance with the plans and data specified in section 113-111(c); and where paving is not provided, the roadway width shall be at least 34 feet. (c) Curb and gutter. Curb and gutter shall be required for all service streets and marginal access streets within a subdivision any portion of which lies within the city district or county urban district and having a typical lot width at the building line ranging from 66 feet to 150 feet. The subdivider shall be reimbursed one-half the cost of the curb and gutter; and the city (county) may, at the option of the subdivider, install the curb and gutter in lieu of reimbursement, such installation to be the subject of an agreement executed by both parties. Should the subdivider elect to install curb and gutter in subdivisions where it is not required, the immediately preceding provision relating to reimbursement and installation shall apply. Curb and gutter shall not be limited to any specific type but shall meet the requirements of the city (county) engineer. (d) Storm sewer, catchbasin, and manholes. If the subdivision is within a drainage basin wherein a system of storm sewers is deemed necessary by the city (county) engineer, storm sewers, catchbasins and manholes, all built to city (county) standards, shall be provided. In accordance with such standards, the city (county) engineer shall approve the size and material of the sewers and shall determine the method of their connection with the overall system for the basin. The subdivider shall be reimbursed a portion of the cost of the required drainage facilities, in accordance with the following provisions: (1) For that part of a storm sewer adjacent or within his subdivision, the subdivider shall be reimbursed for that portion of the cost of the main in excess of the cost of a main of adequate size for his particular subdivision. (2) For that part of a storm sewer system not adjacent or within his subdivision but required as part of the overall drainage system the subdivider shall be reimbursed for the amount in excess of the cost of an improved open drainage ditch of adequate size, the city (county) also to bear all costs of easements or right-of-way. For every subdivision, a system of drainage, including on-site and off-site facilities, shall be subject to approval by the city (county) engineer; and if storm sewers are impracticable, the subdivider shall provide all ditches and culverts necessary to connect with existing drainage, where the easements are provided by the city (county). (e) Alleys. All alleys will be graded for the full 20-foot width, shall be provided with concrete aprons to all street intersections which are paved or to be paved in accordance with this chapter, and shall be properly drained, all in accordance with city (county) standards. (f) Street marker signs. Street name signs, of the design and material specified in city (county) standards, shall be installed at all intersections of a subdivision any portion of which lies within the city district, county urban district, or county suburban district. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(B); Ord. No. 08-04, § 2, 2-19-2008) Sec. 113-230. - Utilities. (a) Water. A subdivision any portion of which is located within 500 feet of a public water system approved by the county health department shall be connected therewith, provided that mains within that distance can adequately serve the subdivision. Mains shall be provided by the subdivider from point of connection with the public water system to the subdivision; and all mains and service connections necessary to properly serve the subdivision shall be provided and shall be of a size that will furnish at least 15 gallons per minute to each anticipated dwelling unit, the number of dwelling units to be determined by the planning commission based upon the number of parcels for single-family and multiple-family dwelling units indicated on preliminary plat data and upon zoning restrictions (if any), and that will furnish adequate quantity and pressure for fire protection within 1,000 feet of each anticipated dwelling unit. Water lines shall conform with accepted standards of good practice for municipal water systems and shall meet, as a minimum, the specifications of the city water department and the county health department. Where a subdivision is not within 500 feet of an approved public water supply, a community water system approved by the county health department and the city (county) engineer may be provided, in which case deed or plat covenants shall establish a perpetual maintenance organization of property owners so that there is reasonable assurance of proper maintenance; or else the subdivision may be designed for individual water systems, to be installed in accordance with the standards of the county health department. (b) Sewer. When the nearest boundary of the subdivision is located within 500 feet of public sewerage system, sanitary sewers shall be installed and connected with the public system provided that gravity flow is feasible. Mains shall be provided by the subdivider from point of connection with the public sanitary sewer to the subdivision and all mains and service connections necessary to properly serve the subdivision shall be provided. Mains shall be at least eight inches in diameter or of such larger size as may be determined by the city water department, provided that a six-inch main which is not over 400 feet in length may be permitted where topographic conditions prohibit further extension of the main; service connections shall be of four inch diameter. Where the subdivision is not within 500 feet of a public sewerage system, a community sewerage system of design approved by the county health department and the city (county) engineer may be provided, in which case deed or plat covenants shall establish a perpetual maintenance organization of property owners so that there is reasonable assurance of proper maintenance; or the subdivider may provide individual septic tanks and disposal fields, which shall meet the standards of the county health department and the city (county) engineer. The lots to contain individual septic tanks and disposal fields shall meet the minimum area requirements of section 113-143(c)(1) and (2) and may be required by the county health department to have larger areas where the results of percolation tests show that additional area is necessary. (c) Installation of utilities. After rough grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied to the street, all of the underground work (water mains, gas mains, etc., and all service connections) shall be installed completely and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section. Where the utility mains are off the pavement, the developer may elect to omit the installation of service connections providing that at such time as these service connections are needed, they may be jacked across the roadway without breaking or weakening the existing pavement. (d) Distribution of utility cost.
