(1) The subdivider shall be responsible for providing and installing all water and sewer lines and connections, in compliance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section, and shall bear the entire expense subject to the following provisions relating to reimbursement by the city (county): a. For that part of a utility main adjacent or within his subdivision, the subdivider shall be reimbursed for that portion of the cost of the main in excess of the cost of a main of adequate size for his particular subdivision. b. For that part of a utility main which is not within or adjacent to the subdivision, the subdivider shall be reimbursed one-half the entire cost of the main. (2) In making reimbursement under the foregoing provisions, the city (county) may, upon approval by the subdivider, install utility lines and substitute charges for such installation as a part or all of its reimbursement, such installation to be the subject of an agreement executed by both parties and specifying the amount of such charges, as determined in accordance with standard rates established by the city water department for each utility and type of construction. (3) No private equity shall remain or rest in any water or sanitary sewer main or service connection thereof or in any drainage vehicle. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(C)) Sec. 113-231. - Mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions. The requirements of this chapter with respect to site improvements shall apply to mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions, except as altered by the following: (1) Curb and gutter and pavement. Curb and gutter or concrete edging, not reimbursable by city (county), and pavement shall be required for streets within parks or subdivisions. In each case, the paved roadway shall be centered within the right-of-way; and the roadway shall not be less in width (between curbs, where used) than the following:
(2) Accessway. A properly located curb cut (where applicable) and an accessway, for the purpose of maneuvering the mobile home into position, shall be provided on each lot within a park or subdivision and shall be at least 12 feet in width, with gradient, not to exceed eight percent. (3) Mobile home stand. A stand for parking the mobile home shall be provided on each lot within a park in accordance with Federal Housing Administration regulations and city (county) standards. (4) Mobile home patio. A patio shall be provided on each lot within a park or subdivision in accordance with Federal Housing Administration regulations and city (county) standards. (5) Utilities. Each park or subdivision shall be connected with a public water or sewerage system if within 500 feet thereof; and if not within 500 feet, it shall provide its own community system or connect with a public system, such utilities to meet all provisions of section 113-230(a) and (b) applicable thereto. Septic tanks and drainage fields for individual lots shall not be permitted. (6) Storm drainage. Where curb and gutter is used, a storm sewer system shall be provided. Where concrete edging is used, storm drainage ditches will be located at the periphery of the park or subdivision (rather than along the interior streets); and the entire site of the park or subdivision shall be graded to permit such drainage. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(D)) Sec. 113-232. - Cost of site improvement. The entire cost of improvements, including labor, materials, and supervision, incurred in meeting the requirements of article V of this chapter shall be borne by the subdivider except where otherwise specified. Reimbursement of the subdivider by the city (county), in accordance with the various provisions relating thereto, shall be accomplished within 30 days after acceptance by the city (county) engineer of the street and alley improvements and within the same period after acceptance of all other improvements, provided that fully documented cost figures have been submitted prior to that time. Otherwise, the 30-day period shall begin on the date of submission of the cost figures. (Ord. of 7-7-1964, § IV(E)) Appendix A - ZONING[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— The city's zoning ordinance is maintained by and made available for public inspection in the department of community improvement.
